PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Brownhill (from 47 citizens) and Sir John Carrick (from 134 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal System in Australia, the State and Federal and criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education System, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children the unborn, the handicapped the aged and the infirm, employer and the employee relationships and the Australian Society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the fringe benefits tax will place enormous cost increases on employers throughout Australia;
(ii) in so doing, the fringe benefits tax will raise the cost of employing labour particularly in remote locations and it will inevitably worsen the already high level of unemployment in Australia;
(iii) much of the cost of the tax will be carried by employees as employers reduce benefits; and
(iv) the cost of the tax will harm small business particularly as these businesses will be unable to pass on the cost of the tax and as a result many may be forced to close.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Government to repeal this unfair tax before it damages Australian business and thereby reduces the standard of living of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Honourable members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on you to remove this new discrimination which your budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 182 citizens), Crichton-Browne (from 22 citizens) and Vigor (from 103 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Whereas the fringe benefits tax will place a costly and unfair burden on independent schools.

The fringe benefits tax will have the most damaging impact upon schools which provide boarding accommodation for children as they are also required to provide accommodation for staff members to live in and supervise the boarders.

Independent schools have limited resources and this additional impost will ultimately have to be passed onto parents, many of whom are already heavily committed to the financing of their children's education.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Parliament to recognise that the future of Australia depends upon the education given to its children and to exempt schools from the operation of the fringe benefits tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the welfare of many employees and their families depends upon a healthy expanding gold mining industry;
(ii) the success of many small businesses in gold mining towns also depends upon the continued profitability of gold mining and prospecting operations;

(iii) the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining and prospecting represents a threat to the profitability of these industries and will therefore cause widespread unemployment and depression throughout the whole gold mining industry.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Government to reject any proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining or prospecting thereby ensuring that the spectacular growth of the industry over recent years is continued.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oil Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that your Petitioners:
Request that the Hawke Government:
Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners most humbly pray-
That the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing Policy.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer- submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menance to the nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australia-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Callaghan Report
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia humbly pray that the Federal Government join with the Tasmanian Government and institute an independent review of the Callaghan Report into the Structure of Industry and the Employment Situation in Tasmania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support `The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of wide-spread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Ports
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, believing
that Australia should not host nuclear weapons in its territory or in Australian waters; and
that the presence of nuclear-armed warships makes a priority nuclear target of ports being visited; and
that the safety precautions for handling and deployment of nuclear weapons are inadequate to guarantee safety from accidents; and

that the following warships, all capable of launching nuclear weapons deployed in the British or United States navies, will be in Australia between 29 September to 13 October-HMS Illustrious, HMS Beaver, HMS Fort Grange, HMS Manchester, HMS Amazon, HMS Olmeda, USS Missouri, USS Paul F. Foster, USS Oldendorf; and
that these warships capable of carrying nuclear weapons will be participating in the 75th Anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy
We therefore call upon the Australian Government to:
prohibit the entry of nuclear weapons to Australia; and to
deny access to Australian ports of foreign warships unless an assurance is received that they are not carrying nuclear weapons; and to
require that foreign warships participating in the anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy not be carrying nuclear weapons in Australian territorial waters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Country Hour
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

that any decision by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to reduce the local content of the program, the `Country Hour', would represent yet another severe blow to Western Australian rural people;
that even under current programming Western Australian country people receive little locally produced radio, and

in view of the inefficiencies in the operations of the ABC disclosed by the Auditor-General, your petitioners call upon the Government to improve the efficient operation of the ABC before it reduces the local content of important rural programs such as the Country Hour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I present the following petition, which is not in conformity with Standing Orders as it it not in the correct form, from 470 citizens requesting that the Senate oppose legislation to discount CPI DFRB/DFRDB payments:

SPEECH.PARA: We the undersigned object to the unfair legislation to discount CPI DFRB/DFRDB payments by 2 per cent. We request that the Senate intervene on our behalf in opposing the legislation and ask the Senate to remind the Hawke Labor Government that the DFRB/DFRDB scheme is not a welfare payment but an entitlement under the existing DFRB/DFRDB Act.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains and Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BROWNHILL

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petition, which is not in conformity with Standing Orders as it does not contain a prayer at the end thereof, from 110 citizens opposing the capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax legislation:

SPEECH.PARA: We, being very concerned members of Australian society hereby voice our disapproval of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the negative gearing provisions and the substantiation provisions recently passed by Parliament. Such taxes do not assist the business community but do create excess paper work, do not provide incentive and are detrimental to the country and create hardship to the taxpayers affected.

APOLOGY TO HIS EXCELLENCY
MR I. G. BOWDEN

I withdraw without reservation or qualification all accusations, allegations and innuendos which I have at any time made within and outside the Parliament, against Ivor Gordon Bowden, an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs, formerly Australian Ambassador to Iran and Australian Commissioner in Hong Kong and currently serving as Australian Ambassador to Pakistan. While I acted in good faith I acknowledge that I have produced no evidence to sustain these attacks and that successive, competent investigations, whose verdict I unreservedly accept, have on each occasion cleared his name. I regret and apologise sincerely for the distress which these unwarranted attacks have caused him and his family and for any damage which these attacks, including those contained in the letter I wrote to the Head of State of Pakistan on Mr Bowden's appointment as Ambassador may have done to his career and to his standing in the community.
I also apologise to those other persons in Government service whom, in the course of my accusations against Mr Bowden, I unjustly accused of improper actions in the course of their duties.
Dated the 2nd day of October 1986.
CYRIL GRAHAM PRIMMER

APOLOGY TO
MR P. G. F. HENDERSON, AC

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT DEFENCE SPACE RESEARCH FACILITY AT PINE GAP

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes that the agreement between Australia and the United States relating to the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap, dated 19 October 1977, means that Australia is free to notify the United States that it desires to terminate the agreement with one year's notice from 19 October 1986;

(b) notes, too, that the United States co-operating agency is alleged to be the United States Department of Defense whereas in fact the Central Intelligence Agency is using the Department of Defense as a cover;
(c) deplores the refusal of the Hawke Labor Go-vernment and its Liberal predecessor to admit to the existence of the United States National Security Agency at Pine Gap;
(d) condemns the Government for its refusal to tell the nation what else Pine Gap does beyond its monitoring and verification role and what its role would be in a nuclear war fighting scenario; and
(e) calls on the Government to give one year's notice of termination of the Agreement to the United States from 19 October 1986.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that it is my intention at the placing of business today to withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name for the next day of sitting and relating to Part VII of the Children's Ser-vices Ordinance 1986. I seek leave to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I moved for disallowance of Part VII of that ordinance because in my interpretation of it the ordinance would require that community groups such as Sunday schools, Brownies, drama classes and bush walking groups be required to be registered and to seek exemption from the operation of the ordinance. It is my view that that is absurd. The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) agrees that those groups should not be registered. He has given me a letter and a list of the groups which he regards as exempt. It is my view, though, that the ordinance still requires them to register and ought to be amended. I seek leave to incorporate the Minister's letter dated 7 October 1986 and written to me and the attachment headed `Childcare care of a specified class' in which he enu-merates the exempted groups.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Senator Margaret Reid
Senator for the ACT
1st Floor
Ansett Centre
4 Mort Street
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Reid
I refer to your notice of disallowance of Part VII of the Children's Services Ordinance (1986) which was tabled in the Senate on Wednesday 20 August 1986.

I understand that your concerns about Part VII are that it would require any place where more than four children are cared for at any one time to be licensed and therefore community organisations such as Brownies, Scouts and Little Athletics would require a licence as child care providers and, that the new licence conditions under consideration by the Department, would impose onerous burdens on private day care centres.
The Australian Law Reform Commission recommended four children because that reflected the operational standard in all States and Territories including the ACT.

Whilst Part VII of the Ordinance applies to all community and business child care centres, it has always been intended to exempt a number of categories of care. Section 119 of the Ordinance was designed expressly for that purpose. It provides that the Minister may exempt specific child care or child care of a specified class by instrument in writing which must be laid before each House of Parliament and which is subject to disallowance.

Attached for your information is a list illustrating examples of the types of child care which I propose to exempt from the licensing provisions. The exemptions will relate to types of child care and be drafted in a way which will, as far as possible, avoid the need for individual care providers to seek specific exemption. This will ensure that difficulties do not arise for particular individuals or organisations providing care as an incidental to some other community or business purpose. It will also ensure that a consistent and impartial attitude is taken to the giving of exemptions.

On the question of the new licence conditions, these are being prepared in consultation with community groups, private day care operators and parents. The final form of the conditions will not be settled until after further consultation with all interested parties.

It is relevant that the underlying principle of the legislation is the best interests of the child. In this regard I draw your attention to Section 5 (2) which requires that a power which affects or concerns a child must be exercised in such manner as will best lead to the proposed development of the personality of the child and to the child's becoming a responsible and useful member of the community. Such conditions as may be attached to a licence would be developed subject to section 5 (2) and must accordingly place the emphasis on the interests of the child and not those of the provider. I also draw your attention to Section 14b which provides for an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where a licence is granted subject to conditions.
I trust the above information satisfies your concerns about Part VII of the proposed Ordinance and you will consider withdrawal of your motion on notice.
I have forwarded copies of this letter to Senator the Honourable Peter Baume and Senator Austin Lewis.
Yours sincerely
GORDON SCHOLES

DEBATE.TITLE: SOUTH PACIFIC NUCLEAR FREE ZONE TREATY BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave, Mr President, to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to certain obligations that Australia has as a party to the Treaty on a South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone. This Bill is complemented by the projected amendments to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 relating to the dumping of radioactive waste, and the provisions of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill 1986, relating to the application of safeguards to nuclear material, which cover obligations under the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty referred to but not provided for in this Bill.

Enactment of this body of legislation, and the making of some related regulations are prerequisites for Australian ratification of the Treaty. The implementing legislation in fact goes beyond the minimum that is technically required for the purpose of ratification: it covers all the substantive provisions of the Treaty. This course of action was chosen by the Government to reflect the Government's commitment to the objectives and provisions of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, as well as ALP policy on the manufacture, testing and stationing of nuclear weapons in or and by Australia.

Honourable Senators will recall that on 6 August 1985, the fortieth anniversary of the first use of atomic weapons, the Heads of Government of countries members of the South Pacific Forum and meeting at Rarotonga, endorsed the text of the Treaty and opened it for signature. Ten of the thirteen countries eligible to sign have already done so. Apart from Australia, they are the Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, Nauru, New Zealand, Niue, Papua New Guinea, Tuvalu and Western Samoa. Four countries have already ratified the Treaty, namely, the Cook Islands, Fiji, Niue and Tuvalu. The Treaty will enter into force when the eighth instrument of ratification has been lodged with the depositary who, as established in the Treaty is the Director of the Bureau for South Pacific Economic Cooperation at Suva.

Many see the Treaty as the South Pacific Forum's most ambitious and far-reaching endeavour so far. Whatever the truth of that, the Treaty shows that the Forum has come of age not only as the authentic and collective voice of the South Pacific region but as an actor able to make that voice clearly heard on the world stage.

The Treaty was an initiative of Australia's and specifically of the Hawke Government. The Government, as soon as it gained office, began work to achieve consensus within the South Pacific on a Nuclear Free Zone. Australia promoted the concept at the Fourteenth South Pacific Forum which met at Canberra in August 1983. In August 1984, the Fifteenth South Pacific Forum meeting at Funafuti, Tuvalu, endorsed a set of principles proposed by Australia as a basis for a Zone and appointed a Working Group of Officials with Australia in the Chair to prepare the text of a Treaty. It was that text which Heads of Government endorsed.

If the initiative for a Zone was Australia's, the Treaty itself constitutes a genuinely collective effort by the thirteen member countries of the Forum. Not only was it endorsed by the thirteen Heads of Government, but virtually every member country of the Forum contributed substantially to the work of development and drafting. Some countries made the main running on some aspects and some on others. Every country can see its hand in the text we now have.

Forum Governments in drafting the Treaty drew on, among other things, the provisions of existing international arrangements prohibiting the proliferation of nuclear weapons and establishing demilitarised and nuclear weapons free zones, notably the Antarctic Treaty (1959)-the earliest of the post-World War II arms limitation agreements-the Treaty of Tlatelolco (1967); the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) of 1968 and the Seabed Arms Control Treaty (1971). Forum Governments gave particular attention to the NPT, which, with 134 parties, is the most-widely supported of all international arms control agreements and especially to its Article VII which recognises the right of any group of States to conclude regional treaties so as to assure the total absence of nuclear weapons in their respective territories. The Treaty of Tlatelolco which broke important ground by establishing the first nuclear weapons free zone in a populated region, namely Latin America, created a precedent valuable to the work of Forum Governments. That they were able to draw on the Latin American achievement is evident in the fact that the Treaty of Rarotonga goes beyond it in several respects.

The Treaty is widely recognised around the world as a significant measure. It has been welcomed by the international community, especially at a time when the world has little to point to by way of progress on arms control and disarmament; and the Forum has been congratulated on it. I note, in passing for example, that in September 1985 the Third Review Conference of the NPT in its final declaration welcomed the achievement of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty ``as consistent with Article VII of the NPT''. I draw attention also to the communique issued by 46 Commonwealth Heads of Government following their meeting at Bahamas in October 1985 which welcomed the Treaty as ``an important step in global and regional efforts to prevent nuclear proliferation''. Recently, on 25 September, the joint assembly of African, Caribbean and Pacific and EEC countries at which some 78 States were represented adopted a resolution lending support to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, urging the nuclear weapon States to sign its Protocols and urging France to end its nuclear testing in the Pacific.

The Treaty expresses the strong community of interest which members of the South Pacific Forum share in environmental and security matters and reflects the deeply felt and long-standing concerns in our region about nuclear testing, the ocean-dumping of nuclear waste and the horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons. It commits the parties to important obligations in those areas.

It also reflects, in the words of the preamble, the determination of the people of the South Pacific ``that the bounty and beauty of the land and the sea in their region shall remain the heritage of their peoples and their descendants in perpetuity to be enjoyed by all in peace''.

At the same time the Treaty does not seek to undermine the factors that have created and sustained the very favourable security environment which the South Pacific enjoys. It does not in any way conflict with Australia's defence arrangements, notably ANZUS. It does not run counter to our support for stable nuclear deterrence. It does not impede in any way our ability to co-operate militarily with our allies. The same is true of this Bill. On the contrary, it seeks to build on those factors by, for example, the provisions against nuclear weapons which will help to ensure that the South Pacific, unlike other parts of the world, does not in the future become a theatre for nuclear confrontation.
I turn to two important aspects of the Treaty: the boundaries of the Zone and its title. Forum Governments in developing the Zone considered two approaches.
an incomplete ``patchwork'' approach, with the Zone confined to the territories of countries which adhere to the Treaty
a ``diagrammatic'' approach, with a boundary line circumscribing the Forum countries as well as large areas of the high seas.

Forum Governments strongly preferred the diagrammatic approach since it was easier to visualise and clearly identifies the region to which the Zone was intended to apply. They set the boundaries of the zone in the East, to abut on the existing nuclear weapons free zone in Latin America, in the South, to abut on the completely demilitarised zone established by the Antarctic Treaty, in the north, to follow the equator but with some humps to accommodate the Exclusive Economic Zones of Papua New Guinea, Kiribati and Nauru and, in the West, to run along the outer limit of the Australian territorial sea. Australia's external territories in the Indian Ocean are also covered by the provisions of the Treaty of Rarotonga but our Antarctic territories are not since they have long been subject to the Antarctic Treaty. Greater detail on the negotiating history of the boundaries of the Zone and other aspects of the Rarotonga Treaty is to be found in the report by the Chair of the Working Group of South Pacific Forum officials. The report is germane in interpreting the Treaty and bears on this legislation.

Even though Forum Governments chose the diagrammatic approach I stress that Forum members, like all other countries, are able to agree to provisions affecting the actions of other States, only in relation to their own territories and, to a much more limited extent, in areas of jurisdiction outside their territory. Beyond that, Forum members can only undertake Treaty obligations in relation to their own actions, and actions on their own ships and aircraft. The Treaty does not seek to mislead or create false expectations by pretending to legislate in disregard of these constraints. Neither does the Bill now before us.

I refer also to the title of the Treaty and, in particular to the appropriateness of the term ``Nuclear Free''. Clearly it is beyond the legal power and practical capability of Forum Governments, including the powers and capabilities of the Australian Government, to exclude all things nuclear from the Zone. Moreover, whatever Forum Governments sought to do within the Zone, it would remain part of a world in which nuclear weapons exist and the peaceful use of nuclear energy and materials is widespread. I draw the attention of Honourable Senators, in this connection, to the term ``nuclear weapon free zone'' which has long been established in United Nations and other international usage, for example, the Latin American and Antarctic Zones which do not preclude transit or visits by ships. In the case of the Treaty of Rarotonga, however, its key obligations go beyond those relating to nuclear weapons and encompass as well the dumping of nuclear waste and strong safeguards on the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. It is for that reason and because no freedom is absolute that Forum Governments concluded that the term ``Nuclear Free'' should appropriately form part of the title of the Treaty and the Zone.

The Bill at hand gives effect to the provisions of the Treaty throughout the Commonwealth, in all States and in every external Australian Territory. It extends to the Australian Antarctic Territories since Antarctica too is free from nuclear weapons by virtue of the Antarctic Treaty.

I turn now to the specific clauses of the Bill and draw the attention of Honourable Senators to its interpretative provisions at Clause 4. Honourable Senators will see that in Clause 4 the term ``nuclear explosive device'' has the same meaning as it does in the Treaty, namely, ``any nuclear weapon or other explosive device capable of releasing nuclear energy, irrespective of the purpose for which it could be used. The term includes such a weapon or device in unassembled and partly assembled forms, but does not include the means of transport or delivery of such a weapon or device if separable from and not an indivisible part of it''. I stress that the inclusion of delivery systems in the definition of a nuclear explosive device would have presented serious difficulties since such systems capable of being used with conventional weapons members in their conventional defence forces. How, for example, is a meaningful distinction to be drawn between military aircraft which could be either conventionally or nuclear armed. Or for that matter between rockets that can and do deliver non-nuclear or even civilian payloads but may also be used to deliver a nuclear warhead. On the other hand, the term ``nuclear explosive device'' as defined in the Treaty, and thus in this Bill, includes so-called ``peaceful'' nuclear explosive devices as well as nuclear weapons because, technically and in non-proliferation terms, it is impossible to distinguish between them. That is an important point of difference between the Treaties of Rarotonga and Tlatelolco since the latter seeks to make that distinction.
I now turn to the specific prohibitions in the Treaty of Rarotonga and the manner in which they are reflected in Part II of the Bill before the Senate.

The Treaty includes an obligation on Parties not to manufacture or otherwise acquire, possess or have control over any nuclear explosive device by any means anywhere inside or outside the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone. The Bill provides in its Clause 8 that the manufacture, production and acquisition of nuclear explosive devices is prohibited. In its Clause 9, it goes on to equally prohibit research and development for the purpose or directed towards the manufacture or production of a nuclear explosive device. And Clause 10 prohibits possession of or control over nuclear explosive devices.
These three provisions thus give effect to Article 3 (a) of the Treaty.

The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and the Treaty of Rarotonga prohibit Parties from having, among other things, control over nuclear explosives. In drafting the legislation and extending this prohibition to individuals it has been necessary to make provision to ensure that this prohibition was not interpreted in ways not intended by the Treaties. Thus, for example, a visiting Head of State or Senior Military Officer from one of the nuclear weapon States has `control' over nuclear weapons and vehicles which carry them although these weapons may be as far way as on the other side of the planet. A visit by such a person to Australia is clearly not contrary to the Treaties and the Bill explicitly provides that it is not a contravention of the Bill. It could also be maintained that some Australians have control over nuclear explosive devices if they are in a position to interrupt communications between foreign ships or aircraft which carry such weapons and their foreign command centres. The example which springs to mind is an Australian employee at North West Cape where the Defence Minister has explained to us, Australia could intercept and prevent a message to fire a nuclear device despatched to, for example, the commander of a nuclear missile-capable submarine. Clearly, this is not what the prohibitions of the NPT and the Treaty of Rarotonga on ``control'' of nuclear explosives were intended to cover, and the Bill explicitly provides that any such ``control'' would not be a contravention of the legislation.

The Treaty in its Article 5 requires Parties to prevent the stationing of any nuclear device in their territory. The definition of ``stationing'' contained in the Treaty also applies to the Legislation. It draws from the definition of stationing in the Latin American Treaty: that Treaty says that stationing means stockpiling or storage of nuclear explosives or their installation or deployment. Deployment of a nuclear explosive weapon in normal usage means that it is set out ready for combat. This definition of stationing was thought to be sufficient for the Latin American Treaty but the Forum Working Group which drafted the Treaty of Rarotonga wanted to make doubly sure that it had a fully comprehensive definition of stationing. It therefore added the concepts of emplantation or emplacement which come from the Seabed Arms Control Treaty of 1971. To ensure that the prohibition on stationing is all-inclusive, the drafters of the Treaty of Rarotonga added to these international established concepts a reference to transportation on land or inland waters, so that there could be no possible circumvention of the prohibition through the deployment of nuclear explosives on mobile platforms.

Some may claim an inconsistency here with the fact that the Treaty of Rarotonga explicitly recognises the rights of parties to permit foreign ships and aircraft to visit their ports and airfields, to allow foreign aircraft to overfly their territory and to allow foreign ships to navigate in their territorial seas, over and beyond the rights of navigation which they already have under international law and which could obviously not have been abridged by the Treaty. A similar understanding was registered in connection with the Latin American Treaty. This is not an inconsistency but reflection of a deliberate intention to make clear the distinction between the stationing of nuclear weapons by the parties to the Treaty themselves or by others on their territory and each party's sovereign right to continue collective security arrangements with external powers. In the course of Australia's defence co-operation with the United States and the United Kingdom it may happen, for example, that nuclear weapons are temporarily present in Australian waters and ports by virtue of visits by those countries naval ships.

Thus, the Treaty of Rarotonga and the present legislation which gives effect to it, in no way impede Australia's ability to maintain military cooperation and exchanges with its allies and friends and particularly with the United States under ANZUS. We can continue to receive visits by United States ships and aircraft to our ports and airfields. United States aircraft can transit our air space and our waters. United States ships and aircraft can participate in exercises in Australia and its territorial waters. Allied and friendly warships can go into dry dock in Australia. All this is permissible under the Treaty and under the proposed legislation because it does not constitute stationing. The Treaty definition of stationing and Article 15 (2) of the Treaty of Rarotonga make this clear and it is reflected in Clause 15 of the Bill.
Clause 12 of the Bill prohibits the testing of nuclear explosive devices by rendering it an offence for any person to undertake or carry out a test of such a device.

Following the text of the Treaty, the Bill in Clause 13 prohibits any person from doing ``any act or thing to facilitate the manufacture, production, acquisition or testing by any person (including a foreign country) of a nuclear explosive device whether in or outside Australia''. This gives effect to the Treaty obligation not to ``assist or encourage'' these activities.

The concept of facilitation was extensively discussed by the Working Group of officials which drafted the Treaty. The prohibition is clearly against taking action to facilitate. This means action deliberately directed at the prohibited activities, not action undertaken for other purposes which can give the unintended effect of facilitating. For example, Australia and several other Forum countries regularly broadcast meteorological information which may be useful to the French authorities in deciding on the timing of nuclear tests at Mururoa. Clearly, the Treaty does not require Australia or other Forum countries to cease broadcasting meteorological information. Equally clearly, it would require us to refuse refuelling facilities for foreign military aircraft primarily engaged in supporting a nuclear testing program. The prohibition on facilitating the production of nuclear explosive devices does not in any way interfere with Australia's ability to support stable nuclear deterrence. This fact is explicitly recorded in the report of the Working Group. But, equally clearly, the prohibition on facilitating the manufacture or production of nuclear explosive devices by any country means that Australian uranium cannot be exported for use in nuclear explosives. That would be contrary to the Treaty of Rarotonga and it would be contrary to the legislation I now propose. It has been the policy of successive Australian Governments since 1977 that Australian uranium should only be exported under conditions which give grounds for confidence that it will not be diverted into the manufacture of nuclear weapons or so-called peaceful nuclear explosives. The Treaty of Rarotonga makes this a binding legal international obligation. The Bill now before the Senate renders it a matter of Australian law.

I am aware of assertions to the effect that the Government's decision to lift the embargo on uranium exports to France is in some way inconsistent with the Treaty. This is not so. Australia's stringent safeguards agreements, including that with France, provide that Australian uranium will not be diverted to military or nuclear explosive purposes and that Australian uranium and derived generations of nuclear material will be covered by IAEA safeguards to verify compliance with this. Uranium exports under these conditions are entirely consistent with the strong safeguards on the peaceful uses of nuclear energy embodied in Articles 4 and 8 of the Treaty of Rarotonga.

On safeguards to ensure the peaceful use of nuclear material, I simply note here that provision for imposing and maintaining such safeguards, pursuant to Australia's obligations under Articles 4 and 8 of, and Annex 2 to, the Treaty of Rarotonga, is made in the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill 1986.

Similarly, Provision for the prevention of the dumping at sea of radioactive waste and other radioactive matter, pursuant to Australia's obligations under Article 7 of the Treaty, is made in the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 through the amendments recently tabled by my colleague, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment. That legislation also includes provisions against aiding and abetting activities which it prohibits, thereby giving effect to the Treaty prohibition on facilitating dumping.

The Bill provides appropriately severe penalties (including up to 20 years imprisonment) for offences committed under Part II relating to the Treaty prohibitions. In view of the severity of these sentences the Attorney-General's consent will be necessary to institute any proceedings against individuals or corporations under Part II. Lesser penalties are imposed for offences under parts IV and V relating to inspections, investigations into possible breaches of the legislation and hearings in camera. The Crown will be bound by the Act although it will not be liable to prosecutions for offences under it.

The Treaty makes provision for special inspections in the event of an alleged breach of the Treaty by a Party to it. These inspections are to be carried out by international inspectors appointed by the Consultative Committee established by the Treaty and on the basis of a directive given to them by the Committee. These inspectors, referred to as Treaty inspectors in the Bill, will be subject only to the direction of the Consultative Committee. Nevertheless, to ensure that the Australian Government can comply with its Treaty obligations and take all appropriate steps to facilitate any such inspection in Australia, the Bill gives Treaty inspectors appropriate powers under Australian law to enable them to carry out their inspections. In addition, the Minister may appoint authorised officers to accompany Treaty inspectors, with powers under the Act to facilitate treaty inspections, and may call upon inspectors from the Australian Safeguards Office to assist the authorised officers and Treaty inspectors in their work. It would be the Australian Safeguards Office inspector who would secure warrants if these were needed, for the Treaty inspection. I should add that the Treaty expressly permits host governments to appoint representatives to accompany Treaty inspectors while in the country. Regulations conferring privileges and immunities on Treaty inspectors, as required by the Treaty, will be made under appropriate existing legislation in due course.

The inspectors from the Australian Safeguards Office, in addition to their role in assisting Treaty inspections, are also given such powers as are necessary for them to investigate possible breaches of the legislation. These powers are substantially the same as those accorded inspectors under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill 1986.

May I reassure honourable senators, that this legislation will involve no financial expenditure on the part of the Government. The Australian Safeguards Office is already fully competent to discharge the tasks required of its inspectors under this Bill.

I conclude by stressing that this Bill is not simply a legal instrument to give effect to Australia's obligations under the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. It is not simply an expression of the desire of the Australian people and of this Government to do whatever can be done to strengthen the peace and security of this nation. It is an expression of the urgent need for Australia to make the fullest practical contribution, within our means, to reduce for all humankind the risk of nuclear war. The Government cannot emphasise the point heavily enough that nuclear weapons, deployed in global defence systems for more than a generation, will not disappear overnight. The nuclear powers have made it clear that they will not disarm unilaterally or easily. The Government recognises that success in arms control and disarmament will be won, not by grand and satisfying gesture, but by painstaking and often tedious work. I instance the consistent effort that the Government and its officers have devoted to encouraging a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean, establishing a network of seismic monitoring facilities in Australia as part of a worldwide system to monitor a ban on nuclear testing, negotiating arrangements to keep the arms race from outer space and (most importantly) taking the initiative towards a comprehensive and verifiable ban on nuclear testing. The Government is proud to include the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone among these initiatives.
I commend the measure to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave, Mr President, to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

On 15 April 1986, the Acting Treasurer announced the Government's decision to phase out the operations of the Rural Credits Department (RCD) of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA). The principal objective of this Bill is to facilitate the winding up of the RCD and to abolish the Department once its operations have ceased.

The RCD was originally established in 1925 to meet the seasonal funding requirements of primary produce authorities and co-operatives. RCD funds have been made available at market related interest rates in recent years and, with the deregulation of financial markets, this has resulted in a much reduced role for the RCD with the great majority of seasonal funding requirements being fulfilled through commercial sources.

The decision to wind down the activities of the Rural Credits Department stems from the recommendations of the Australian Financial System Inquiry and the Review Group on the Australian Financial System. Both committees considered that in view of the developments which have taken place in financial markets since the Department was first established it was no longer necessary, or desirable, for the RBA to continue to be involved in providing seasonal advances. Both groups noted, however, that termination of the RCD should be preceded by an appropriate transitional period to enable RCD customers to arrange alternative sources of finance.

In line with this recommendation, the Government, in phasing out the operations of the RCD, has implemented transitional arrangements to allow those remaining authorities and co-operatives which utilise RCD advances to have access to the facility for the duration of one full commodity season following the announcement of the Government's decision.

Clause 11 of the Bill, which provides for the winding up of the Rural Credits Department, would restrict the Reserve Bank from making an advance or discounting a bill after 30 June 1988, or such later date as is determined by the Treasurer. This is to allow sufficient time for remaining customers to exercise their final drawing rights.

As at 30 June 1986, the capital and reserves of the RCD stood at $140 million. Clause 11 of the Bill provides that, as the activities of the RCD are wound down, the capital and reserves of the RCD which are surplus to its operational requirements can be distributed to either the Reserve Bank Reserve Fund or Consolidated Revenue, as determined by the Treasurer following consultations with the Board of the Reserve Bank. When the activities of the RCD have ceased and its capital and reserves have been distributed, the Department may be abolished on a day fixed by Proclamation.

I would also note that, under existing legislation, half of the profits of the RCD have been applied to rural research. Funds available for this purpose from the RCD should be increased by approximately 9% to $3.0 million in 1986-87 through the normal transfer of profits earned by the RCD in 1985-86. Consideration will be given to supplementing funds available for rural research in future years as the activities of the RCD are phased out.

The Bill contains other consequential amendments to the Reserve Bank Act 1959 in relation to termination of the RCD as well as the repeal of certain sections of the Banking Act 1959 which deal with the statistical returns to be provided by the RCD to the Reserve Bank.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (WORKS AND HOUSING) ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Act 1985 so as to authorise payments in 1986-87 arising out of decisions, taken at the 13 June 1986 Loan Council meeting, which fall outside the provisions of the Financial Agreement Act 1928. Specifically, this Bill seeks to authorise the payment of general purpose capital grants to the States in 1986-87; the prepayment of Capital Grants during the first six months of 1987-88, pending passage of similar legislation in that year; and, the alteration of the amounts that may be nominated by the States and the Northern Territory from their approved borrowing programs for the purposes of public housing in 1986-87.
Capital Grants to States

Since 1970-71 a portion of the State Governments' borrowing programs have been provided by the Commonwealth as interest free capital grants. The grants were introduced to help States finance works, such as schools and other capital works, from which debt charges are not normally recovered. The effect of these grants, therefore, is to relieve the States of those debt charges-that is, interest payments and sinking fund contributions-which they would otherwise have to pay, and the grants accordingly have a substantial beneficial effect on the overall financial positions of the States. In addition, there are no conditions attaching to the manner in which the grants are applied by the States.

In the ten years prior to 1985-86 the grants represented one-third of the State governments' borrowing programs. In that year the portion of the programs provided as a capital grant was temporarily increased by 7 per cent to approximately 35.7 per cent, with the loan portion being reduced by an equivalent amount. This arrangement is to be continued in 1986-87. As the Loan Council agreed to limit the total State governments' Loan Council program to $1,204m in 1986-87, 23 per cent less than for 1985-86, the total amount of capital grants to be provided for 1986-87 is $429m.
Public Housing Nominations

The arrangements whereby the States and the Northern Territory are able to nominate part of their approved borrowing programs for public housing were introduced in 1982-83. The arrangements have contributed considerably to the financing of public housing in the States and the encouragement of the States to increase their own housing expenditures.

As a condition of the payment of these funds, a State or the Northern Territory must be able to meet its matching requirements for the purposes of the Housing Assistance Act 1984. Subject to that, the nominated funds will be provided to the States and the Northern Territory at the loan terms and conditions set out in the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, and hence will bear interest at the highly favourable rate of 4 1/2 per cent per annum and will be repayable over 53 years.

In the Commonwealth Government's housing assistance package which the Treasurer and the Minister for Housing and Construction announced on 2 April, 1986, the Government indicated that it was prepared to allow the States and the Northern Territory to nominate up to 60 per cent of the loan portion of their programs for public housing. At the loan council meeting on 13 June, 1986 it was also agreed that Western Australia and South Australia, which nominated the whole of the loan portion of their programs in previous years, could again nominate the whole of the loan portion for public housing in 1986-87. This Bill seeks to give effect to those decisions.
This Bill forms an important part of the Commonwealth's overall financial assistance to the States and the Northern Territory and I therefore commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Archer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Messages received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to the following Bills:
Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986
Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986

Bill returned from the House of Representatives with a message intimating that it had agreed to the amendment made by the Senate to this Bill as an alternative to the amendment to which the House had disagreed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to notice of intention to withdraw, given earlier today, I now withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Regulations 2, 7 and 9 of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (Inquiries) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1986 No. 100 and made under the Broadcasting Act 1942, be disallowed.

These regulations deal with a significant and unjustifiable intrusion upon civil liberties in the first case, and with significant and unjustifiable intrusions on the effective and efficient operation of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in the other two cases. I shall be quoting directly from a reply the Tribunal has made to an inquiry of mine to help establish the unsuitability of regulations 7 and 9. Before I deal with these individual regulations and the continuing saga behind their emergence in operation, I want to explain why the best course of action open to the Senate is, in fact, to disallow these three regulations.

It is a timely coincidence that yesterday the eightieth report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was tabled by Senator Cooney, the excellent Chairman of that Committee. Senator Cooney, in his tabling speech, drew attention to a number of serious flaws in the Acts Interpretation Act which restrict the Senate's ability to improve delegated legislation. As Senator Cooney said:

. . . although each House of Parliament has a power of partial disallowance over Australian Capital Territory ordinances, there is no similar power of partial disallowance over Federal regulations and other instruments.

In fact, the Committee report indicates that since 1957 the Senate has been unable to disallow even a single word or figure in an Australian Capital Territory ordinance. There is no restriction on what the Senate or the House of Representatives can remove from ordinances made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910. However, this freedom has not been extended to the handling of regulations which we can disallow under the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. All we can do in this case is disallow whole regulations even though there might be only a couple of objectionable words in each of the regulations.

Yesterday, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee pointed out that action to remedy this problem was promised by the Fraser Government but not finalised before it went out of office. I join with the Committee in urging the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to deal effectively with this problem; otherwise amendments will have to be moved to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill in the near future.

In this case, the Department is putting forward the extraordinary notion that if a group has fewer than 20 members it has to supply to the Tribunal the name of each of the members in any written submission to the Tribunal. I will come directly to why this does not sit well with the current legislation and to what the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal thinks of this requirement. For the moment, I point out that this intrusion upon civil liberties could be prevented by the removal of 18 words, one number and two commas in one part of one definition. The result would be that all unincorporated associations would have to provide particulars of the objects of their association and the names of the association's office bearers. This is quite reasonable in all the circumstances, instead of having two separate requirements depending on whether there are 20 members in the organisation or fewer than 20.

The Senate does not have the power to make this sensible and straightforward deletion. It does not even have the power to delete the definition of `prescribed particulars' from this part of the interpretation provisions. To fix the matter, we have to remove the whole of regulation 2. Regulation 2 contains those definitions which basically are there for clarity, as many of them are tied to specific sections of the Broadcasting Act. The regulations will survive basically intact if we remove this section of the interpretation provisions. It is a pity, though, that the Senate is not able to take the most constructive course. This problem should be solved in the near future.

In relation to this matter, I want to mention also that paragraph 4 (1) (b) requires that an application to the Tribunal must state what substantive power is being invoked in that application. The difficulty is that even learned counsel appearing before the High Court of Australia have got such matters wrong in the past. Perhaps, if the application form to the Tribunal were designed with some boxes next to the Tribunal's list of substantive powers, people could just tick what they thought was relevant. However, the forms are not like that. Some people may well be put off making an application because they are not sure about these powers. It does not matter that sub-regulation 4 (4) says that strict compliance with the regulation is not necessary and substantial compliance is sufficient. The damage will be done earlier because people will be daunted by the bureaucratic requirements and hence will decide not to make applications.

Surely the Tribunal can work out what powers it thinks it is acting under. Why have these useless and convoluted requirements been put into the regulations? Regulation 4 would be improved greatly by the removal of paragraph 4 (1) (b). However, the Senate is not allowed to take that constructive step at the moment. The Australian Democrats will not seek to toss out the whole regulation because of the disadvantage that would place on individuals and groups wanting the Tribunal to exercise one of those powers. We stop at pointing out the way some people will feel shut out by all the unnecessary formality. We hope that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will be able to take some administrative action to minimise this problem that it did not create. In the explanatory statement accompanying the regulations there is another extraordinary paragraph that I want to follow up. It reads:

No provision is made by the regulations at this stage for review on the merits by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Administrative Review Council proposes to consider the desirability of such a review of the Tribunal's procedural decisions as part of a reconsideration of rights of review of the Tribunal's decisions under the Broadcasting Act. The ARC review is likely to commence during 1986.

This sort of approach is quite frightening. It could come only from a department hellbent on shackling and crippling the Tribunal. It could come only from a department that has learnt no lessons from the litigation and extra expense that was created during the Perth inquiry as a result of the Department's dereliction. The Department seems to be completely away from the real world in its Belconnen tower. It is more or less saying that it wants to open up even more opportunities for litigation in this case. That is beyond belief. I hope that we can move in the opposite direction in relation to area inquiries, and have a freer operation of the Tribunal without all the usual legalities, QC's and legal proceedings.

The last sentence in the quotation about the ARC's activities anticipated for this year has a choice irony about it. We are dealing only now with the fruits of the Administrative Review Council's expedited work from 1980 and 1981. If this type of delay happened in the private sector-we are now in 1986-there would be wholesale sackings at the policy and implementation levels within the firms concerned. It probably means increasing promotions in the Department, as good people continue to leave in droves because there is such a paralysis in the area. After all, we have seen major changes in the operation of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal since the wild west days of its early years. Policy statements and practice notes have been coming out regularly. Decisions have been formally recorded in the course of hearings. The results of court challenges have modified procedures. So, in a sense, to hang a regulatory peg on what was recommended five years ago is very anachronistic. To have the Administrative Review Council do another review just as new regulations come in seems a little strange to say the least. It is not good enough for the Department continually to shut the gate after the horse has bolted. The Department should be kept right away from deciding what conditions the Tribunal will work under. There is a clear conflict of interest as the unimaginative activities of the Forward Development Unit have made clear. This Parliament and nation cannot afford to let major broadcasting problems fester because the Department either is not interested or is not up to it at policy level.

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal Inquiries Regulations came virtually a whole year after the passage of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985. Instead of being available at the start of this year as expected, nothing turned up until late May. In the meantime some notices relating to the new radio services were issued and withdrawn because of defects and the absence of regulations. These delays are costing the Government licence fee revenue each time they occur. The whole saga is available for reading under the freedom of information legislation. The history of regulation 2 which I am seeking to disallow, shows precisely what is wrong with the Department and why the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal should take over the carriage of the regulations which affect it. We discover that originally the Department did not see any distinction between unincorporated associations with fewer than 20 members and the other types of unincorporated associations. A departmental briefing note, which I received through the Minister, says:

The Department did not initially instruct the draftsman to include this provision following strong representations from the ABT that the requirement for such information was an unfair and onerous obligation to impose on such bodies and involved an unnecessary workload for the Tribunal.

That note continues with public interest groups saying that the requirement to submit all the names was an unfair invasion of privacy. After all, section 22aa of the Broadcasting Act says that the criterion for the Tribunal to take note of a document is that it be relevant to the inquiry. Then comes the clincher:
However, during the later discussions it became clear that industry argued in the strongest possible terms for the inclusion of this basic information.

Basically the Department takes its obligations to consult the industry as meaning that it does what the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations and the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters want it to do when they start pounding the table. I found it rather eerie for the Department to talk of balancing the interests of the broadcasting industry, the public interest groups such as the Media and Communications Council and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with those of the commercial organisations-FACTS and FARB. This is precisely why the Department gets into so much trouble, as in fact the supplementary licence fiasco and the equalisation disaster show. The Department can think only in terms of what its client groups want. It is not interested in and perhaps no longer capable of starting with what is best for an open, accountable broadcasting system and, indeed, I am very greatly saddened by this case. I believe that many fellow Australians are saddened in the same way.

I believe that we need some degree of remedial action. Why now should groups with less than 20 members submit all the names of members but other groups not? What is magical about the number 20? In the Estimates committees proceedings I was told it emerged from an extensive consultation. In fact, I quote, 20 was supposedly:
. . . a reasonable level to establish in requiring an organisation to list its local membership rather than just its office holders.
It happens to be the number recommended by the Administrative Review Council in 1981. But what do we find when we go to that report? Paragraph 54 of that report states:

The Council has accepted suggestions by some people who made submissions to it that the procedure should make provision for particulars to be available of the composition of unincorporated associations participating in inquiries and of their objects of association.

All we know at this stage is that it was not FACTS because that group did not get involved in this inquiry at all. I have already pointed out that the rules of standing before the Tribunal were liberalised last year. I add that the ARC's recommendation of a register of unincorporated associations has, in fact, been discarded. It does not require much intelligence to realise that there really is no way of checking whether or not an association has at least 20 members. So what we have here is some gratuitous voyeurism-some early detection scheme for suspected ratbags, but something which is really ineffective. Yet the legislation says that the relevance is the only criterion for the Tribunal to consider a matter. Let me quote what the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal had to say when responding recently to a letter of mine seeking information about the Tribunal's experience of these regulations. It said:

We regard the information required under regulations 4 (2) and 10 (2) as irrelevant to the inquiry process. Section 22aa of the Broadcasting Act 1942 makes it clear that any person lodging an application or a relevant submission is a party to proceedings at an ordinary inquiry. It does not really matter who that person is. The essential issue is whether what is being said is relevant to the inquiry. In some inquiries, especially inquiries into program standards, it could be that the numerical strength of a particular opinion might affect the weight given to a particular opinion (although we have to be careful about relying on mere volume), but names and addresses of any one but the submitter are never likely to be of interest to the Tribunal, and their inclusion in the material to be supplied in an inquiry gives the erroneous impression that the Tribunal regards them as significant.

I wholeheartedly endorse this approach. The Australian Democrats would have been satisfied with earlier drafts of the regulations which stipulated that just the office bearers and the total membership figures should be included. Naturally, groups should be encouraged to spell out more information about their objects and activities, but a full disclosure of names somehow smacks of Big Brother. The process whereby this provision slithered into the regulation is a terrible indictment of the Department's method of setting up these regulations.

I come to regulation 7. Regulation 7 also goes back to 1981, by a curious coincidence. However, this time the opposite of a clear-cut recommendation of the Administrative Review Council is being implemented. It amounts to a hidden subsidy for those who are often vociferous about the user pays principle. It certainly flies in the face completely of the Government's attempts to recover as much as possible of the stated costs of procedures under the freedom of information legislation. Perhaps this could happen only in the Department of Communications.

Regulation 7 quite reasonably requires the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to notify licensees about relevant submissions lodged in the course of an inquiry. It then places an obligation on the Tribunal to furnish these licensees or their umbrella organisations with copies of all the relevant submissions free of charge. This service is of course available only to those most able to pay for it; that is, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, and individual licensees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. A standing order of the Senate states that speeches shall not be read. I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Vigor is reading every word of his speech.

—Senator Vigor, I must say that it is my impression that you are reading but you might give confidence that you are not if you look up more frequently when you are addressing the Senate. You are not permitted to read your speech but you are perfectly entitled to read quotations.

—I have some detailed material in my notes. Basically, the removal of regulation 7 would enable the Tribunal to recover some of its expenses of providing this sort of material. It is important that the Government should be consistent in these matters and be prepared to recover the costs of photocopying from those people who are supplied with copies of material put before the Tribunal. It is an utter disgrace that the Government should be putting up the cost of freedom of information services at the same time as it is providing free photocopying for FACTS, FARB and those types of organisations. It is for that reason that the Democrats oppose regulation 7. I hope that the Department will provide information about the anticipated cost to the Tribunal of supplying such documents. If this measure is not supported by the Opposition, I hope that the Senate will have information available to it to see how the cost compares with the costs the Government intends to recover under freedom of information provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn next to regulation 9, which basically binds the Tribunal in senseless red tape. Under regulation 9 it is almost impossible for the Tribunal to conduct an inquiry it initiates in less than three months. If the Opposition is honest in its view about deregulation and if the Government and the Opposition are reasonable, they will see from this regulation and from regulation 8 that the times involved in regulation 9 mean that it will take at least three months for any type of inquiry, however simple, to be put in train if the Tribunal initiates it. There would be much greater control over the workload of the Tribunal if the Tribunal could have greater control over the inquiries it initiates and handle each case effectively. It would also serve the Broadcasting Tribunal well if it had the ability to expedite inquiries in which only a few people were involved.
The Tribunal, in its letter to me, made the following comments about administrative inflexibilities:

The significant problem already manifest is that the Tribunal must deal with any application for an amendment of the program standards through the inquiry process laid down in the regulations. There are two difficulties with this. The first is that there are already signs that the Tribunal will receive a large number of applications designed to facilitate the showing of one particular program, or to `pick off' particular aspects of the Tribunal's standards. The Tribunal has prepared some information on the application for amendment of the standards which have been lodged under the new inquiry process.
In order to save time, I seek leave to have the document-which comprises two pages from the Tribunal-incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
APPLICATIONS AND REQUESTS FOR PROGRAM STANDARDS INQUIRIES
The following applications for inquiries to vary standards have been received since 23 May 1986, when the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (Inquiries) Regulations were Gazetted.

1. Application from FACTS to vary Television Advertising Condition 11 to allow advertising time lost as the result of a commercial-free broadcast of the wedding of Prince Andrew and Miss Sarah Ferguson to be made up by increased advertising during the same time zone on other evenings in the following week.
2. Application from WA Health Department to suspend the limitation on foreign content for advertisements relating to health and safety issues which do not promote any particular product.

3. Application from Austrama Television Pty Ltd on behalf of Network Ten to vary the Pre-school Children's Television Program Standards to allow the displacement of pre-school programming on Melbourne Cup Day by an all-day Cup coverage.

4. Application from TVW Enterprises Ltd to vary the Pre-school Children's Television Program Standards to allow the displacement of pre-school programming on a number of days over the summer period by various tennis tournaments.

5. Applications to vary TAC 11 to allow displacement of advertising to allow the broadcast of a program ``The Prince and Princess of Wales ... In Person'' with limited advertising breaks and the advertising time lost as a result to be made up by increased advertising during other programs. Two applications have been received: TVW Enterprises Ltd has requested an ad hoc variation; the Seven Network has requested a general variation to the standards to provide for displacement of advertising to allow the transmission of programs with advertising restrictions attached to them. In both cases the applicant had already contracted for the program with limitations on advertising breaks included in the contract.
6. Application from FACTS to repeal Television Advertising Conditions 13 and 14 (two of 16 standards establishing advertising conditions for television).
In addition to the above, letters have been received which were not accepted as applications as the standards in question had been subject to a recent inquiry and no new information was provided:
1. Request by TVW Enterprises Ltd to allow alcohol advertising outside AO time on Melbourne Cup Day.

2. Request by Australian Parents for Drug Free Youth to amend Television Program Standard 21 (advertising of alcoholic drinks) to prevent personalities with appeal to young people under the age of 18 years from being involved in alcohol advertising on television.
The following points should be noted about these applications and requests:
(a) Of nine received, only two were from ``the pu-blic''; all others are from licensees or their representatives;
(b) Five of the nine are for ad hoc variations to standards to facilitate the broadcasting of parti-cular programs in the manner preferred by licensees;
(c) One is to repeal two particular standards which are part of an inter-related package of standards regulating advertising;

(d) One is to vary a standard to facilitate one particular advertisement which could have been made so as to comply with the foreign content standard, or could have been broadcast as a community service announcement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Most of the applications until now have been from broadcasters. But the Tribunal expects the general public gradually to catch on and use the process.
