The letter goes on to point out in general terms that the Tribunal is adversely affected by this particular regulation. I make that point to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot afford to wait for the Department to patch up problems which become apparent to it in six months time or so. We need action right now to get the broadcasting system back into kilter. The disallowance of regulations 2, 7 and 9 would, I believe, be a useful start. The transfer of responsibility from the Department to the Tribunal of these powers, which is the effect of the disallowance, would allow problems to be dealt with speedily and effectively and be part of a deregulatory process. I recommend that all people in this place who are in favour of deregulation should support this motion for disallowance which, I believe, moves in the right direction to get a properly managed broadcasting system and an effectively operating Broadcasting Tribunal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support Senator Vigor's motion for disallowance of part of these regulations. I submit that, in regard to many of the things which Senator Vigor said, he has presented a picture of the operations of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which is not in accordance with fact and has indicated the potential effect of these regulations according to certain claims which he has made which, again, I believe are not in accordance with the facts. One thing which Senator Vigor has pointed out is the lack of power in the Senate to deal with parts of a regulation and to delete only parts of a regulation. The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which was presented only yesterday-the eightieth report, dealing with application of the Committee's principles, report of the Acts Interpretation Act, and legislation considered in 1985-86-makes this point very clearly in paragraphs 2.18 and 2.19. The purport of that is that, in order to disallow part of a regulation which the Senate might find objectionable, a whole regulation must be disallowed. For that purpose, Senator Vigor has sought the disallowance of the whole of regulation 2 because he objects to the definition of prescribed particulars.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of removing the whole of regulation 2 will be to deny any part of the interpretation clause of these regulations. Therefore, the Tribunal would be expected to operate under a regime in which it does not have any guidance by way of regulation or, indeed, in the Act itself, as to what the interpretation of the regulation is to mean. Questions such as party, proceeding, public documents, substantive power, approved form, inquiry and inquiry documents would stand without definition because of the removal of regulation 2. It was for that very reason that Senator Vigor, who was originally agitated about the application of regulation 4, did not proceed to include it. He realised that, by disallowing the whole of regulation 4 when his only objection was to regulation 4 (1) (b), he would have brought about a situation in which the work of the Tribunal would have become impossible. By disallowing regulation 2 precisely the same effect is achieved.

Before I deal with each of the regulations which it is sought to disallow, I want to deal with the letter, which has now been incorporated in Hansard, from the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, Miss Deirdre O'Connor, addressed in reply to Senator Vigor, on this matter. I think it to be quite improper for the Chairman of the Tribunal to have addressed such a letter to Senator Vigor. I think it to be quite improper for the holder of a statutory position to write or respond to somebody who is not the Minister to whom he is responsible drawing attention to matters to which he has objection and which ought properly to be determined as matters of public policy subject to the scrutiny and review of the Parliament. I do not believe that it is proper for an office holder, such as the Chairman of the Broadcasting Tribunal, to be seeking the assistance of senators, or anybody else for that matter, to have disallowed a series of regulations which the Tribunal finds to be objectionable when the central issue is whether the Government, as a matter of public policy, with the review and oversight of the Parliament attached to that, regards the regulations as being the correct way to proceed.

What sort of situation will we have if every one of the statutory authorities starts writing to the Parliament saying: `We do not like what the Government is doing about this. We therefore encourage you to disallow regulations. We therefore encourage you to put up a view purporting to be a Tribunal view which is at variance with the Government view'? I think that is absolutely disgraceful on the part of the Broadcasting Tribunal and it is absolutely improper. It even goes to the extent, for instance, that there is an error of fact in the letter. The letter states in part:

In some inquiries, especially inquiries into program standards, it could be that the numerical strength of a particular opinion might affect the weight given to a particular opinion (although we have to be careful about relying on mere volume), but names and addresses of any but the submitter are never likely to be of interest to the Tribunal, and their inclusion in the material to be supplied in an inquiry gives the erroneous impression that the Tribunal regards them as significant.

Neither the existing regulations nor the regulations which are before us require names and addresses to be given. Regulation 2 under the heading `Prescribed particulars' states that the following information must be provided in relation to unincorporated associations:
. . . the name of each member of the association or, where there are more than 20 members of the association, the name of each officer of the association.

The regulation does not require addresses and for the Tribunal, in its letter, to imply that addresses are either currently required or will be required in the future is simply a misleading statement. The other point that needs to be made is that the Tribunal had plenty of opportunities, as Senator Vigor well knows, to make its views known to the Government in the process of consultation which took place prior to the drawing up of these regulations. In the briefing which Senator Vigor was given by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) it was indicated:

The regulations were the subject of very extensive consultation with industry groups (the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations-FACTS, the Federation of Australian Broadcasting Stations-FARB; the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia-PBAA; public interest bodies (Media and Communications Council) and the ABT.

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has had its crack at these regulations; it has had its opportunity to tell the Government what it thought of these proposed regulations; it has been given every opportunity; and the Government has now come to a decision, which it presents to the Parliament by way of regulations. The Tribunal, having had one crack at the thing, now decides to use the forms of the Parliament by way of a letter addressed by the Chairman to Senator Vigor to once again try to win a battle which has already been settled. I do not believe that that is the correct way for statutory authorities to proceed.

I am not one who is known in this place as a defender through thick and thin of the Department of Communications, but for Senator Vigor to make the implication that the Department was the one that was at fault over the extraordinary saga of the Perth television inquiry is absolutely unfounded. The problem as far as the Perth inquiry was concerned was the intervention of any number of grossly overpaid members of the legal profession. If there is any fault-and I note that I have stirred Senator Chaney into some degree of agitation-it lies in an Act which provides for a great deal of legal representation and for a situation of constantly going backwards and forwards with appeals to the Federal Court, the full Federal Court and the High Court of Australia. I think in the Perth inquiry the Minister was enjoined at some stage in something like 16 cases. The fault lies, therefore, in the structure of the Act; it does not lie with the Department of Communications, if in fact, the legal profession cuts a swathe through the processes which ought to be relatively uncluttered for the establishment of these licences.

I turn to each of the three regulations which Senator Vigor seeks to disallow. The first is the question of `prescribed particulars' in regulation 2 which was the subject of a very extensive investigation by the Administrative Review Council. The Council dealt with this matter in its report to the Attorney-General entitled `Australian Broadcasting Tribunal Procedures' which was presented in 1981. Paragraph 54 of the report states:

The Council has accepted suggestions by some people who made submissions to it that the procedure should make provision for particulars to be available of the composition of unincorporated associations participating in inquiries and of their objects of association.
Paragraph 55 states:
RECOMMENDATION 11
(a) The regulations should provide that where an application or submission is made on behalf of an unincorporated association, it should contain:
(i) either a list of the members of the association or, where the membership exceeds 20, a list of its officers and a description of its membership, and
(ii) A statement of the objects of the association.

So this very issue which Senator Vigor seeks to have disallowed has been the subject of investigation by the Administrative Review Council, a body which has established its reputation of a degree of sensitivity to civil liberties and to administrative law procedures. This regulation follows precisely the recommendation of that Council. Senator Vigor is apprised of this information because in the briefing which he was given by the Minister for Communications, the Minister said:

In order to assist in resolving this issue the Department sought advice from the Attorney-General's Department and received advice that where the information sought related to a function or activity of the ABT, it would not be contrary to `Information Privacy Principles' which have been developed to regulate the collection storage and access to personal information.

So it has been tested by the Administrative Review Council and recommended. It has been tested by the Attorney-General's Department against its information privacy principles and been found to be perfectly sound. Both of those facts were known to Senator Vigor; both of them ought to have been more directly addressed in terms of dealing with this matter. I do not see that the principles of natural justice require anything else when one is faced with a series of accusers saying that certain things should be done, certain standards should be introduced and certain licence conditions or standards should be varied, than one being entitled to know who it is who is making that claim. For instance, it is perfectly legitimate to know whether in fact an application for the change of a licence condition has been generated by a public interest group or perhaps by four sacked employees. Indeed, if there is an assault upon the standards laid down for the advertising of tobacco products from a group calling itself Citizens for Free Speech, it is perfectly legitimate to find out whether it is a fact that it is a group of five people, all of whom are senior executives of tobacco companies. It seems to me perfectly fair and reasonable that that information should be public information. In terms of the advice of the Administrative Review Council and the Attorney-General's Department and the principles of natural justice which are at stake here, the Opposition does not support that disallowance.

We come then to the question of the alleged subsidy to the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters and the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia which is indicated in sub-section 5 of regulation 7 in regard to the provision of information and the provision of copies of documents. One has to look at this matter in relation to sub-section 3 (b) which gives the Tribunal the power or, indeed, the requirement to ensure that organisations receive a copy of each relevant submission lodged with the Tribunal in relation to an inquiry. What the Tribunal, of course, could do under these circumstances is order the person making the submission to provide a copy of the submission to all of the affected parties. Indeed, Miss O'Connor's letter to Senator Vigor says in part:
In some cases, it is appropriate for us to deal with this requirement by directing submitters to serve copies of their submissions on the applicant or affected licencees . . . .
The Tribunal says that in some circumstances that may not be a fair way to go. It also says:

For example, if the ordinary citizen lodges a written submission in response to a Tribunal notice, it may be very difficult and often unfair to require that citizen to serve additional copies on one or more affected licencees.

So this is the position: The Tribunal is required to ensure that the affected parties get copies of the documents. It can do one of two things. It either requires the submitters to provide them or it provides them itself. I cannot see in this instance that the transfer of the financial burden from the submitter to the Commonwealth is unjustified. If Senator Vigor is saying that he would prefer to have a situation in which individuals making submissions to the Tribunal are in fact required to pay the cost of ensuring that everybody who is affected by the submissions gets a copy of the submission, I think he will find that the enthusiasm with which some of the public interest groups may have embraced him on this occasion will turn out to be extremely short lived. The Opposition does not believe that the prescribed organisation sub-clause of that regulation in fact serves anything other than a very useful public purpose.

I come lastly to the attempt to remove regulation 9, which is the public notice of inquiry regulation. Here again, I believe that the Senate has not been put in possession of all the facts by Senator Vigor. His claim is fundamentally that it will always take a minimum of 10 weeks for these inquiries to be completed. If, however, he reads regulation 9 in conjunction with regulation 8, which is headed `Disposal of certain matters', he will find that the number of short cut procedures available to the Tribunal dealt with in regulation 8 allow for a substantial shortening of the time involved. Indeed, the new procedures place much greater emphasis on documentation rather than, as has existed in the past, an emphasis on time consuming oral hearings and cross examination. So the claim made about regulation 9 does not stand up when one reads it against the discretions given to the Tribunal in regulation 8 to provide for a short circuiting of the procedures.

I think that that adequately deals with the matters which have been raised. I repeat: Regulation 2 seems to us to be perfectly fair in terms of protection of privacy and natural justice principles; regulation 7 seems to us to be perfectly fair as far as providing written material to prescribed organisations is concerned; and regulation 9 is perfectly fair when one reads it in conjunction with regulation 8. I conclude, therefore, only by drawing attention once again to what I believe to be the very undesirable precedent established by the Chairman of the Broadcasting Tribunal, in addressing to Senator Vigor a letter seeking to overturn regulations which the Tribunal had an opportunity to participate in developing, and which are properly matters to be determined by the Government and by the Parliament. If we let this sort of procedure get out of hand, the lack of control which is already evident over statutory authorities will become even more manifest, and I believe that to be most undesirable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some things in what Senator Vigor said which I think ought to be agreed with, and a lot in what Senator Puplick had to say, although there were some things which Senator Puplick went to which should be rebutted, such as his fairly savage attack upon the legal profession, which is something he can never refrain from entering upon. His ability as a speaker, which we in this chamber have all heard of, and his ability to grapple with legal concepts, should lead him to take up the practice of law and to serve the public, as many people in that profession do, very nobly.

SPEECH.PARA: Be that as it may, the point we have to agree on as far as Senator Vigor goes is that it is an unnecessary fetter upon the power of the Senate not to be able to disallow part of a regulation. I think that the rule of the Acts Interpretation Act which says that the Senate must disallow the whole of a regulation and not part of it is a very poor rule and it ought to be changed as a matter of priority. It is in the hands of this Parliament to change it.

Having said that, I now come to the substance of Senator Vigor's argument. With respect to him, I think there may be a misconception as to what these regulations are all about. I do not think that we can look at the matter, as he has done, simply from the point of view of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Perhaps the best way of entering into that concept is to read what is in the explanatory statement. When regulations are passed explanatory statements are set out explaining what the regulations go to. In the second paragraph of that statement this appears:

The Broadcasting Act 1942 provides for commercial and public broadcasting services and establishes the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as an independent body with licensing and supervisory powers in relation to those services.
The Act sets up the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as an independent body with certain powers. The explanatory statement goes on:
Section 17a of the Act lists the most significant powers of the Tribunal which are classed as substantive powers.

These reflect a broad range of powers including, for example, a power to grant licences. If we think about that for a minute, we will understand how significant that power is. In other words, this Tribunal can grant to bodies the ability to make a lot of money and to broadcast to many people throughout the nation the sorts of things that they feel appropriate. It is a very significant power that the Tribunal holds. Another power is the power to determine standards for programs. In other words, it has the power of censorship in a sense, which is a very broad and significant power. It also has the power to approve transactions relating to the ownership or control of licences. On reading that again, we realise the very wide and extensive powers that the Tribunal has. It has the power to reprimand licensees. In other words, it can impose sanctions upon them, and it can issue directions to licensees. Anyone wanting to enter into the field of public or commercial broadcasting must realise the significance that the Tribunal has.

Properly, the Parliament has set up a procedure whereby those affected, or likely to be affected, by what the Tribunal can do, can go before the Tribunal and put their case. That is a very fair way of doing things. In other words, if somebody is going to determine our rights, our privileges, what we can or cannot do, is it not only fair that we go before that body and have our say, in terms of either written or oral submissions or both? Indeed, there is provision to do just that before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The next question is how we go before it. Will the Tribunal's members literally sit in the shade under the banyan tree and dispense licences or reprimands without any sort of regulation or rules as to the way they should go about it? Of course not. These regulations set up the procedures whereby the Tribunal is to operate. It is at that level that objection has been made to it. From what I can gather the main objection is that if there are 20 or fewer people going before the Tribunal, either to make or to resist an application or to apply for something, they have to provide their names. What is so extraordinary in the requirement of people having to provide their names? That is what the regulation simply says:
. . . `prescribed particulars' in relation to an unincorporated association means particulars of the objects of the association-
that is proper and, as I understand it, there is no objection taken to that requirement-
and the names of each member of the association, or where there are more than 20 members of the association, the name of each officer of the association.

If people have such an approach to things and they want to go before the Tribunal, why should they not tell it their names? That is all it requires. Would honourable senators object if five people were making an application and were told to give their names? I suggest that that is a very ordinary requirement. I suggest that in any legal proceeding the person against whom one is battling ought to identify herself or himself. Simply to say that the whole legal process-that is what the inference is-should be able to proceed behind some sort of name such as the Honest John Broadcasting Group, the Trustworthy Media Men or the Sunshine Girls, and to conduct proceedings on that basis, seems to me to be quite bizarre. We would then get back to the John Doe and Richard Roe situation, and the Smith and Jones situation, and the Tribunal sits there and says: `We are not terribly interested in who you are. Simply say what you want, as you will. Send a record along, don't even come yourself'.

Senator Puplick has said that a letter from the Chairman of the Tribunal to Senator Vigor of 13 October 1986 contains some perhaps unfortunate statements because, amongst other things, this was quoted by Senator Vigor:
We-
that is the Tribunal-
regard the information required under regulations 4 (2) and 10 (2) as irrelevant to the inquiry process.

In other words, the Tribunal is saying that it does not matter who comes before it or what the character is of the person applying for a particular licence or what the character of a person is who is interested in something going on before the Tribunal. It says that the character and the history of the person is irrelevant. It also says that the sorts of financing that might be behind that person are irrelevant. For a tribunal to write a letter divorcing its ability to look at the character, the background, the finances and the history of a person who makes the application and to regard all those as being irrelevant, it seems to me is to restrict itself too much in its considerations. I would have thought that it would subject itself with respect to an application by way of prerogative writs and all sorts of other things. Perhaps, to be fair to the writer of the letter, that is not quite what is meant, because it goes on to say this:
Section 22aa of the Broadcasting Act 1942 makes it clear that any person lodging an application or a relevant submission is a party to proceedings at an ordinary inquiry.

It says that that is relevant. What may be meant by that is that in the old days the person making the application had to show some proprietary interest in the proceedings to get a hearing; whereas now that does not matter so much. Indeed that is probably what is meant by this letter. But certainly by the way in which it is expressed it would mean otherwise. It is unfortunate that the head of the Tribunal which has to hear evidence should write a letter apparently criticising the Tribunal's ability to look at evidence, which I would have thought was very relevant to many of its considerations.

I go to the next objection, which is the objection to regulation 7 which in effect requires that the Tribunal give notice of the material it has before it to all interested parties. I would have thought that that was a very fair regulation and very properly in the rules that govern this area. If a person has to come before a tribunal, make submissions and, in the end, accept its decision, surely he should know the material of those who are putting a proposition adverse to his. Surely, any hearing ought to be conducted on the basis that there are no traps, that there is no ambush, and that the evidence that one party has is well and truly available to the other; so not only does the tribunal know what the evidence is but also both parties know what it is so that a proper conclusion can be reached. All regulation 7 does is to make sure that all those who come before the Tribunal are well apprised of what is going on.

It is said: `Why should the Tribunal have to provide those documents? Why should the Tribunal have to photostat, or have photostated, documents and send them to the applicants?'. It does that so that the matters before the Tribunal can be better dealt with. The Tribunal can then be assured that all the relevant information has been provided to all interested parties; so no party can come along and say `I did not get that document', or `Had I known that it was part of a submission I would have acted differently. I ask for an adjournment'. So time and tide are wasted. The provision of material to the various parties obviates those problems.
Finally, there is the objection to regulation 9 because it is said that it is time wasting. Let us look at regulation 9 (2), which states:
A notice, under sub-regulation (1) at the commencement of an inquiry shall be published-

(a) where the inquiry relates to the grant of a licence (other than supplementary licence) otherwise than by way of renewal-within 28 days after the specified date referred to in sub-paragraph 82 (1) (b) (i) of the Act . . .
and-
(b) in any other case-as soon as practicable but within 28 days after the commencement of the inquiry.

It goes on to specify other time limits. It sets out time limits so that those who may be affected by applications before the Tribunal are given notice. I ask Senator Vigor to look at this whole matter in the context of interested parties to an application who are, first of all, notified in time and given enough time to prepare their case and, secondly, given the material that is necessary for them to prepare a defence or an answer to the Tribunal, whichever is the relevant position.

If we look at all these regulations as a whole we see that they are very much akin to regulations that guide courts in their actions. They are very close to the orders that the courts rely on to conduct their affairs in a proper, practical and effective way, doing justice to both parties. If we took away any of these regulations which are objected to we would find, in effect, that people who are entitled to know how things are going, what the state of play is before the Tribunal and how they should go about preparing their cases, would be denied that opportunity. I think they are sensible regulations.

Senator Puplick has touched upon the fact that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal itself has had an opportunity to put a submission before those who would decide how these regulations would be made. The regulations were subject to very extensive consultation with industry groups and with the Tribunal itself. We have the results before the Senate today.

If the regulations were disallowed, what regulations would provide a proper guide to the Tribunal, so that not only is the Tribunal given a chance to exercise its functions but also those who come before it are given a chance to put proper submissions? In putting proper submissions they are entitled, as anybody is, to engage the services of a lawyer. Some calumny has been heaped upon the heads of lawyers. The law is an old profession of mine. Lawyers have served the public very well not only at law but also in this very chamber which they have graced over the years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And favoured.

—And favoured. I say without any facetiousness at all that people who are well versed in preparing applications to go before bodies such as the Tribunal can have their applications dealt with expeditiously and in a way that justice is done to all parties, and in many cases at a reasonable cost. I must concede that there are times when my colleagues perhaps charge a little more than should be expected, but by and large the judicial system and the process set up in this community whereby rights are adjusted among the citizens are well served by the legal profession.
—Are you willing to declare your interest?

—I have declared my interest. There is no doubt about that. Nevertheless, I will not sit down without at least putting in some defence of the defenceless lawyers who have been maligned here today, not only by Senator Vigor-who, having listened to me, will no doubt change his attitude-but also by Senator Puplick who should not have done that. Having made a brilliant speech in all other respects, he failed to pay tribute where it was due. I hope that Senator Vigor, having listened to Senator Puplick and me and now that this matter has been put in its proper setting, will see that this motion should not be passed and no doubt will not be passed by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I must raise a few points that have been raised during the debate, particularly those made by Senator Puplick with his characteristic eloquence. He tried to paint a picture of corruption and malpractice in the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I wish to put that matter straight immediately. I wrote to the Tribunal on 2 September 1986 to get clarification concerning the Tribunal's attitude. I informed the office of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard that letter asking the Tribunal for its opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
2 September 1986
Ms. Deirdre O'Connor, Chairman,
Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.
Dear Ms O'Connor,
I wish to bring to the Tribunal's attention my motion to disallow the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (Inquiries) Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1986 No. 100.
There are some significant civil liberties matters involved about which I have already contacted the Minister for Communications.

I also understand that a significant additional administrative burden is already being imposed on the Tribunal as a result of these new procedures, and that scarce valuable staff resources are being tied up because there is no flexibility allowed in the response to requests for exercise of the Tribunal's powers.
I would be grateful for any information the Tribunal can supply about the operation of these Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (Inquiries) Regulations to date, and any problems encountered.
Yours sincerely,
David Vigor

TALK.START.PARA: —I also point out that after replying to me, both verbally and in a letter, the Chairman of the Tribunal, in fact, sent a copy of her letter to Mr Duffy. I did not incorporate the whole letter previously, but considering that it has been the subject of considerable discussion I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard. During my first speech I incorporated only the appendices.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
CHAIRMAN
13 October 1986
Senator David Vigor
Senator for South Australia
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Vigor
Thank you for your letter of 2 September 1986 bringing to our attention your motion to disallow the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (Inquiries) Regulations.

I note that you refer to ``significant civil liberties matters'' involved in the Regulations. I assume that you are referring to regulations 4 (2) and 10 (2), which require unincorporated associations to provide a list of members or (in the case of larger organisations) office-bearers with any application or submission to the Tribunal. We regard the information required under regulations 4 (2) and 10 (2) as irrelevant to the inquiry process. Section 22aa of the Broadcasting Act 1942 makes it clear that any person lodging an application or a relevant submission is a party to proceedings at an ordinary inquiry. It does not really matter who that person is. The essential issue is whether what is being said is relevant to the inquiry. In some inquiries, especially inquiries into program standards, it could be that the numerical strength of a particular opinion might affect the weight given to a particular opinion (although we have to be careful about relying on mere volume), but names and addresses of anyone but the submitter are never likely to be of interest to the Tribunal, and their inclusion in the material to be supplied in an inquiry gives the erroneous impression that the Tribunal regards them as significant.

On the question of additional administrative burdens, I do not think that the Tribunal has yet had sufficient experience of the new process to reach final overall conclusions about the relevant burdens imposed by the old process and the new process. However, I can identify one area where the Tribunal has experienced a significant problem already, and another where problems could arise in the future.

The significant problem already manifest is that the Tribunal must deal with any application for an amendment of the program standards through the inquiry process laid down in the regulations. There are two difficulties with this. The first is that there are already signs that the Tribunal will receive a large number of applications designed to facilitate the showing of one particular program, or to ``pick off'' particular aspects of the Tribunal's standards. The Tribunal has prepared some information on the applications for amendment of the standards which have been lodged under the new inquiry process: ATTACHMENT A. Note that the bulk of applications so far have been from broadcasters. Once the availability of the new inquiry process becomes widely known to the public, the number of applications can be expected to increase.

Sections 17b and 17c of the Act require the Tribunal to hold an inquiry where a valid application is received. This makes it extremely hard for the Tribunal to keep control of its agenda for revision of the program standards, even though we are making use of our powers to join and defer inquiries. We are also now finding that the mere processing of the applications is a considerable additional burden on the Tribunal's resources for very little valuable outcome.

The second difficulty is that the inquiry process in the regulations was really developed for quasi-judicial licensing functions, and is generally not suited to an inquiry into the determination of particular program standards, which is a legislative kind of function. To go through an inquiry process, with parties, hearings (possibly with rights of cross-examination etc), at the behest of a special interest group (whoever it may be) is often an inappropriate way to proceed in the revision of program standards. It could positively inhibit public debate on issues where it is most important. Yet under the current law, we have no discretion to proceed in any other way unless the matter is urgent (see s. 17c (7) of the Act) or relatively trivial (see regulation 8).

Note that the ability to abridge an inquiry where an issue is trivial applies only to applications lodged with the Tribunal. If the Tribunal itself wishes to amend a standard, even if only to change a single word, it must open an inquiry file, draft issues for the inquiry, prepare a notice in accordance with regulation 9, publish the notice in accordance with regulation 18, allow 6 weeks for submissions, and then consider the responses (if any) and prepare a report. We have found already that an inquiry initiated by the Tribunal takes an absolute minimum of 10 weeks from start to finish, so that even non-controversial changes cannot be implemented quickly.

The other issue that could be of concern to us in the future is the requirement in regulation 7 that the Tribunal should, so far as practicable, ensure that each affected licensee receives a copy of each submission lodged in an inquiry. A similar requirement applies to any person who has lodged an application for the exercise of a substantive power. In some cases, it is appropriate for us to deal with this requirement by directing submitters to serve copies of their submissions on the applicant or affected licensees (or the relevant industry association), but in many other cases it will simply not be fair or practicable to make and enforce such a direction. For example, if an ordinary citizen lodges a written submission in response to a Tribunal notice, it may be very difficult and often unfair to require that citizen to serve additional copies on one or more affected licensees. It may be equally unreasonable to reject the submission if the submitter objects to supplying additional copies. The result under regulation 7 could be that the Tribunal is obliged to become an unpaid photocopier of documents for affected licensees. This is all very well as a voluntary practice adopted from time to time according to the circumstances, but the new regulations would make it mandatory.
Yours sincerely
DEIRDRE O'CONNOR
cc: The Hon. M. J. Duffy MP
Minister for Communications

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I come to the substantive matters of this debate. Firstly, let us consider regulation 2. If the definitions were left to the Tribunal we would have a freer and more reasonable requirement for making submissions before the Tribunal. I support the disallowance of regulation 2. However, I will comment a little further about some matters associated with my attacks on the Department. I wish to bring to Senator Puplick's attention the fact that the Perth hearings were extended by over 40 days because the Department failed to specify the technical conditions associated with the licence, which left an enormous loophole which the Tribunal was unable to handle under its powers. That is a major reason why there were such extended hearings in Perth which cost both the commercial applicants and the public purse a lot of money. If that matter had been tightened up and properly thought through those 40 days, or at least a large proportion of them, could have been saved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal has the ability to initiate inquiries under the Broadcasting Act. Regulation 8 allows it not to open an inquiry in response to a request if it feels the matter is of little importance. Senator Puplick implies that this gives it the freedom necessary to expedite inquiries. That is not the case. Regulation 8 deals only with situations where the Tribunal has not initiated an inquiry. The Tribunal has no way, once an inquiry has been called on its own motion, of expediting it. I bring to the notice of the Senate the part of the letter from the Chairman of the Tribunal, which has been incorporated in Hansard. It says:
We have found already that an inquiry initiated by the Tribunal takes an absolute minimum of 10 weeks from start to finish, so that even non-controversial changes cannot be implemented quickly.

Regulation 8 does not help the Tribunal at all in these cases. These regulations will have to be revised. It is a great disappointment that both the Government and the Opposition will not support our motion for disallowance. I hope that we can find a better way of doing things. The Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are pushing for the ability to be able to change one or two words and to make sensible amendments to regulations so that we will not have this type of process in the Senate. It would certainly help us to be better legislators if we had more fine tuning on disallowing parts of regulations. I commend this matter to the Senate for expeditious action. I hope that the Government will take notice and introduce soon legislation to bring into effect an ability for the Senate to be able to change all regulations, down to the level of a single word. I commend to the Senate the disallowance of regulations 2, 7 and 9 of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (Inquiries) Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1986 No. 100.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Sanders had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert:
``this Bill be referred to the Select Committee on Animal Welfare for report by the first day of sitting in 1987, and that the Committee give particular attention to whether-

(a) the Bill would weaken the supervision of animal exports, such as by the delegation of powers by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, resulting in decisions to export being made by persons who are neither qualified nor informed to assess properly whether an export is in the best interests of the animal or human communities;
(b) the removal of the requirement for applications for permits to be gazetted would undermine basic democratic principles by denying the public any meaningful participation in permit decisions;

(c) at a time when our native fauna and flora is under ever-increasing threat, strong legislative steps should be taken to close loopholes in existing laws, rather than creating even greater opportunities for those who wish to over-exploit our native species; and
(d) there ought to be stronger supervision of the export of animals covered by the Convention on Trade in Endangered Species''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the adjournment of the debate yesterday I was saying that Australia is dealing with a multi-million dollar smuggling business. There is considerable evidence to link the wildlife smuggling trade with drugs. It is a serious problem, one to which too little attention has been paid to date. Only five cases of wildlife smuggling have been brought to court since the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act came into force in 1984. That indicates both the difficulty of the problem and the attitude to wildlife smuggling. The prevention of wildlife smuggling is not regarded as a major priority by Customs nor by the authorities that have anything to do with it. Whether that is because of a lack of resources, lack of interest or lack of direction I do not know.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government should direct more attention to this problem. The Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, of which I am a member, has heard considerable evidence from Customs officers. They have expressed concern at the situation, at the lack of resources and the obvious links between wildlife smuggling and other illegal imports and exports. Australia's geographical position and the size of our country make thorough surveillance difficult but the same problems exist for those involved in drug detection. That problem should not prevent more effort being expended. It is to be hoped that the Federal Government will look at this matter and take it much more seriously than it has in the past. I am persuaded by the argument that if controls were lifted on the export of several varieties of our birds, particularly the galah and the cockatoo, to which I referred yesterday, that may help to reduce the illegal trafficking. People in the bird industry have some concerns about liberalising exports. They are concerned basically because of the need for specialised supervision by appropriate authorities. There are administrative and other restrictive difficulties. These would definitely need to be addressed.

However, in a period in which we are trying to encourage more exports-exports are probably paramount in everyone's mind at the moment-this is an opportunity that should not be overlooked. Returns would come not just from sales but also from ancillary industries, such as transport services. Additionally, Australia would be viewed more favourably by pet lovers around the world who cannot understand why they are forbidden to buy galahs and cockatoos when they know that in Australia those birds are often regarded as pests and disposed of accordingly. An example of a ridiculous situation is that the Taiwan Zoo, which is keen to obtain some Australian kangaroos for its collection, is buying them from the United States of America. I accept that the controlled legitimate export of wildlife would require extensive supervision with specialist knowledge and perhaps would be a costly administrative exercise. At a time when the Government wants to keep spending to a minimum and economic restraint to the forefront it may be a bit of a problem but I believe that the concept is worthwhile.

Clauses in this legislation which strengthen penalties for those caught smuggling are important. However, they are not tough enough. After all, when the potential booty is worth, perhaps, hundreds of thousands of dollars or more, a $5,000 fine is probably most inappropriate. I welcome also the increased protection for people who provide information to Customs authorities on smuggling operations. We are all aware of the penalties dished out to informants in the drug trade. Concrete boots are reasonably common. With the financial rewards for wildlife smuggling, it is only reasonable to assume that similar retribution would occur against informants on wildlife smuggling.

One final aspect which I feel should be emphasised is the liberalising of the export of pets from Australia. In many pet purchases, very often no descriptive receipts are issued. For example, in the case of budgerigars, a bird is a bird is a bird. Only an expert would be able to distinguish one breed of budgie from another. However, some budgerigars cannot be exported at present. I hope that the new relaxation of laws regarding pet exports does not open up a new, lucrative trade in illegal exports.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, Australia is very rich in flora and fauna. I hope that all Australians realise the value of their heritage and what wonderful natural resources we have in such things as our birds, animals and flowers. Therefore, it is important that we as individuals and as a government take seriously the threat imposed by illegal exports of our wildlife and support legislation that will help to control the legitimate movement of birds and animals, while providing penalties for those who attempt to export them illegally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sympathetic to the intention of the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats to the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1986. The amendment endeavours to bring the legislation, which is being amended by the Government, under the scrutiny of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare so that detailed examination can be given to it, having in mind the problems that have been revealed to the Committee in evidence before it. Although I am sympathetic to the intention of the amendment, I do not believe that it will be supported. I am beginning to believe that the amendment does not need to be supported because the Animal Welfare Committee will carefully scrutinise the Government's amendments. In fact, the Committee has the legislation under scrutiny. It is fairly evident that the legislation as it now stands and, for that matter, as it is being amended, does nothing substantial to correct the serious problems which our wildlife species face. That is the basis of a report we expect to bring down.

SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned about the legislation because of revelations which have been made that the Australian Customs Service plays only a very small role at the Customs barrier in the protection of species which are being exported, sometimes live but mostly as products derived from the exploitation of wildlife species. Other evidence seems to indicate-I direct this remark to Senator Puplick-that legal trade in wildlife species, and the products derived from wildlife species, is often a mask and a cover for substantial illegal trade. That is why I recommend some caution to those who are suggesting that we solve our problems, especially the problems which the rural sector faces, for example, the problem of the damage done to crops by flocks of birds, by legalising their export. I suggest that the solution is not to legalise their export, but to seek other means to solve the problems farmers face and the problems that the birds themselves face as a result of the competition between commercial production and the need for the birds to live freely in their environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got any ideas?

—To a certain extent we are pre-empting the investigation by the Committee. The Committee will bring down certain recommendations. We have some ideas. Those ideas are tempered by harsh reality. Sympathetic people-most people are sympathetic-would say: `Let us give the greatest possible advantage to our wildlife species. Let our wildlife species and their environment be protected'. That is a very, shall we say, sympathetic option to take but in reality it is not easily achieved. The Committee is considering it, which is why, possibly, we are taking longer with the inquiry than we would like to take. The solution is not to make legal something which is illegal at present.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said previously, legal trade can be a cover for considerable illegal trade. I do not want to go back to the days of the great debate on applied ecology and the turtle farm project. In order to sell the products of a device designed to produce turtles in a domestic environment, all that was stimulated in the community was a desire to gather and display turtle products. The end result would have been to stimulate the harvesting of turtles from the wild. There are all sorts of problems. The Committee is investigating them. It will investigate the legislation. I agree with Senator Sanders that the Government's amendments do little to improve the controls that are supposedly in place. There has to be some in depth consideration of the problem which probably will lead to a complete overhaul, not only of the legislation, but also of our approach.

The concerns which Senator Brownhill has expressed are quite real. His solutions, however, will probably not meet that real concern. I suggest that the Democrats' amendment, although well-intentioned, is not necessarily the best way to deal with the matter. Although the Senate Select Committee is not likely to receive the reference-I know what the numbers are as well as Senator Sanders; nevertheless he has brought the matter forward for debate by moving an amendment-the Committee will be considering the amendments and the whole legislation. No doubt it will bring down some recommendations to the Senate in its report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1986 is a Bill amending legislation which was originally countenanced in the days of the previous Fraser- Anthony Government, and very necessary legislation it was too. It really brings together and helps us to meet our obligations for the protection and conservation of the world's wildlife under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. I indicate at the outset that the Opposition will not be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Sanders. Three members of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare have taken part in this debate, and that is good, as well as one other speaker, Senator Puplick, from my side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: We will not be supporting the amendment for the reasons basically outlined by Senator Georges. I think that the Senate Select Committee, in its hearings and in the work it has before it, will pick up most of what is envisaged in the amendment moved by Senator Sanders. Indeed, I would be very disappointed if the Committee did not do that. We will not be supporting the amendment. I would not want to see this Bill held up unnecessarily because, as has been indicated by previous speakers, it does tighten up in some areas and strengthen the ability of officials to detect and to prosecute those wildlife traffickers, who we abhor, who make money out of our indigenous wildlife. Anything that can be done to stop that trafficking and to bring those people to justice has to be commended. This Bill does tighten that up, so we would not want to hold it up. That, besides the reason that I think that the Committee has all the power to do the things that Senator Sanders had indicated he wants done, means that we will not be supporting the amendment. We are not against the intent of the amendment; I just think the matter can be handled if things take their course.

The previous speakers outlined the Bill, the various aspects of it and the necessity for it, so I will not detain the Senate too long. But I do want to pick up a few points on the way through. First of all, one of the amendments allows the export of invertebrates. There is a program going on now instigated by the James Cook University at Townsville on the export of clams. This has been found necessary because the clams in the reefs of the South Pacific have been very severely depleted, possibly by the sort of plundering that has gone on on our Great Barrier Reef with overseas fishermen who come in and decimate the clam life on the reefs. One way of helping out our South Pacific neighbours is by breeding our giant clams. I understand that this is being done by the James Cook University on Orpheus Reef. Once the clams have been bred they cannot be exported to help these other nations build up their clam populations without this legislation going through. That is one of the very necessary amendments to this legislation.

The changing of the legislation for the pets of people departing this country has already been acknowledged and I have no objection to that. One other section allows the regular import and export of prescribed specimens, for example, by scientific institutions to develop biological control agents. They will not be required to make individual application for each shipment. They will receive a single authority, subject to the regular reporting of shipments. I think that is very necessary also. Currently the Alan Fletcher Research Station in Queensland does a lot of biological research into the control of weeds in Australia. One project which immediately comes to mind and which Professor Ovington is quite aware of is the biological control of mistflower, which is spreading particularly in south-east Queensland. The only other method of control is the use of herbicide, which is to be avoided if it possibly can. There is a biological control which looks as though it will be available. Unfortunately that has been held up, but I have had discussions with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and Professor Ovington is chasing that up.

I use that as an example because when one goes down this track, quite often one wants to get in through the year whatever samples one is wanting to test. Once permission has been given to do that, one has a blanket permission to bring in two or three lots instead of having to go back every time to get that permission, whether it be for a bug, a spore or whatever. It is another amendment which I welcome. Provision has also been made for the interchange of material between approved zoological organisations and scientific organisations. That also is to be welcomed. Indeed, Senator Puplick, in his contribution to this debate, mentioned a lot of the great work which has been done by zoos around the world and by individuals around the world and in Australia to build up the numbers of what were very seriously endangered species, to the extent that those species can be once again released in their natural habitats.

For those reasons, along with the reasons suggested by those who have taken part in the debate, we certainly will not be opposing the legislation. I will just pick up a couple of things that have been said, particularly by Senator Sanders. Once again he raised the usual argument about the woodchip industry and the toll on wildlife that happens in that industry. Nobody denies that, whatever happens, when man comes into an environment there is a toll. There would have to be a toll in the woodchip industry. There is a toll when one puts a roadway through an area. There is a toll when one puts a railway line through an area. I spent many years in western Queensland in unfenced country and knocked over the occasional emu or horse and plenty of kangaroos, sheep and cattle. There is a toll and there would have to be a toll in the woodchip industry. That is accepted. It is also accepted that when regrowth occurs, the wildlife comes back in very large numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the same species.

—And of the same species. For that reason, the woodchip industry very deliberately only take sections of trees out in coops so that the animals that are indigenous to that area can survive, and when the regrowth occurs, they breed up quite well.
—They didn't do that in the first place. That is the real problem.

—I am the first to admit that. There are many things that we did not do correctly in the first place. Mining is another one. We have all learnt as we have gone along. The rehabilitation of mining areas and the provision of coops to allow indigenous species to go to are things that we have learnt. We would not want it any other way now. If we had not taken notice of that we could rightfully stand condemned by everybody.
—You will acknowledge that we are still learning?

—Sure. We can learn something new every day. One of the other things that Senator Sanders mentioned was the Administrative Appeals Tribunal inquiry into the management program of kangaroos, particularly in Queensland. I think that the ANPWS stands condemned for its handling of this particular situation in that the inquiry, interestingly, was all about the 1985 management program but, for some reason best known to itself or because of some mistakes in its procedures, the documents that were brought before the AAT went to great pains to point out in paragraph 15 on page 14:

SPEECH.PARA: Three documents, each entitled Kangaroo Conservation and Management in Queensland, one dated March, 1975 (the 1975 document), one dated June, 1977 (the 1977 document) and one dated March 1984 (Exhibit 1), were put before the Tribunal at that earlier hearing. Each of those documents had been in existence at the date of publication of the gazettal declaration, and there was no indication as to which one was intended to be referred to in that declaration. It ultimately transpired that both the applicant and the respondent were proceeding on the assumption that what had been intended to be approved by the Minister was the document dated March, 1984, but which the quotas therein set out for the culling of several species of kangaroos replaced by different quotas which had been approved by the Minister on 14 February 1985 in respect of the year 1985.

So there is the Administrative Appeals Tribunal telling the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service that it had not got its act together properly. Indeed, the 1985 management program was a very different program from the 1984 program. Senator Sanders also quoted some figures which have been bandied around at other times. On page 1205 of the Senate Hansard of 10 October 1986 he is recorded as saying:
In 1985, 1,343,167 Queensland kangaroo skins entered the trade in New South Wales.

He went on to cite quite a few other very specific figures; but never have those figures been substantiated. The citing of unsubstantiated figures to indicate that something might be wrongfully going on does the conservation cause no good at all; it just calls its credibility into question. Once the carcass has been tagged, irrespective of in which State the kangaroo has been shot, the skin can enter the trade and go anywhere in Australia. It might go to Queensland to be tanned and then to New South Wales to be made into shoes or to Victoria to be made into handbags. I have even heard that kangaroo skin is used in South Australia to make whips. The figures given by Senator Sanders, and even the figures in the Sydney Morning Herald, which also have never been substantiated--

TALK.START.PARA: —The real problem is that nothing can be substantiated. That is how bad the system is; it is a real mess.

—It gets back to some of Senator Georges's remarks earlier. We have a program. The problem gets back to the tagging. That is where the substantiation can be done. Once the matter gets beyond the freezer boxes with the carcass and the tags, the product is very hard to control, as is any other product. If Senator Georges's Committee points up a problem-deficiencies, corruption or whatever-we will be able to address ourselves to the matter. But the problem comes back to a management program and tagging. If that is where the problem is and procedures need to be tightened up, let us do it. In Queensland, and in every other State, there are people who try to flout the system. Once found out they are prosecuted with the full weight of the law.
—That is not so.

—It is so. If the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare comes up with instances of people deliberately flouting the law and not being prosecuted, it is in the hands of the Committee members to bring that matter to this chamber and to the people of Australia. I know of people who have been prosecuted. As well as being fined, the carcasses in their possession were impounded. That is the only point at which effective control can be exercised. I repeat that if the Committee can point to methods of abuse and how they can be better controlled, all power to it. It has the opportunity to bring the matter to this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: At the current stage there is a conflict between the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, on the quota for Queensland. The quota requested by Queensland for the 1985 management program was in the vicinity of 1.86 million to 1.84 million. The quota agreed to by Minister Barry Cohen was 1.3 million. After that quota was agreed to, a scientific committee was set up to look into it. It has become known as the Sharman committee. Everybody agreed to the establishment and the personnel of the committee. Interestingly, that committee agreed to a quota for Queensland for the 1985 management program of 1.84 million, but the Minister, for reasons best known to him, did not agree to that. People may think that will mean those extra 500,000 kangaroos will not be shot. I point out that-the same as with birds-since the development of the rural areas of this country macropods have bred up in large numbers because we have provided them with water which they would not otherwise have had. We have provided them with crops and improved pastures. Indeed, I recall telling a previous United States Ambassador when the kangaroo meat substitution scandal was on that he should not knock eating good roo meat because it is acknowledged to be high protein and the roos have been fed on the best crops and the most improved pastures that we have available. The cattle and the sheep have only what is left to eat. This is what has happened. Because of the crops, the improved pasture and the water the--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was their land to begin with and they were kicked off it.

—If we had not provided those conditions, the roos and the birds would have died in any drought year. Indeed, they still do in their thousands. Since the development of our rural areas we have allowed their numbers to breed up so there has to be a managed culling program.
—So you shoot the lot of them.

—Nobody shoots the lot. As Senator Georges should know, the relevant authorities can give permission for pests to be culled. Unfortunately, that type of culling does not provide secondary industry with hides and carcasses. The extra culling recommended by the scientific committee set up by the Minister would have provided extra carcasses, hides and jobs in Queensland and the kangaroo population would not have been in any danger. It is acknowledged by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation that currently there are about 20 million to 30 million kangaroos in Queensland. It is also acknowledged that the large numbers of roos cause a severe cost detriment to the rural area of Australia. I raise this matter under this Bill because this Bill controls the export of the specimen products.
—Speaking of substantiated numbers--
—They are substantiated numbers. If Senator Haines is going to tell the CSIRO that it plucks figures out of the air as she does, so be it.
—You are plucking things out of the air.

—I am not; I am just citing CSIRO figures. They are there for all to see. We support the legislation. The amendments which are proposed are necessary. We will not support the amendment as moved by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate. I think the concerns of substance that have been raised during the debate are adequately covered in the second reading speech. I refer particularly Senator Sanders to that speech. I do not propose to take the time of the Senate by repeating the points made in the speech. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Sanders's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 7, clause 16, line 35, leave out `or'.
(2) Page 7, clause 16, after proposed paragraph 42a (2) (c) insert the following word and paragraph:
`; or (d) specimens that are live native Australian animals of a species included in the sub-phylum VERTEBRATA, other than fish.'.

The purpose of the amendments, other than to correct a typographical error, is to ensure that multiple transaction permits are not available for live native Australian vertebrates, other than fish. This means, for example, that there could be no multiple transaction permits for the export of kangaroos. This has always been the case, and was inadvertently reversed in the course of the drafting process. The omission, fortuitously, was identified during the debate in the House of Representatives, and thus I have moved this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the Government's amendments. It did concern us that there would be multiple permits for kangaroos. It behoves us to tighten up in every way the shipment of kangaroo hides. I point out that I was quite surprised to hear Senator Collard cite figures of 20 million to 30 million kangaroos in Australia, as if the figures represented some sort of gospel, given by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. In fact, no one knows how many kangaroos there are in Australia; absolutely no one. There is no estimate. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service cannot come up with a decent estimate. Nobody can give us any estimate. It behoves us, before we implement a program of culling, which means killing, kangaroos, or basing an industry on kangaroos, to know how many kangaroos there are. Yet we are told over and over again that there are plenty, that since the numbers killed every year are remaining constant, there must be plenty of kangaroos. But in resource management this is a very fallacious argument. Anyone with any knowledge of resource management will realise that if one does not include catch effort-the effort made to take an animal, a fish or any manner of wildlife-one simply does not know how many there are. In the anchovy industry off the coast of South America, the catch figure was kept up every year until the industry collapsed completely. In Tasmania-my wonderful home State, the home of the woodchipper, the miner and the Hydro-Electric Commission-we had an animal called the Tasmanian tiger-the thylacine. Numbers of this animal were considered to be very plentiful-so plentiful, in fact, that there was a bounty on its head. The bounty remained until long after the last thylacine had been killed. So it is a fallacy merely to say that one can kill a certain number of animals every year and that this proves there will be plenty left.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the amendments moved by the Government. We support those amendments. I urge the Government, having regard to its enlightened amendment, to take a good, hard look at the whole kangaroo culling program and to inform the National Parks and Wildlife Service that all of us would appreciate its taking a good, hard look at the whole situation. It should take its responsibilities seriously, control the industry and protect the wildlife, rather than taking the course, which is common to many bureaucracies, of taking the bureaucratically easy path of going along with what the industry wants. The industry is becoming very powerful indeed in the kangaroo area. The tail is now wagging the dog. The industry was set up to use the by-products and is now dictating policy. Often the National Parks and Wildlife Service yields to the demands of industry to the detriment of Australian wildlife.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 20 February, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, for which I lead on this occasion, has great pleasure in supporting the Criminology Research Amendment Bill 1986. This Bill deals primarily with the addition of the Northern Territory to the Criminology Research Council and amendments that flow from that; an increase in the size of the board of management from six to eight-the same size as the new Council so the board will then comprise the Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, three persons nominated by the Attorney-General, and four persons nominated by the Council-the granting of specific authority to the Institute to collect information and statistics without detracting from the role of the Australian Bureau of Statistics; the provision of information and advice to the Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory departments, agencies and authorities dealing with the administration of criminal justice; collaboration with bodies in Australia and overseas; and, finally, the granting of power to the Attorney-General to request the conduct of particular research matters or training programs by the Institute. The Board of Management is obliged to give priority to the Attorney-General's request as the Attorney-General specifies.

SPEECH.PARA: Before saying anything further about the legislation, I am sure that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) would want to join with me in recording a tribute to Mr Bill Clifford, the previous head of the Australian Institute of Criminology, who died on 6 June. This Bill was introduced prior to Mr Clifford's death. Nevertheless, I think he was one of the most significant figures in the development of criminological studies in Australia. He had a distinguished international career culminating in a four-year term as Director of the United Nations Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice Branch. He became Director of the Institute in 1975 and he held that position until his retirement in 1983. I believe that Mr Clifford was one of the outstanding figures in terms of research into crime, criminology and punishment. He had particular interest in the control of social behaviour which he developed during his studies, in particular, in Japan and he was an outstanding public servant. On behalf of the Opposition, I indicate our appreciation of the great work which he undertook.

Research into crime, the causes of crime and the nature of punishment is a very old area of study. One can trace back to the works of Cesare Beccaria, the first scientific attempt to come to grips with the study of crime. Beccaria published his great work Treatise on Crimes and Punishments which first appeared in Italian in 1764 and was subsequently published in English in 1880. Beccaria's treatise was the first succinct and systematic statement of principles governing criminal punishment. It was the first to be based upon some attempt to undertake some genuine scientific work and, interestingly, Beccaria was the first modern writer to advocate the complete abolition of capital punishment. To that extent he established a tradition which has been adhered to in civilised countries and by civilised people ever since. I think it most unfortunate that we see in Australia today the rise yet again of the debate about the reintroduction of capital punishment. I think since the days of Beccaria onwards scientific study and research have indicated that the death penalty is not a deterrent, that it is a cruel and unusual punishment, that mistakes are frequently made; and that civilised persons should not countenance that sort of approach to punishment. Beccaria's work was very influential once it was in English. Jeremy Bentham, one of the great social reformers and pioneers in England, was very much influenced by Beccaria's work.

I mentioned Beccaria because I think there tends to be a general lack of knowledge about the importance of scientific research in terms of the establishment of what are the facts about crime; everybody thinks that he knows all the details of what constitutes criminal behaviour, how widespread it is, whether it has or has not increased over recent years and what the response should be to alleged upsurges in crime or a particular type of criminal behaviour.

The Institute has identified a number of areas important enough to require continuing research and coverage. They include crime and criminal justice statistics, policing and public scrutiny, courts and sentencing, penal policies and corrections, Aboriginals and criminal justice, violence against women and children, corporate and white collar crime, juvenile justice, something that wallows in the absolutely awful name of victimology-part of what ought to be done is that criminologists ought to be penalised for the cold blooded murder of the English tongue-specialist research topics, particularly those relating to drug marketing and drug enforcement strategies, and the general position of women as the victims of crime.

In the annual report of the Institute in recent years one has seen very good reports of work done on censuses on national corrections, prison trends, juveniles under detention, prosecutorial discretion, enforcement strategies of Australian business regulatory agencies and political terrorism. The Institute is not a major consumer of public funds. It was given a grant of just over $2m in 1985 and it had been provided with $2.3m in the 1985-86 Budget. I do not believe, given the important work that the Institute does, that that is other than money well spent.

I want to draw attention to a couple of more recent reports and publications by the Institute of Criminology. It publishes an excellent journal entitled Reporter. In volume 7 No. 1 of March 1986 my attention was particularly drawn to two areas-the report of a conference on child abuse and a very good report on Dr Jocelynne Scutt's work relating to media exploitation of women. Both of these areas are increasingly of community concern. It is interesting to see that the Institute has drawn attention to them in its most recent publication. Indeed, it has provided considerable discussion about the approaches that need to be taken in order to have an understanding of what constitutes the main dynamics of child abuse and to what are the consequences of the presentation of women by the media in particular stereotype roles. Those are among the important issues to be addressed.

I refer to a more recent publication-the July 1986 publication, which I think is the first of the series-entitled `Trends and issues'. Dr Paul Wilson of the Institute, who is perhaps the most publicly known criminologist in Australia, is the general editor of this publication which comments on trends and issues in crime and criminal justice. This particularly interesting edition of the publication is entitled `Uses and abuses of drug law enforcement statistics'. I repeat the point that I was seeking to make earlier: Everybody who believes that they know everything that there is to be known about crime and criminal behaviour and therefore can automatically assume what the penalties are would do well to read this material. For instance, the publication contains extremely good figures on the percentage of drug offences involving cannabis, heroin and cocaine, and those figures are broken up State by State. I think it is of some significance to know that, while in Victoria cannabis accounts for 74 per cent and heroin for 16 per cent of drug offences, in Queensland the figures are 94 per cent and 2 per cent respectively. The publication states:

. . . drug offence rates vary considerably across the country. In 1983-84 the highest rates are found in Queensland and South Australia. New South Wales, commonly regarded as having the most serious illegal drug problem in Australia by virtue of its population and being the entry point for a large proportion of illegal drugs, is ranked fourth, after Tasmania, in rates of recorded drug offences.

How one goes on to interpret these statistics in terms of whether they reflect on the nature of sentencing, the penalties, the law and the competence of the police forces, is a matter for debate. But it is important in the first instance to get these sorts of figures down on the record. The document further states:
. . . enforcement statistics are often used in a biased and unscientific manner to illustrate particular points of view in the drugs debate.

That, I think, is particularly important. The use of raw statistical data without a clear understanding of the methodology by which the data has been gathered, the analysis which has gone into the data and all of the other factors which relate to the production of raw statistical information are some of the useful functions which the Institute and its research projects provide. This extremely valuable document also states:

Informed debate on drug issues and proper evaluation of law enforcement policies are not possible until we increase the range and quality of data collected on illegal drug use and strategies to control it.
The document concludes:
With such information our drug control policies could be constructed on a firm and factual base and could realistically be evaluated.
