I think what we are doing in terms of this piece of legislation is giving some greater flexibility, scope and purpose to the work of the Institute. We are giving the Attorney-General power to commission and direct that a particular type of work be done. I believe that this is a significant advance and something which should be greatly valued.

I think two other areas which have been the subject of recent publication or research by the Institute are of interest. People perhaps will not be surprised that my attention has been drawn to a talk delivered by Dr Wilson to the South Australian Police Association on 10 April 1986 which glorifies in the brilliant title of `Serial and Lust Murder: Questions on Police Management and Response'. Needless to say, the title immediately got me in. As a result I have managed to obtain from the Institute a copy of Dr Wilson's paper. In fact, the paper is very interesting because the thesis put forward by Dr Wilson in fact deals with the relationship of a particular type of pornography with the predisposition that people have towards the commission of certain types of criminal activity involved, particularly in this case, with what Dr Wilson calls lust killings. He says:

While I would not suggest that sexual/sadistic pornography `causes' lust killings, I do believe that this material can easily reinforce predispositions towards committing these particular types of crimes by fuelling existing tendencies within the potential murderer's psyche.
He continued:
Of course, even if I am right this is not a sufficient reason to censor what normal men and women see or view in their own homes.

He concludes that paragraph by indicating that he would `far prefer to see education and voluntary boycotts of this material than legislation'. I think that is quite correct. I certainly do not believe in moving back into the realms of censorship to deal with these matters. I believe that by and large the good sense and good judgment of the majority of the Australian community can be relied upon in that regard. But here again I think this is a useful contribution to the debate about the nature of pornography, about the effects of pornography and about the causes of a particular type of violent crime. Dr Wilson has advanced the debate on a number of fronts. For instance, his discussions on the question of the validity of maintaining a belief in insanity as a defence in capital cases I think again helps to advance a better understanding of what we are trying to do.

The last point I want to make concerns research. I have not been able to find any written material on this subject although I have heard a radio report. I would like to make, as it were, a commercial and say that I would be most interested to see any material that is available. From the radio report I gathered that someone called Dr Hatty had been studying the question of suicide in prisons and had indicated that approximately half of all the deaths which take place of people in custody are the result of their committing suicide. In fact, if that is the case, there are certainly a number of quite profound indications for the way in which our penal institutions are conducted. This finding certainly has some very significant implications in regard to the sorts of people who might or who might not appropriately be sentenced to terms of imprisonment. I have been very concerned about the sorts of pressures which have been placed on our penal institutions in New South Wales in the course of the last couple of years. Over a period I have had the pleasure-I might say perhaps the privilege rather than the pleasure-of visiting most of the gaols in New South Wales. I might add that I have done so purely in a spirit of research and endeavour and for no other purpose. But it seems to me that in New South Wales in particular the question of the appropriate segregation of first offenders is an area which has not been properly addressed.

I believe that there has been some reform in a number of areas. I well recall some years ago, when my very dear friend John Maddison was Attorney-General and Minister for Justice in New South Wales, going to a number of prisons and talking to a number of prison officers about the way in which prisoners were segregated when they came into the system and the way in which it was determined where they should be sent. In those days there were continued prosecutions for homosexual offences. I well remember an officer of the New South Wales Prisons Department, as it then was, telling me, without realising the irony of what he was saying, that the way in which they solved the problem was to sort out all of the homosexuals when they got into the detention centres and to ship them all off together to Berrima. The whole of the homosexual population was contained in Berrima Gaol and some of them had to share cells. I shall never forget him telling me that as far as he could recall he had never had any complaints.

I suppose from time to time one comes across these fairly quaint approaches to the administration of penal laws in Australia. However, it is certainly true, if we are to continue systems of keeping people in prison, that we will need a great deal of research into the effects. For instance, it used to be claimed some 15 years ago-I think these figures are still fundamentally accurate-that of people who were brought before the courts and sentenced, approximately 70 per cent actually went to gaol and 30 per cent were out on some form of release such as weekend detention, licence, or whatever. But those figures have now turned around and of the people brought before the courts and sentenced only about 30 per cent actually end up being sent to prison. Therefore, what is happening is that the population of the prison system is getting progressively worse, if one can use that term. In fact whereas prisons used to have a great range of offenders, they primarily now contain much worse offenders. The most violent, the most intractable criminals are being sent to them. Obviously, under those circumstances there need to be significant changes in the way in which penal institutions are managed and in which sentencing is dealt with.

I will not go into the alarming statistics which one sees, for instance, about the confinement of the Aboriginal population in gaols. There is absolutely no doubt that a gross violence is being perpetrated against the Aboriginal community throughout Australia when one compares the percentage of Aboriginals who are in prison with their percentage in the population, and in particular when one looks at the relative statistics between males and females as far as that is concerned. If the Institute is able to address these sorts of questions in terms of research, data and statistics, we as legislators will be in a better position, given that the Commonwealth has very limited jurisdiction and limited direct involvement in this matter, Federal offenders being primarily incarcerated in New South Wales institutions. We will be provided with more information, and I believe that will help us to look at the issues of law reform and penal reform and at the whole way in which the criminal justice system in Australia operates.

I am grateful for the opportunity to indicate, on behalf of the Opposition, our support for this legislation. I am most impressed with the ongoing work which the Institute has done. I believe that it has made, and continues to make, a valuable contribution. We in the Opposition will continue to look carefully at the research mat- erial that is produced by the Institute. I hope that as a result of these amendments some of that work can be facilitated and some greater flexibility in the operations of the Institute can be brought about. We certainly wish this Bill a very speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pay tribute to the excellent contribution made by Senator Puplick, who has mentioned many of the things that I would have mentioned had I intended to speak for longer than I shall today. The purpose of the Criminology Research Amendment Bill 1986 is to amend the Criminology Research Act 1971. That Act set up the Australian Institute of Criminology, the Criminology Research Council, the Criminology Research Fund-which is jointly funded on an equal basis by the States and the Commonwealth-and a board of management for the Institute. Since the word `criminology' is often used incorrectly, although not as often as it used to be when people read detective novels and thought they had read about criminology, and since its scope is not well understood, I would like to give a dictionary definition of it and then explain the importance of the study of criminology to contemporary Australian society. I have deliberately chosen the Macquarie Dictionary, not only because it is Australian but also because it seems to be more up-to-date with the contemporary usage of language. The Macquarie defines criminology as:

SPEECH.PARA: the science dealing with the causes and treatment of crimes and criminals.

Criminology is the study of the nature of crime, the factors associated with criminal behaviour, and the treatment of offenders, which is often somewhat optimistically referred to as `correction'. It is a social science which calls on a number of other branches of science and their skills and research findings, such as sociology, law, psychology, psychiatry, general medicine and forensic science. It is a valuable tester and dispeller of myths, such as the myths that harsher penalties always deter criminals, that church-going or making divorce harder to get will reduce the rate of juvenile offences, or that the stranger is always the greater danger to women and children.

I studied criminology as an academic discipline in the mid-1960s. It was a very valuable experience, not only the theoretical study but also the opportunity I had, which not many people even today have, of actually visiting prisons and seeing prison conditions of the sort that the previous speaker, Senator Puplick, referred to. My studies made me immediately aware of the great lack of Australian based research in the area, or even of basic data, such as crime statistics which could be compared, say, between States or over time-I understand that that is still a problem-let alone evidence on the effects of particular preventive or corrective practices, such as release for community work, parole and so on.

Since the 1971 legislation was passed, much has been achieved. Fifteen years is a very short time in which to develop research in a very complex area. Much remains to be done even if the context of the research remains static, which of course it does not. One example of that is the great increase in the last 15 years of drug-related crime. Fifteen years is also not a long time in which to educate the community, or even its decision-makers, such as ourselves, about the work being done in criminology research. We still hear of police statistics and even police theories being quoted as evidence, say, of the effect of sentencing policies on the causes of crime, rather than seeking advice from the people who are able scientifically to collect and specifically evaluate the available evidence. This lack of qualified advice was evident in relation to the drug offensive, as referred to by Senator Puplick. Governments of all varieties have not made full use of the criminology research results which are available.

I am glad to have this opportunity to commend the work of the Institute and its excellent quarterly publication, the Reporter, and also its various research papers which are available from time to time. The work of the Institute has been very valuable to parliamentary committees-for example, the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, of which I am a member. We have had very valuable input from members of the Institute. I hope that parliamentary committees and other reviews within the community will increasingly seek submissions and evidence from the Institute. In addition, it also illuminates and encourages community debate. As an example, I would like to mention some of the seminar programs that the Institute has held this year. These are only about half of the year's programs: It has held seminars on child abuse, on the jury system, on drug markets and law enforcement strategies, on law and psychiatry-that was an international congress of very great moment-on women and crime, and on the privatisation of correction.

Last year I was a member of a review team which examined the functions of the four statutory authorities which are the responsibility of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). These are the Institute of Criminology, the Institute of Family Studies, the Law Reform Commission and the Human Rights Commission. That review reaffirmed the value of those authorities and their continued support as separate bodies. It made some recommendations regarding their future functions, and this Bill embodies some of those recommendations as they apply to this Institute. The Bill also includes the Northern Territory, which for obvious reasons was not covered 15 years ago. It will now be represented in the structure of the Institute.

I want to give two examples of matters which came out of that review and which have been embodied in this Bill. The Bill gives the Institute specific authority to collect information and statistics separately from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This is extremely important to the work of the Institute because different methods of data collection and data of different categories are required from those that the ABS collect; that is, it is a specialised area of statistical collection and analysis. In accordance with the findings of our review, the amendments enable the Attorney-General to request the Institute to carry out a particular research or training project as a matter of priority. I stress the word `request'. The provision does not detract from the autonomy of the Institute. I am sure that its board of management will always give due weight to any such request received. I also note with pleasure that this Bill removes gender specific language from the Criminology Research Act to make it gender neutral.

Finally, I commend the Bill and hope that it will lead to further fruitful work in criminology research and to better liaison with government so that wider use is made of the resources provided by the Australian Institute of Criminology and the Criminology Research Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the amendments to the Criminology Research Act encompassed in the Criminology Research Amendment Bill 1986 are mainly of a machinery nature they are very sensible and the Australian Democrats give them our whole-hearted support. In particular we support the amendment which provides for the Northern Territory to be a participant in this scheme which will increase the size of the board of management. We also support other measures which will enhance the activities of the Australian Institute of Criminology. Senator Zakharov has already referred to those measures, particularly the one which relates to the collection of statistics.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators will be aware, the Criminology Research Council and the Institute established under the Act do extremely valuable work for the community. It is difficult to over-estimate the importance of research in this area. Research is an essential adjunct to the law and to law enforcement processes. The administration of the criminal justice system without research would be blind. Criminology research is an area of great significance to the wider community and to any civilised society. Senator Puplick raised a number of points on that in his speech a short time ago. The development and the maintenance of a humane and just society cannot be achieved unless our planning is based on fact and unless our decision making is informed decision making.

More often than not, unfortunately, the debate about crime and the criminal justice processes tends to emphasise how bad things are and how much worse they are now than they were X years ago. Nowhere is this more true in Australia than in the community debate on organised crime. A frightening picture is built up of the tentacles of organised crime reaching into every sphere of life. The media scenario is that Mr Big seems to have replaced the communists under the bed, or if he is there as well it must be getting very crowded. This gets close to something Senator Puplick referred to in his speech. To combat this threatening problem, draconian measures are floated in the media and taken up with alacrity in the community with, I believe, very little regard being given to the civil liberties of individuals or, more importantly, to whether any of those measures will have the intended results. While it is certain that crime exists in our community and that it is manifesting itself in an organised way in certain spheres-the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and other inquiries have certainly identified these for us-it is equally true that solutions can and must be found. I believe that our responses to these issues will not be constructive and they most definitely will not be effective unless we are properly informed as to the content and the results of what it is that we are trying to do.

Quite apart from responding, it is vital that we, as politicians, inform ourselves about ways in which crime can be prevented. A preventative approach is clearly of benefit to the perpetrators of crimes, to the victims, as well as to the wider community. It seems to us that while a great deal is often talked about and an enormous amount of energy and money is spent in apprehending criminals, very little attention is actually directed towards the prevention of crime.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was making some comments about the Criminology Research Amendment Bill. In summary, the points I had made were that I believe that the only way that genuine reforms of the criminal justice system will be successfully implemented in Australia will be through the educative role of bodies such as the Institute of Criminology and the Criminology Research Council. From the 1985 annual report of the Australian Institute of Criminology we see quite clearly the valuable work that has been done in this area. Research has been reported on crime statistics, public security, sentencing, correctional service policy, Aboriginal people and criminal justice, violence against women and children, corporate and white collar crime, juvenile offenders, victims of crime, terrorism and drug enforcement policies.

SPEECH.PARA: These areas have often been cynically exploited and treated as political footballs, as complex problems and also with a fair amount of disregard for the well-being of the people involved. Independent bodies such as the Australian Institute of Criminology do much to destroy many of the myths and prejudices which surround this area and which have affected decision-making by legislatures. For example, Mr John Walker's study of the use of remand in custody orders has revealed some disturbing matters. Remand in custody involves deprivation of an accused person's freedom in conditions comparable to those in which convicted people are punished. The data in the study, contrary to the common notions of human justice, suggests that on occasion the police and the courts use remand in custody as a means of incapacitating the alleged offender while investigations continue and magistrates sometimes use remand to give alleged offenders a taste of prison. Deprivation of freedom in such circumstances can be regarded only as the most serious infringement of civil liberties. As the study concluded, some form of monitoring system is urgently required.

The research grants awarded by the Criminology Research Council are being used to fund equally valuable projects. These range from a study of agency approaches to the implementation of environmental legislation to the crime prevention strategies for services for unemployed youth. The cost of policing and enforcement of the courts and correctional services for the criminal justice system in Australia approximates $2,000m a year. The amount spent on the Institute of Criminology in 1984-85 was only $2m-that is, $2,000m against $2m. This is an example of the misplaced priorities we so often see. Not only that; it is false economy. There is no doubt that the cost of our law enforcement agencies and our correctional services would be reduced if we put more money into preventative measures. This can only be done by developing these preventative measures through appropriate research. The subject matter of this Bill encourages discussions as to whether we can find more effective ways of dealing with crime in our society. Hopefully, the on going debate about this will lead to improvements. That can only be applauded.

This brings me to one of the most important consequences of the work done by the Institute and the Council; that is, the use made of this information by legislators around the country. I often wonder, for example, how informed honourable senators, members of the House of Representatives and our State colleagues in the various parliaments around Australia are about the deterrent effects of penalties which we include, almost as a matter of course, in legislation. Most of the available studies indicate that tougher penalties do not deter criminals. In the sphere of domestic violence, for instance, experts emphasise the use of non-arrest alternatives such as mediation counselling, rehabilitation and referral to other agencies. We all pay lip service to the need for rehabilitation in the criminal justice system, but how many of us know whether it happens and, if it does, to what effect?

I wonder whether members of parliament are sufficiently sensitive to the fact that certain programs work with certain offenders but that there is no right program for all offenders. Do we pay sufficient attention, in formulating laws in this chamber, to the links between criminal activity and unemployment, poverty, the lack of educational attainment and racism? From what I have seen here, I doubt it very much. The problem is two-fold: First, there is the need to fund and support research bodies adequately, so that information is available on prevention strategies and necessary reforms. Secondly, and equally importantly, it is vital that this information be used by legislatures in their deliberations. For example, it would be extremely useful if relevant research findings were made available by the Government prior to debates on certain pieces of legislation. I urge the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who is at the table, to have discussions with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to see whether at the next Criminology Research Council meeting-or by referring the matter directly to the Australian Institute of Criminology-it is possible to have agreement that research findings will be made available to us when relevant legislation is about to come before us. It is all well and good that we applaud the contents of this Bill. Everybody who has spoken so far in the debate has done so. It is much more important that these studies be used in our deliberations as comprehensively as possible.

I refer now to some aspects that the Institute of Criminology, through its ongoing research, might be able to influence in the wider debate about various crime issues in Australia. I refer to a debate that is taking place on mandatory sentences for drug offences. That debate is occurring in my State of Queensland. As a remedy, mandatory sentences seek to restrict the discretion of a judge of the court in his sentencing options. They are an extremely popular reform in many ways because they seem to follow the notion of getting tough with criminal offenders and getting tough on drugs. Hence, that notion has been able to find a fair amount of support in the community and the media.

This also appears to be a relatively quick and direct solution to the problem that the community is facing. Despite the popular nature of this operation, we should look at the research in this area to see whether that type of move is as beneficial as the popular myth seems to make out. I quote from a report by the United States Justice Department which reviewed mandatory sentences in the United States in the last 10 years. It made the following comment, which is an appropriately cautious comment for a justice department to make, however, the content is clear. It said:
It is difficult, perhaps fundamentally impossible, to substantiate the popular claim that mandatory sentencing is an effective tool for reducing crime.

That seems to be a rather laid back way of saying something. The report refers to the review that was done of the New York criminal code in regard to mandatory sentencing, which is probably one of the best known examples in criminology of what has occurred. Essentially what was said to be the United States' toughest drug laws ever were enacted in New York. The law contained three major provisions: First, long term mandatory sentencing for heroin dealers; secondly, restrictions on plea bargaining for heroin dealers, which we do not have to deal with so much in the Australian context; and thirdly, mandatory sentencing for certain categories of repeat offenders. The prescribed prison terms were truly staggering. The law established three categories of heroin dealers. Class A-1 included major dealers, defined as people who either sold one ounce or possessed two ounces of heroin. The mandatory minimum prison terms for these people were 15 or 25 years and a maximum of life imprisonment. Class A-II included middle level dealers, defined as those who sold one-eighth of an ounce or possessed one to two ounces. The penalties for these people were six to eight years. Class A-III included minor or street dealers, defined as those who sold less than one-eighth of an ounce, and the mandated prison terms were of one to eight years.

Despite the combination of harsh penalties and the enormous publicity surrounding this operation in New York, the review found that it had little or no effect on the crime rate. Its impact was examined in the study from a variety of different angles. The first angle was that heroin use in New York City was as widespread four years after the law came into force as it was when it came into force. The second angle was that serious property crime, the kind generally associated with heroin users, increased sharply, by 15 per cent, as did serious property crime in the surrounding states. Hence New York was not out of pattern. It showed the same pattern as the general area. The third angle was recidivism-the law did not appear to have had any effect at all. It is interesting to ask ourselves why. The research is very interesting. The answer is that deterrents and incapacitation are wonderful theories but do not seem to work all that well in practice. The review of the drug law concluded:
Mandatory sentencing laws directly affect only an end product of a long criminal justice process-the convicted offender.

Following arrest, three key decision points affect the outcome of a case: The indictment, the conviction and the sentence. For a deterrent to work, there cannot be any slippage between the three. However, in New York, in the four years after the law came into force, the percentage of drug arrests leading to indictment declined from 39 per cent to 25 per cent. At the same time the percentage of indictments leading to conviction fell from 86 per cent to 80 per cent. Thus, while 33.5 per cent of all drug arrests before the law came into force led to conviction, only 20 per cent did so four years after the law came into force. To put it another way, the drug offences conviction rate declined by one-third, thereby seriously undermining any intended effect of the law.

The people who were convicted stayed longer in gaol. But if the intent of the law was to cut down on drug dealing, it does not seem to have worked. The percentage of convicted offenders receiving the various prescribed penalties certainly went up. Judges imposed harsher penalties under the law, as they were required to do, but only two-thirds as many convicted offenders ended up being dealt with. The reason for that is quite clear. As soon as the penalties went up, there was a reaction. About two and a half times as many defendants sought trial because of the penalties involved. Since a trial in New York takes, on average, 15 times as long to deal with as one in which a guilty plea is entered, it is fairly obvious that the prosecutors simply tailored the number of cases they were to deal with to fit the time they had available. So the number of people who appeared before the courts dropped alarmingly. If one puts the various percentages together, the overall effect was that 11 per cent of the people arrested for heroin sale before the law came into practice went to prison. Four years afterwards the figure was still 11 per cent. In other words, the law had had absolutely nil effect.

Senator Zakharov referred to the need for the Australian Institute of Criminology to keep its own statistics. The interesting thing is for us to try to work out what happens as a result of laws, apart from what we might wish to happen. The debate that has taken place in my State of Queensland has been rather superficial. Everybody says that it is good to have these harsher penalties for drug dealers. But if the aim is to reduce the amount of drug trafficking, to focus just on harsher penalties seems to me to be departing from what legislators ought to be doing, that is, directing themselves to the real issues and seeking real solutions to the problems, not just the solutions which might make them popular in the Press. Getting tough by levelling harsher penalties may make us feel good but it does not help those who are pushed into the drug trade.

I ask the Minister to take seriously the comment that I have made which is that where it seems appropriate in legislation that comes before us, the Australian Institute of Criminology may be asked to do its literature searches and to come up with a useful survey of literature and research in areas which may be made available on call to any member of parliament who wishes to have that information. Simply having research done is useless unless that research is applied. The place where, presumably, a lot of that research has to be applied is in this chamber and in the other place. I ask the Minister to consider this matter seriously. Justice and humanity demand that, as much as possible, we inform ourselves of the effects of the laws that we pass. I commend the work carried out to date by the Institute and by the Council. The Australian Democrats support this Bill. My only hope is that the very good work both of these groups have done to date does not go to waste in terms of debates in this chamber on relevant legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that during the course of this debate on the Criminology Research Amendment Bill, which unfortunately I have missed, there has been nothing but praise both for the legislation and for the Australian Institute of Criminology. That information comes to me from its Director; so I hope that it is reliable. Certainly I hope that is the attitude of the Senate. It is a first rate organisation. It has done first rate work and this particular legislation will enable it to go on performing that work in the future. There are many areas that have been mentioned in the course of the debate, I understand, as potentially proper subject areas for the attention of the Institute. I am sure that within the limits of its resources and the resources that the Government, with all the best will in the world, is able to provide to it, that it will do its best to pick up those suggestions. I thank the Senate for its support of the Bill and I commend it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 September, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Good freedom of information legislation is that which would set a minimum of procedural obstacles by way of delay or complexity of costs and afford the maximum of practical assistance to those who are pressing requests for access to information'. Little wonder it is that Senator Gareth Evans has his head in his hands as his very own words are quoted back to him as part and parcel of the exercise in which we now see Senator Evans once again involved on behalf of the Government in the murdering of freedom of information legislation. The days of Opposition were easy for Senator Evans. When the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs produced its report on freedom of information, Senator Evans had been criticising the lack of response on the part of the government of the day to all of the recommendations of that Committee-the recommendations for easy access, for waiver of charges in the public interest and for limited charges to be imposed. On 11 September 1980, Senator Hamer asked him:

SPEECH.PARA: Would a Labor Government accept those recommendations?
Senator Evans replied:

I can make, so far as I possibly can, Senator, an absolutely unequivocal statement of my belief-I hope it goes further than a belief-that an incoming Labor government would fully respect and adopt all the significant recommendations that are contained in the Senate Committee report and would introduce a Bill in those terms. That is my understanding and the position of my colleagues on the subject matter. I believe that is an accurate statement of what will in fact happen.
Those words need to be supplemented only by one quotation from the current Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen:
Freedom of information is a basic democratic right and it lies at the heart of the democratic system.
Or, as Senator Evans again said on that previous occasion:
There is the notion that freedom of information is not really a democratic right at all but rather a luxury or a privilege that is to be doled out in small doses to a duly grateful peasantry.

The peasantry on this occasion is certainly not duly grateful for the treatment which is being meted out to it by Senator Evans and his Government in this shabby piece of legislation which attempts to wind back the clock on freedom of information. After all, as Senator Evans has reminded us on a number of occasions, one cannot trust governments or public services to try to make available to people proper information that might help them in dealing with matters of concern to them. Indeed, as the Sydney Morning Herald editorial said on 7 October, quoting those words of Mr Lionel Bowen:
True, so why is Mr Bowen, now the Attorney-General, proposing to make it more difficult and more expensive for the public to use the Freedom of Information Act?
If the Government's and the bureaucracy's motives were not so suspect, the argument for more economic rigour would be more readily acceptable.
As the Age article on 9 October said:
A bill is now before the Senate which, if passed, will make FOI so costly that most ordinary people will not be able to use it for anything except seeing their personal files.
Rights which are not used tend to disappear.

Senator Evans, it can be understood, finds himself in an exquisitely unique position as far as freedom of information is concerned. The one-time champion, the one-time advocate and the one-time defender of freedom of information now comes along here with a poisoned chalice in order to murder this piece of legislation by a combination of increased charges and increased complexity. It flies in the face of everything that he promised to do in opposition, everything that he promised he would achieve in the first six weeks of his own Attorney-Generalship, and it is no wonder he sits there in embarrassment and later will have to get up and defend what, for him, is the indefensible.

It seems that even Senator Cooney has been reduced to total silence as far as this debate is concerned because, despite the lecture we got earlier today about the values of the legal profession in standing up for the rights of ordinary citizens, these luminaries of the legal profession opposite-Senator Evans and Senator Cooney-will, in fact, troop into the division lobbies when we come to the appropriate stages in dealing with this legislation, in order to make freedom of information more costly, more complex and more genuinely difficult for people to actually obtain.

As far as the specific provisions of the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986 are concerned, I will outline them briefly. The Bill will introduce a $30 application fee for an FOI request. It will increase the charge for agency research and retrieval time to $15 an hour. It will introduce a charge of $20 an hour for agency decision-making and consultation time. It will introduce an application fee of $40 for internal review requests. It will provide that no fee or charges will be payable in respect of requests for access to personal income maintenance documents. It will maintain the present 45 days time limit on answering requests from 1 December 1986. It will strengthen provisions for refusal of requests on work load grounds. It will reduce the grounds for the remission of charges. It will reduce the obligations on agencies to publish section 8 and section 9 statements and to provide statistics, and it will make what are called miscellaneous and consequential amendments.

The heart of this legislation lies in the new charges. Let us examine the bogus evidence upon which the Government has come to the Senate in order to deal with the question of charges. Most interesting is the way in which the Department of Finance has behaved in this matter. In the annual report of the Attorney-General's Department for 1984-85 the costs of the Department of Finance under freedom of information legislation are shown as $65,630. In the annual report of the Department of Finance for the same period those costs are shown as $123,160. In other words, the Department of Finance has managed to concoct a set of figures which are twice the figures of the Attorney-General's Department. Perhaps I should put it another way: The Attorney-General's Department has managed to concoct a set of figures which are half those of the Department of Finance. On the basis of this bodgie evidence one is supposed to believe that there is some extraordinary explosion in the cost of freedom of information services.

That is not the only example that can be given. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal told the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, initially, that its cost for freedom of information requests last year was $15,924. However, the Attorney-General's Department had managed to get that up to $25,666. When one inquires about the reasons for the discrepancy one is told that it all depends on what set of overhead figures are used-66 per cent, 80 per cent or 85 per cent. At various stages various departments use any one of the three figures, presumably depending on what time of the month it is or the particular condition of the individual making the determinations.

TALK.START.PARA: —A sexist remark.

—If Senator Gareth Evans believes that only a certain section of the population is affected in that way, that is his problem. I turn to the evidence presented by the Government. The Attorney-General, in the second reading speech and in the financial impact statement which was attached, made some comments about what are alleged to be the costs of freedom of information legislation over the last year. Mr Bowen claimed originally that the preliminary figures for 1985-86 show that there will be a cost to the revenue of $14m. Nevertheless, when the Department of Finance came before the Senate Committee to make its presentation it was prepared to put this figure up to in excess of $19m. We have had a series of exchanges in which the Department of Finance has said that the cost of FOI rose from $17.6m in 1983-84 to $19.2m in 1984-85-a 9 per cent increase. However, the actual figures show a decline. Taking the Attorney-General's own figures given in his second reading speech and related statement, the cost of FOI will reduce from $16m to $14m. It takes the most extraordinary effort, even on the part of the Government, to turn a reduction of $2m according to the Attorney-General into an increase of 9 per cent according to the Department of Finance. This is given as some rationale or excuse for claiming that freedom of information is becoming so costly and so much of a burden upon public revenues that a new higher system of charges must be introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Finance has concocted a marvellous way in which it thinks these charges should be calculated. I quote from a letter which the Department of Finance provided to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in which it is said, among other things, concerning the $4m allegedly to be raised by these new charges:

The estimates assume some 12,800 chargeable requests, an average of four hours per request for search and retrieval time and an average of 11 hours per request for decision making/consultation time . . .

The basis for calculation of costs for each request is an average of 11 hours to make a decision and to consult and four hours to search. In addition, it is anticipated that there will be 1,000 chargeable requests for internal review. From the figures of the Department of Finance, that works out to give an average cost of in the vicinity of $310 for each freedom of information request.

One knows that the figures on freedom of information requests have been padded out by Commonwealth departments consistently including, as FOI requests, requests made by members of the Commonwealth Public Service for access to and information on their own personnel files. When Dr Peter Wilenski, the Chairman of the Public Service Board, came before the Senate Committee he freely admitted that this was a complete travesty of the way in which freedom of information calculations were expected to be made; that departments have been putting into FOI requests personnel requests for access by public servants to their own personnel files; that this has served both to inflate figures and to inflate costs; and that access which should be provided under established Public Service Board guidelines is not being properly applied within departments. The Government stands accused on this occasion of both fudging the figures on costs and fudging the figures on requests, and using those bogus figures to bring about a situation in which representatives of organisations, such as the National Secretary of the Returned Services League, make representations to senators that these charges will substantially disadvantage their members. Mr Pearce from the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association gave evidence to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee stating that these new arrangements will make the whole system of freedom of information less viable for individuals.

The Opposition has a series of amendments which it proposes to move to this legislation. They touch upon three particular areas-the making of multi-document requests, which is referred to in the legislation; the power to remit charges in certain instances where the public interest is involved; and the reduction of the 45-day time constraint for the answering of requests. I will be dealing in the committee stage with each of those areas. I want to say something at this stage on the question of charges. These changes have come before us in a piece of legislation which the Opposition has taken to be a Budget Bill. We will therefore deal with it differently from the way in which it would be dealt with if it had come to us, as the last attempt did, by way of amendment to regulation or by way of a piece of legislation which was not seeking to raise revenue within the context of the Budget. Much as it disconcerts members of the Opposition to be in a position of not voting against the increases in charges as part of the Government's financial strategy within the Budget-the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has given a commitment not to interfere with the Government's financial arrangements within the Budget-it is not our intention to move for the charges section of this legislation to be struck out of the Bill. In fact, we know that on this occasion, given what the Australian Democrats have said, that would be possible, if we so moved. Nevertheless, a principle which we have established, in dealing with the Government's financial legislation arising out of this Budget, is an overriding commitment. It is one which we have made and which has been given clearly by the Leader of the Opposition, and we will not depart from it on this occasion. But it ought to be made abundantly clear that this legislation is the Government's legislation; these charges are the Government's charges; these imposts are the Government's imposts. If it had not put them in a piece of budgetary legislation, with these sorts of financial implications, the legislation would not have had passage through the Senate in the way in which it will have passage as a result of what I have just said.

The second area was the area of the 45 days-the attempt to prevent the automatic reduction at the specified date on 1 December 1986 from 45 days to 30 days for the handling of requests. This was originally set by the Senate Committee at 60 days, with an automatic reduction to 45 days, followed by an automatic reduction to 30 days. The Attorney-General now comes along to the Parliament and says: `That 45-day period should not be reduced to 30; it should be maintained at 45'. But what did he say when he was the Opposition spokesman? He sent a submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That is referred to in paragraph 8.40 of the Committee's original report. What did he say in that submission? He said that it ought to be-without any difficulty at all and from the point of introduction-no more than 10 days. The submission which he made to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee was that it ought to be 10 days-not just that it should be eventually reduced to 10 days, but that it should be 10 days from the introduction of the legislation. That 10 days has now grown to 45 days. It has not only grown to 45 days, but we are now told by the same person, Mr Lionel Bowen, that the automatic reduction to 30 days, which he and Senator Evans criticised as being far too long at the time, should now be maintained at the present, higher 45-day mark. We have a great deal more to say about that, and we will move an amendment to delete from this legislation the attempt by the Government to remove the requirement for the 45 days automatically to become 30 days.

We then have the case of the curious explanatory memorandum or, I should say, explanatory memoranda. When we deal with proposed new section 24 (1), we find some extraordinary comings and goings by this Government. New section 24 (1) is designed to introduce a system whereby multi-document requests may be refused if an agency or a Minister is satisfied that they will clog up the work of the department. In the Government's original explanatory memorandum on this matter, headed `Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986, Explanatory Memorandum, Circulated by Authority of the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General, the Honourable Lionel Bowen, M.P.', we read this:

Section 24 (1) will provide that a multi-document request may be refused where the agency or Minister is satisfied at any time after receipt that the likely total work would substantially and unreasonably divert the resources of the agency from its other operations, would interfere substantially and unreasonably with the performance by the Minister of the Minister's functions, or would result in substantial delays in dealing with other requests.

One would have thought that that test-that there would have been a substantial and unreasonable burden-might have been a fair test. But having looked at that, the Attorney-General's Department, the Attorney-General or somebody went into a fairly flat spin, because that explanatory memorandum was withdrawn. In fact, in the House of Representatives the Attorney- General tried to deny that it had ever been issued in the first place, and a new explanatory memorandum was put out. The section, in the second explanatory memorandum, is explained in the following terms:

Section 24 (1) will provide that a multi-document request may be refused where the agency or Minister is satisfied at any time after receipt that the likely total work would substantially divert the resources of the agency from its other operations, would interfere substantially with the performance by the Minister of the Minister's functions, or would result in substantial delays in dealing with other requests.

You will note, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the term `unreasonably divert' has been deleted from the second explanatory memorandum. So instead of the test as it originally was, being `substantially and unreasonably divert', it is now simply `substantially divert'. The additional protection which one might have thought the original explanatory memorandum offered to people to challenge the determination of the Government to refuse requests has been substantially and unreasonably weakened. No satisfactory explanation has been given, other than the most feeble of all-that is, that it was a printing error, that somebody else did it, that some clerk, official or government printer ought to be held accountable for a document which was nevertheless circulated with a cover page indicating that it was authorised by the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General.

The final point to which we will draw attention in seeking to amend this legislation is the provision which currently exists for the remission of charges on the basis of public interest. We will move to strengthen the ability of the person making the decision to give access to a document in the general public interest on the basis of waiving the normal fee or charge. If one refers again to the original Senate Committee report, at paragraphs 11.40, 11.41 and 11.42, one will see that that report argues as cogently as was possible-in fact, it argues with brilliant cogency-for the waiver of fees. I say that the language in that chapter is as tightly argued and as formidable as it possibly could be because I know that that was one of the chapters in the report which was actually written in long hand and drafted by Senator Gareth Evans when he was a member of the Committee. There simply can not be anything more cogently and more strongly argued than this question of waiver of fees, written in Senator Gareth Evans's own beautiful script which now, of course, is cast into the rubbish bin of history once Sir Humphrey has managed to turn Senator Evans into Minister Evans.

Of course, this is exactly what has occurred: The bureaucracy has sought to weaken and damage this legislation. It was to be the great weapon in the armoury of the public-or, as Senator Evans said on that wonderful occasion, a duly grateful peasantry-in order to advance their own protection, to advance their own cause, to keep government honest, to keep the facts on the table, to allow for the smooth public administration of the country. And here it is no more than two parliamentary terms away from those ringing words of Senator Evans, no more than two elections away from those wonderful submissions of Lionel Bowen, that we find the two of them, as neat a conspiracy against the public interest as one could possibly imagine, coming into the Parliament in order to support and argue for a piece of legislation of this mean and miserable character. One knows that Senator Evans will not do so with any great enthusiasm or with any great heart. One knows that Senator Cooney cannot even bring himself to open his mouth on the subject, lest he fall into the trap of denouncing this absolutely monstrous piece of legislation. Nevertheless, there it is.

As I have said, the charges sections of this legislation, because they are taken by us to be legitimately part of the Government's budgetary arrangements, will not be voted against by the Opposition. However, those three areas-the multi-document request, the waiver of charges in terms of the public interest and the attempt to stop the reduction of time from the 45 days-will be argued against strenuously. We will move amendments against them and we will expect, of course, the unqualified support of the Australian Democrats on this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Highly qualified support.

—Senator Vigor's support should be unqualified because the sheer logic of the whole matter is such that it should commend itself even to Senator Vigor, even if it did not a couple of hours ago when he was dealing with other matters. Senator Evans will be discomfited to know that we will have a great deal more to say about this legislation as the debate proceeds but all I can promise him is that while we will say it with as much fervour as Senator Evans said it when he was in opposition, it will still be with considerably less time and with considerably more determination to stick to the arrangements and promises we made than he and Mr Lionel Bowen have been able to assume and to demonstrate. I conclude by saying that not only should they be ashamed of themselves but from the look on Senator Evans's face I can see that he at least is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a rousing condemnation of the Freedom of Information Act from Senator Puplick. I notice that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) is congratulating Senator Puplick and I think that should be on the record. Senator Puplick used two phrases: One was that the Opposition would not be voting against the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986. Let us be very clear what that means. The Opposition will vote for it and the Australian Democrats will make sure, by calling a division, that the Opposition is voting for those very things that Senator Puplick so eloquently just condemned. He called the legislation a poisoned chalice and the Opposition is steadying the Government's hand so that the Government is able to drink from the poisoned chalice. This is all in the name of some pseudo-operation that the Opposition has come up with called Budget Bills, that is, it continues to draw its salary for the second half of the year but it does not intend to review any legislation while it does so. Senator Puplick called it Government legislation. I find that an extraordinary admission coming from Senator Puplick. No legislation belongs to the Government; all legislation belongs to the Parliament because only the Parliament is able to pass legislation. This Government will be able to pass this legislation only with the help of the Liberal and National parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill ought to be entitled the destruction of the freedom of information laws amendment Bill. The Freedom of Information Act began operating in December 1982; so it has had a very brief history indeed. Many of its Australian Labor Party advocates at that time are now Ministers and since they are Ministers presumably they are now impelled by a different view, that is, they have been discomfited by the freedom of information legislation because it has brought out inconvenient facts at inconvenient times. That is one of the important things about freedom of information, for example: The MX missile material, the Daintree rainforest material, the fate of Australian aid to the Philippines, the fake testing in the United States of America of chemicals used in Australia, the social security fraud, the surveillance of doctors in the Medicare investigations, Budget planning, tax avoidance, defence planning. The list goes on and on of items that through freedom of information have been brought out at an inconvenient time to the Minister concerned. We now see the results of this Government's discomfiture with this Act.

Let us not forget the issues about which we are talking here. We are talking about the right of citizens in Australia to have information about the activities of those who govern them, that is, the government of the day and the bureaucracy. In a democratic society one would think that such a right would simply be taken for granted. Knowledge is power and in this circumstance those who have the monopoly of information obviously intend to keep that monopoly of information to themselves.

Four years ago, after an extremely hard fought campaign of which the Minister for Resources and Energy was part, the Freedom of Information Act came into force and the public was given a legally enforceable right to know what is going on. In many ways it was circumscribed but it was still a start down the track of that enforceable legal right to know what is going on. It was a simple matter of justice, a belated achievement at the time but it was an achievement of great proportions to Australia. In the last four years we have seen this Act under continual attack from within the Government and the bureaucracy. One of the main focuses of this attack has now emerged in this Bill and that is costs. Nobody, the Government least of all, will ever admit that he has any disagreements with the fundamental principles underlying freedom of information. It is just the unfortunate and unintended consequences presumably of the Freedom of Information Act about which the Government is concerned. We are now about to see a collusion, a dirty deal entered into by the Government and the Opposition, to destroy this Act.

Last November this Senate disallowed attempts to increase the powers of the Freedom of Information Act under regulations. It should be noted that the Opposition parties, quite rightly at that time, supported that disallowance. This time, however, the Government has been one bit smarter. It has introduced this Bill as part of the 1986 Budget. I forecast that this will be exactly the same fate for the Australia Card because the Government, with foresight, introduced it as part of the Budget although obviously it had been around before as had these charges. This Senate had had a debate about them and disallowed them last November. So this measure is not new and it could never be claimed as being anything new. This Parliament is now about to pass not only this legislation but also legislation about the Australia Card. Having got this legislation into the Budget context, so called-the Opposition has decided that it will sit on its hands because it will not review legislation at this time of the year-we now find that like the wine tax and so many other measures that have affected various sections of the community, the Opposition will not only allow it to pass, but also will not vote against it, to use the phrase Senator Puplick used. It will actively vote for it. It will cross the floor and join with the Government to start the dismemberment of a very important and very great development in Australia's democratic history.

When in opposition the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, said that freedom of information is a basic right that lies at the very heart of the democratic system. Obviously, that is now about to be an excessively qualified right and a right I believe, in terms of what the Government is doing, that is wrenching the heart out of the democratic system, to use Mr Bowen's term. In government Mr Bowen, rather than looking at the heart of the democratic system, is now gravely concerned-to use his phrase-about the cost of administering the Act. It now appears that the price of freedom will be rather more than mere vigilance on the part of the Senate.
Debate interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate both in his capacity as the Minister representing the Prime Minister and as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's statement in the House of Representatives yesterday that Australia would not participate in and would not facilitate participation in the strategic defence initiative. Is the Minister aware of the statement by United States Defense Secretary Weinberger as reported in the Australian Financial Review on 6 June this year? In expressing the hope that Australian expertise might be involved in the strategic defence initiative program, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: A Government agreement is not necessary at all.

Noting that the Minister has previously said that Government institutions such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation will not be participating in the program, I ask: Has the Government attempted in any way to prevent private sector participation in the research aspects of the strategic defence initiative program? If so, what specific action has it taken to block such participation? Lastly, if no restriction exists on the private sector, is the Minister aware of any Australian involvement in the program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of parts to the question directed to me by Senator Chaney. He is right in saying that I have previously expressed a position in the Senate about the SDI program and indicated the Government's attitude to that program in general terms, particularly casting doubts on the credibility of the program in scientific terms and the desirability of the program in terms of its contribution or otherwise to raising the level of international tension. Insofar as organisations like CSIRO are concerned, I understand that the Government's position has been made clear to those organisations but I would like perhaps to elaborate on that answer at a later stage because I am not quite clear at this time what precise steps have been taken in relation to that.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to private sector involvement, I think I would again give the same answer: The Government's intentions and policy stance on that position have been made clear. There are, of course, difficulties about answering that part of the question which goes to what extent research activities of one kind or another are in fact related to the SDI program. For example, there are peripheral research activities being conducted by Australian companies which may have a marginal relevance to the SDI program. I do not know; that is very difficult to assess. For example, research into various types of computer technologies, research even into things such as advanced welding techniques, could be said by somebody who wanted to make a spurious case on this matter to be related to the SDI program. But at present I know of no Australian companies which could in any way be described as being directly involved in the SDI program. I will seek further information on that question for Senator Chaney and try to provide it as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer. However, I would just seek clarification on one point. The Minister has indicated that as far as he is concerned he knows of no Australian private company or non-government body that is participating in research. He said in his answer with respect to the private sector that the Government position had been made clear. Has the Government in fact in its statement meant to indicate to the private sector that it should not participate or is that in fact a matter which has been left up to the private sector?

—I do not think the Government has made any direct approaches to private sector companies saying that they may or may not be involved or that they are on the fringe, as it were, of being involved in SDI research. I do not think the Government has made any approaches to such companies and said: `You shall not do it'. Let me obtain further clarification of that matter for the honourable senator. I will try to provide an early answer.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. The Government announced in August 1985 a range of economic measures against South Africa which included a direction that Commonwealth departments and authorities could no longer enter into certain contracts with South African majority owned companies. What steps have been taken by the Government in relation to its purchasing activities to implement these sanctions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a well known fact that the Australian Government has taken very energetic steps to impose where possible sanctions against the purchase of goods from South Africa. The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services has asked his ministerial colleagues to direct their departmental heads and the officers of statutory authorities under their ministerial responsibility to implement the Government's policies with regard to sanctions against South Africa in their purchasing operations. The Department of Local Government and Administrative Services has also issued instructions to Commonwealth Government departments and authorities by way of two Commonwealth purchasing circulars to realise those objectives.

ANSWER.PARA: So, in general, the Government has stopped Commonwealth agencies buying supplies of South African goods or goods of South African origin or purchasing from South African owned firms. This policy applies to the purchase and sale of goods and services for Commonwealth purposes both in Australia and overseas. Government contractors are required to refrain from sub-contracting work to South African companies or incorporating South African origin supplies in Commonwealth orders. So I think the Government has done whatever is possible to do at this stage to ensure that its policies in respect of South Africa are implemented by all agencies and departments under its controls.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Resources and Energy say whether it is the Federal Government's intention to seek World Heritage listing for stage 3 of Kakadu National Park? If so, what effect will this have on the development of the ore bodies within that area?

—No decision has yet been made with respect to seeking World Heritage listing in relation to stage 3. Of course, that decision has been made and announced and begun to be implemented so far as stage 2 is concerned following on the earlier listing of stage 1. But the detailed future of stage 3 remains, as has been said on a number of public occasions, to be finally determined.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article on the front page of yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald dealing with the reluctance of the National Farmers Federation to be involved in the review of the fringe benefits tax? If so, can the Minister indicate what are the principles of the tax the Government has excluded from discussion with the NFF?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw that report and, indeed, a number of other reports covering the same subject in the Press yesterday. I suppose it is to be regretted that the National Farmers Federation decided to take the attitude it did. It is, however, worth noting that the NFF headed by Mr McLachlan, who is a member of the New Right or the extreme Right, as I think it should be more accurately described, has not gone as far as the Federal Opposition has now gone. Mr McLachlan claims that the NFF is objecting not to the principle of imposing a tax but to the way in which the tax on fringe benefits is to be imposed. That was similar to the policy line which was run previously by Mr Sinclair and Mr Hunt and Sir William Knox in Queensland from the Liberal Party-that is, that section 26 (e) would be enforced. Of course, the Commissioner of Taxation scuttled that well and truly yesterday, but I will leave that aside for the moment. That line run by the two leading National Party members of the Federal Parliament, by the Liberal Party leader in Queensland and a number of other people was, however, overturned when Sir Robert Sparkes stood over Mr Sinclair and forced him to make this statement:

ANSWER.PARA: The only way to treat fringe benefits is to provide a total exemption . . .
I repeat:
The only way to treat fringe benefits is to provide a total exemption . . .

That was Mr Sinclair repudiating himself, repudiating the statements once made by the Leader of the Opposition, repudiating Mr Hunt, repudiating Sir William Knox, repudiating even the National Farmers Federation, and repudiating even the extreme Right, as represented by Ian McLachlan, who does not challenge the principle, so he says, that fringe benefits should be taxed. So we now have the position where the Leader of the National Party has gone to the extreme of the extreme Right. He has fallen right off the planet. I have also noted, of course, that Senator Bjelke-Petersen said:
Our position is that the current legislation should be scrapped and that the Government should enforce taxation of benefits in the hands of the recipients under section 26(e) of the Taxation Act.

Mr Sinclair has repudiated Senator Bjelke-Petersen as well. I would have thought that Senator Bjelke-Petersen was far enough to the right to please Margaret Thatcher. But Mr Sinclair has now gone beyond that as well. He says that the only way to treat fringe benefits is to provide a total exemption. In other words, he is saying: `Let's declare to the world that the taxation system is wide open to the sort of rorting and wholesale tax evasion which was so popular when John Howard was Treasurer'.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I was trying to discern something intelligible or intelligent from the babble of voices opposite, but I have failed to do so.
—I would ask the Minister to ignore the interjections and concentrate on Senator Morris's question.

—Certainly, Mr President. In conclusion, Senator Morris, it is regrettable, I think, that the National Farmers Federation has chosen not to accept the Government's invitation, although it is not terribly surprising. I suppose the one little ray of sunshine here is that at least the National Farmers Federation is not as extreme as the National Party under Mr Sinclair has become, after he was stood over by Sir Robert Sparkes.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FRANKLIN-LOWER GORDON WILD RIVERS NATIONAL PARK

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment: How much Commonwealth Government money has been spent on ranger facilities, wages and other expenses in the Franklin-Lower Gordon Wild Rivers National Park? Is the Collingwood Bridge ranger facility to be transferred to Queenstown? Is any part of this facility to be transferred? Will the Government ensure that this vital ranger establishment, which serves 500 to 1,000 Franklin River rafters each year, is consolidated rather than downgraded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The costs of ranger facilities, wages and other expenses in the Franklin-Lower Gordon Wild Rivers National Park are met from contributions by the Commonwealth and Tasmania governments for management of the whole--
—I thought he said that this was without notice.

—Mr President, this is extremely childish behaviour by the Opposition. I will read it out, and then I will table it. I am sure Senator Sanders will be pleased to hear that the total Commonwealth contributions were $500,000 in 1983, $498,000 in 1984-85 and $2m in 1985-86. A further $2m is to be contributed this financial year, bringing the total to $5m. The combined budget for the area is allocated to programs approved by the World Heritage Area Ministerial Council. This arrangement does not enable me to distinguish exactly how many dollars of Commonwealth funding have been spent in the Franklin-Lower Gordon Wild Rivers National Park on the items listed by Senator Sanders. However, I am able to advise that the injection of Commonwealth funding for management of the area enables the employment of six additional rangers, two park assistants and one office assistant in the Franklin-Lower Gordon Wild Rivers National Park. Three of the rangers are stationed at the Collingwood Ranger Station.

ANSWER.PARA: The Tasmanian World Heritage Area Council has not considered any proposal for the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service to transfer the Collingwood ranger station to Queenstown. Currently the three staff of the ranger station are accommodated in three caravans and a small cabin, but the Tasmanian Government has asked the Ministerial Council to consider a proposal that a permanent ranger station be constructed in the park on the Lyell Highway. The Council has not yet addressed this proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister to table the paper from which she was reading.
—I do so happily.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to newspaper reports of a `toughly worded speech' made by the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations, Mr Richard Woolcott, in the course of which he urged the United Nations to adopt drastic budgetary measures without which it may not survive its current financial and organisational crisis. Can the Minister expand on the nature of this crisis and comment, if possible, on the possibility of the restructuring of the United Nations to reflect, among other things, the anti-discrimination requirements of its own various covenants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Press reports of the statement by Mr Richard Woolcott, who is, as Senator Giles says, Australia's permanent representative to the United Nations in New York. The statement does accurately reflect the Government's concern about the need for major reform in the administration of the United Nations and its commitment to work towards a more effective and more efficient organisation. These views were expressed at the United Nations most recently by Mr Hayden, in his speech, I think, to the General Assembly on 1 October this year. Mr Woolcott's statement was addressing the report of the 18-member group of high level intergovernmental experts, the so-called G18, which did recommend a number of reforms to improve the efficiency of the administrative and financial functioning of the UN. The proposals deal with such issues as improved program management, staff savings and more efficient intergovernmental machinery. The report also discussed the need for a more responsive budget setting process.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not sure about the extent to which that report addressed the question of effective implementation of the human rights covenants of the United Nations and the UN human rights machinery, but that is something I will pursue further with the Minister and give Senator Giles a further reply, if one seems useful.

Mr Woolcott's statement, I add finally, endorsed many of the recommendations of the G18 and restated Australia's support for reform. Mr Woolcott urged that the necessary decisions be taken during the current session of the General Assembly. I repeat that it is the Government's hope that significant reform will be accomplished because it is only through such a process that the United Nations' present financial and, some might say, political crisis will in fact be overcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the continuing increase in our current account deficit. I ask: Is it not a fact that our economic recovery rests heavily on a dramatic improvement in our balance of trade? Is it not a fact that there has not yet been a turnaround in private industry investment notwithstanding the 40 per cent drop in the value of our dollar over the past two years? In these circumstances, does the Minister agree that the course on which Mr Keating has now embarked, of talking up policy and the dollar to attract capital inflow to cover the current account deficit, is fraught with danger in that any inflow from such talk will be speculative, and although speculative funds might provide a short term gloss to figures, they will not provide any long term solution to our problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The word `speculative' was used in Senator Lewis's question, and of course the question contained more speculation than interrogation of me. It was a highly speculative argument which was encapsulated in his question. I do not agree that the economic recovery of this country rests, as he put it, on a dramatic turnaround in the trade deficit. I have said on a number of occasions, as have other Government Ministers, that we do not expect a dramatic turnaround in the trade deficit.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian trade deficit problem has been accumulating for many years. It has become worse in recent years and, to use the honourable senator's words, we have seen in the last 12 months some dramatic illustrations of the problem which has been there for years. The sins of many years, inflicted, of course, by governments other than this one, cannot be turned around and expurgated in a dramatic way. I must disagree with the honourable senator's first speculation, which is that there can be a dramatic turnaround in the current account deficit.

The second speculation related to private sector investment. The Government has been conservative, in my view, in the estimates which have been made in the Budget Papers in respect of private sector investment in this country. Consequent upon the embryonic J-curve effect there is a lot of discussion in Australia about investment at present, and that discussion will undoubtedly continue and lead to an improved investment performance which in turn will lead to a steady turnaround in the current account deficit. Senator Lewis also asked me about the Treasurer, in the honourable senator's words, `talking up the dollar' in the United States, leading to speculative investment. That is the wildest speculation in his question. I do not know to which particular statements of the Treasurer the honourable senator was referring, but I know that a number of prominent Australian businessmen taking part in a conference in New York some 10 days ago delivered speeches in which some suggested that the Australian dollar had been undervalued in recent weeks. A number of them made statements which were very cautiously optimistic about the Australian economy, and a number of them made statements which suggested that they felt it was a very appropriate time for non-speculative investment in Australia.
