It was not just the Treasurer, if that is the allegation against the Treasurer-and I do not accept that allegation-made those sorts of statements; a number of Australian businessmen made them as well. I have at least one of the speeches which were given and I would be happy to make it available to the honourable senator at an appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services will recall that I referred him last week to the malicious tactics used by the Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association of Australia in its campaign for increased nursing home benefits. Could the Minister indicate whether there have been any further attempts by this Association to exploit the fears of nursing home residents in New South Wales? Can he give any reassurance to these patients that their interests will be safeguarded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said last week, Cabinet will shortly be considering, as it does every year and as it has done every year for the last 20 years I think, an increase in the nursing home benefits which will, I expect, be paid in November this year. There has been no indication by the Government or by any member of the Government that we would not take into account increases in costs and therefore increases in nursing home fees, any more than any other government has done. I was disappointed, although I must say not surprised as I indicated last week, that some of the private nursing home proprietors would have used the sort of tactic they have in implying that the Government will not have such increases.

ANSWER.PARA: As for further developments on last week's effort, Senator Childs probably knows that there has been considerable agitation, again I repeat, by some private nursing home proprietors in New South Wales trying to worry those people who use their facilities, and in particular trying to worry the relatives of those people who use their facilities. In particular, one group of individuals decided to ring offices of members and senators impersonating the relatives and, in one case, a nursing home client in order to press the case. It was only because of the interrogation skills of a member of one senator's staff that eventually these people were trapped into admitting that they were not nursing home clients, and in one case that they were nursing home proprietors.

I must say that some of the nursing home proprietors in this country, particularly some in Senator Childs's State-I emphasise only some of them-are some of the most unsavoury characters that a Minister for Community Services, and previously Social Security, would have to deal with. That has been the view not only of the Minister but also of several previous Ministers who have spoken to me, including Ministers in previous governments. It is a pity that those decent people who are working in this area and who own nursing homes should have their reputations associated with the few, particularly some of the large entrepreneurs, who use the tactics that they are using at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation a question about the possibility of a private firm building a new international terminal at Brisbane Airport in conjunction with the building of a hotel. On 20 August the Minister informed me that the tender for a combined hotel-international terminal was being examined as part of the normal tendering process. Is it correct that the Government has now decided not to proceed with the building of a new terminal as part of a hotel complex at Brisbane? Can the Minister give the reasons why this decision was made? Is it a fact that the Government claims that it has not the money to build a new international terminal in Brisbane, despite the growth of tourism in Queensland and the fact that Expo 88 is to be held there? If this is so, should not the Government be encouraging the private sector to build the international air terminal in Brisbane for it at no cost to the taxpayer so that it will be ready for Expo 88?

—I recall the previous occasion when Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me about the Brisbane Airport. Subsequently I was able to get a reply to her. I recall that there were some substantial problems with the Government's proposals in respect of suggestions about constructing and developing the Brisbane Airport. There was some regard to legal difficulties which were apparent at that time. In view of those circumstances I think that I should get a precise answer from the Minister to see whether he is able to advance his response on this occasion to the fresh questions raised by the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Education to an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald entitled `ESL Cuts: Cavalier accuses Ryan'. Can the Minister confirm that she has received a letter from the New South Wales Education Minister concerning the English as a second language program? Can the Minister explain to the Senate the consequence of this communication?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm that I have received a letter from Mr Cavalier, the New South Wales Education Minister, part of which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning. It is regrettable that I am in a position to confirm that to the Senate because it is my strongly held view that communications between ministerial colleagues, particularly in areas where there is some controversy or some misunderstanding, are best handled confidentially and it is always my practice to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: However, for reasons best known to himself, Mr Cavalier allowed part of the letter-which I might say is a very long letter-to appear in the Sydney Morning Herald, or it appeared by some other means. I do not think its appearance really assists in what ought to be the top priority for Mr Cavalier in the New South Wales Government as it is for our Government, for me, to arrange Commonwealth-State education funding programs so that children who are in need of ESL teaching suffer no diminution in the services available to them. That is my objective. That is the objective which has been achieved in our negotiations with other States and major non-government systems. Of course, it is our objective concerning New South Wales. It seems that Mr Cavalier has other objectives in mind at this stage. I hope he will consider and review his position.

However, since this has been made a matter of public knowledge in this rather regrettable way, I need to place a couple of things on the record about the capacity of the New South Wales Government to use Commonwealth education allocations for a variety of purposes, including maintaining ESL classes. As I have said before in this place, our Government is of the view that the New South Wales Government, when reaching agreement with us about the allocation of extra recurrent funding for next year, ought to give the highest priority to ESL-related programs. Those extra recurrent funds to which I refer are substantial. The New South Wales Government will receive an additional $18.4m in extra recurrent money in 1987 as part of an overall package received from our Government of $147m for its recurrent program. The New South Wales Government will also receive $9.3m in ESL general funding from 1987 as well as a special allocation of $1.5m in additional funds for ESL made available after the Budget.

Anyone who follows that figuring must agree that these funds are more than adequate to compensate for the $7.3m reduction in the direct ESL general program. At this stage, the New South Wales Minister has chosen to propose that none of the extra recurrent funds be allocated to ESL. Instead, New South Wales has proposed to spend all that money on professional development for teachers. The Commonwealth accepts that professional development for teachers is an important objective. However, we do not believe under present circumstances that those programs deserve as high a priority as ESL programs. Today I wrote back to Mr Cavalier asking him to reconsider his view and to use that substantial extra recurrent funding to which I have referred to give a higher priority to ESL programs so that it will not be necessary for any such reduction in ESL teaching in the New South Wales system to occur. The particular proposals on professional development that have been made to me by the New South Wales Minister have not been agreed to. I have asked him to reconsider. It is very important that all honourable senators whom I know are very interested in this matter agree that the important outcome is that Commonwealth funds available for education purposes in New South Wales be used according to the best possible methods, including the maintenance of necessary ESL programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Finance. In view of the Minister's much aired views on the cashing out of fringe benefits by employers and taking into consideration the policy of reviewing Australian Public Service conditions of employment, does the Minister have any plans to alter the salary packages of public servants so that fringe benefits become assessable in the hands of the recipients, thereby saving taxpayers the millions of dollars which will be spent by government departments on calculating and meeting the fringe benefits tax liability? An example of just one Department's costs is that of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, which told an Estimates committee that it estimated for that Department that `between one and two staff years will be required to monitor and control the payments of fringe benefits tax'. In reaching a decision on this matter has the Minister had any discussions or advice from persons within the Public Service who are likely to be in receipt of fringe benefits as part of their salary package?

—Cashing out is an option available to those who claim that it is far too onerous for them to administer the fringe benefits tax. Those claims, almost without exception, are bogus. They are made because it is judged to be much more acceptable to the public to say `We think it is too hard to administer and we are protesting about it for that reason' than it is to say: `We are protesting about this because we have been up to our ears in tax evasion and we will stay up to our ears in tax evasion if we can bluff the Government or get a compliant Opposition in the Senate to prevent the legislation being passed in the first place'. It is in that context that the cashing out option arises. A question very similar to this was asked last week. Perhaps I should apologise because when I was asked-I cannot remember by whom-whether the total staff or administration cost to the Australian Public Service of the fringe benefits tax had been assessed I said that the so-called Waste Watch Committee had organised questions to be asked of every Department and I thought that the Waste Watch Committee would have the answers, unless it ran out of toes and was unable to total up the figures, in which case I suppose it could have sought Senator Watson's assistance or perhaps that of Senator Walters.
—Are you having a go at Tasmanians?
—I understand that Senator Watson was an accountant although, from the way he behaves here, not a very good one.
—I take a point of order. Will the Minister please answer the question and behave himself?
—Order! I ask the Minister to ignore the interjection and come back to the answer.

—Yes, Mr President. The fact is that Senator Watson said-no, Senator Walters, that is right; I should be able to tell the difference, although a newspaper once published a photograph of me with Senator Walters's name underneath it--
—Sue!
—Order! I ask the Minister to stop boasting and answer the question.

—Yes, Mr President. I decided not to sue, being a believer basically in a free Press and even of the freedom of the Press to misrepresent. The resources required to administer the matter within the Australian Public Service are not vast. The small amounts of fringe benefits which are provided are of the type that do not readily lend themselves to cashing out. That is not so in the great majority of cases in the private sector.

—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister consider that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is indulging in tax evasion when the amount of fringe benefits in that Department alone is $642,000?

—No, I do not. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has one of the higher fringe benefits costs. The Government's estimate of the revenue yield from the fringe benefits tax is of the order ultimately of about $700m. If one wishes to take the implicit assertion of Mr Hay, Mr Ansett and Mr McLachlan, that sum is $2 billion from the small business sector alone.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Firstly, could the Minister tell the Senate whether the co-operating agency at the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap is the United States Department of Defense or the Central Intelligence Agency which has been using the Department of Defense as a cover? Secondly, could the Minister say whether the United States National Security Agency is another co-operating agency which operates from Pine Gap and whose role includes interception of communications into and out of Australia, including commercial and political information? Finally, could the Minister outline the role of Pine Gap in a nuclear war fighting scenario as envisaged by the United States Secretary of Defense, Caspar Weinberger, in his 1984-88 program presented to Congress, as opposed to a deterrent function and state whether the Australian Government would terminate the agreement if it were evident that the Joint Facility had such an offensive role?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document formally entitled `Exchange of Notes between Australia and the United States of America constituting an Agreement Amending the Agreement relating to the establishment of a Joint Defence Space Research Facility of 9 December 1966', which document is from the Australian Treaty Series No. 24 of 1977, states that the co-operating agencies responsible for the operations of the facility at Pine Gap are the Australian Department of Defence and the United States Department of Defense. I also remind the honourable senator in this respect that on 27 May this year I advised her, in this chamber, that there are no National Security Agency facilities in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the latter parts of her question, the Government does not accept, as I have said to her on previous occasions here, that United States strategic policy is offensive in nature or is based on a nuclear war fighting posture. We are satisfied that United States nuclear strategy remains defensive in orientation, that it is designed to deter all conflict and that it is not a nuclear war fighting strategy. I remind the honourable senator, as I have in the past, of President Reagan's declared view that a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought; a view that was repeated by Secretary Weinberger, as the honourable senator may recall, in his speech to the National Press Club in April. Were the Australian Government to terminate the agreement over the facility, to which I have referred, it would reduce the contribution to verification of compliance with arms control and disarmament measures made by the joint facilities and would reduce significantly prospects for arms control agreements-prospects which, despite the disappointing outcome of the recent meeting at Reykjavik, remain alive. Furthermore, such a termination would add to the possibility of nuclear war by accident or misunderstanding.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the various proposals by political parties, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and others that unemployed juveniles be given the opportunity by compulsion or otherwise to undertake educational training or meaningful work in consideration of receiving unemployment benefit. I refer also to various statements over the years by members of the Australian Labor Party that International Labour Organisation conventions to which Australia is a signatory preclude the compelling to work of recipients of social security benefits. I ask: Is there any restriction, ILO or otherwise, which stands in the way of an Australian government seeking to impose training or work for a payment of unemployment benefit? Could a compulsory scheme be introduced, or is only a voluntary concept possible?
—I do not know the answer to that question. I will seek an answer and provide it to the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of persistent National Party claims that it best represents Queenslanders living in rural and provincial areas? Does the Minister have any information on non-metropolitan unemployment in Queensland since the National Party was last elected to government in that State? If so, what do the figures tell about job prospects for Queens- landers living in provincial cities and rural areas compared with the prospects of other Australians? What are the economic management implications of the figures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly aware of the repeated claims by the National Party that it best represents the interests of non-metropolitan Queenslanders. I think it also claims to best represent the interests of Queenslanders in general. I do not know which claim is the more absurd. The claims have about as much relationship to reality as the equally repeated claim that Queensland is the free enterprise State. Those who saw newspapers this morning and yesterday morning would realise how much enterprise there is in Queensland, if free enterprise means allowing market forces to determine outcomes rather than heavy-handed government intervention. The truth is that the Queensland Government presides over the most regimented economy in the country and has done so for many years.

ANSWER.PARA: In December 1983 unemployment in rural areas, or non-metropolitan areas, of Queensland was lower than the national average rate. In Queensland it was 9 per cent, against a national average unemployment rate of 9.5 per cent. But since January 1984 the national average unemployment rate has decreased steadily, while the Queensland non-metropolitan unemployment rate has increased steadily. For the 1984 calendar year, the average national unemployment rate was 9 per cent, while in Queensland it had grown to 9.8 per cent. If one looks at the more recent monthly statistics for 1986 until the end of August, one finds that the Queensland non-metropolitan unemployment rate was consistently about 2 per cent higher than the Australian average unemployment rate. Of the averages for all of those months, Queensland had a rate of 9.5 per cent in non-metropolitan areas and the national average unemployment rate was 8.1 per cent. So over the whole period it was a bit higher than 2 per cent.

The Queensland National Party Government is committed to providing plenty of jobs for politicians in rural areas. There is a ratio of one politician to about every 2,000 people, I think, if one counts the lot. There are plenty of jobs for National Party politicians. The Government is committed to that. But there are not too many jobs in non-metropolitan Queensland for other people.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DRUGS: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS FILM

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to media reports of the exchange between the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Qantas Airways Ltd over the national flag carrier's refusal to show a Department of Foreign Affairs film entitled `It's Not Worth Taking a Trip with Drugs'. I ask the Minister: Is it true or fair to assert, as Qantas is reported as stating, that the Department of Foreign Affairs `simply shoved the film at us on a take it or leave it basis'? Did the Department threaten Qantas with a Press campaign if the airline failed to show the film? Is Qantas right in asserting that `the Department is scrambling to get runs on the board in the wake of the hanging of Barlow and Chambers'? Is it not true that Qantas sought to sting the Department of Foreign Affairs for thousands of dollars to show this film? What action will the Government take to stop Qantas deceitfully referring to itself as `the spirit of Australia'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone asked four questions. The answers to them, as best I am aware, are as follows: In the first place, it is not the case that the Department of Foreign Affairs, as is reported, simply shoved the film at Qantas. Rather, officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs consulted with Qantas throughout the development of the film clip. Secondly, it is not the case that the Department threatened Qantas with a Press campaign if the airline failed to show the film. Thirdly, it is not the case, as someone from Qantas apparently asserted, that the Department was scrambling to get runs on the board in the wake of the hanging of Barlow and Chambers. That is a very unsavoury allegation and is utterly without foundation. This Government is deeply concerned by the particular horrific example provided by the Barlow and Chambers case of what ignorance of another country's laws can mean for Australians involved with drugs. Hence, the Government's initiative in getting the film made.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Vanstone is on slightly firmer ground, however, with her final question, which refers to the fee reportedly demanded by Qantas for the showing of the film. It is the case that Qantas sought charges amounting to an estimated $80,000 to $90,000 per annum to show the film. It is probably fair comment to say that in thus responding I do not think, and the Government does not think-certainly the Minister for Foreign Affairs does not think-that Qantas has done much to earn its `spirit of Australia' tag. It ought to be acknowledged in this respect that Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd has agreed to show the film, as has the Greater Union theatre chain, within Australia. In doing so they have displayed a considerably greater spirit of public service to all Australians than our national airline has displayed, apparently, on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Given that there have been many claims of insufficient research being carried out in Australia and of the need for government encouragement for research, can the Minister say what support is being given currently to industrial research? Specifically, can he outline the national teaching company scheme and say what benefits the scheme will have for local industry? Will the Minister also point to any further steps which are to be taken to encourage research for industry in Australia and to what extent the allocation of research moneys is co-ordinated with other research funding by the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of industrial research and development in Australia is crucially important. We had perhaps the worst performance in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development during the 1970s in terms of private sector research and development, and that is something from which we must recover, as we have to recover from a lot of other things that happened in the 1970s. I do not think Senator Watson, Liberal, Tasmania, is indicating that what I just said is wrong. I think he accepts what I just said.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government has provided significant resources to encourage research and development activities in private industry. The 1986-87 Budget provides $100m in tax incentives-that is, revenue forgone-for expenditure on research and development in private industry; $12.5m has been provided in grants to support worthwhile research and development which will not benefit significantly from the tax concession, mainly because the companies are small or perhaps have insufficient cash flow and are not eligible for the tax concession for those reasons; a further $2m is provided to support light industry research associations to supplement industry funding; and $1.2m has been provided for technology research and development, including $750,000 for the teacher company scheme, to which Senator Crowley referred in her question.

The teacher company scheme is designed to foster interaction between industry and tertiary education institutions by the placement of graduate researchers in industry to conduct industry relevant research projects under joint industry and academic supervision. The scheme aims to assist local industry to benefit from Australian scientific and industrial research. It encourages innovative companies and academics, through a system of grants, to come together to develop business efficiency within those companies. Twenty companies and researchers from institutions around Australia have been selected and given grants under the scheme.

Other steps have been taken to encourage research for Australian industry. For instance, within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's five research institutes, an estimated $107m will be spent on research this financial year. Budget allocations have risen over the past three years, with priority being given to biotechnology, generic manufacturing technologies and information and space technologies. Research and development activities are increasing significantly in Australian industry, largely as a result of the implementation of the tax incentive. I expect the proportion of industry based research to rise considerably as a proportion of total Australian research. The reaction to the new tax incentive scheme for R and D has been very encouraging. Indications from over 1,000 company registrations are that companies anticipate investing over $500m on R and D in 1985-86-one third more on R and D in real terms than in 1984-85-and further increases are expected this financial year.

The Government, by these mechanisms, is seeking to redress the balance between a highly funded government research sector and a poorly funded private research sector, which was the hallmark of this country in the 1970s. Senator Lewis earlier today asked me a question about anticipations about reducing the trade deficit in this country and whether that deficit could be reduced dramatically. I said that, in the Government's view, it could not. It is the sort of things addressed by Senator Crowley's very perceptive question, if I may say so, which should be drawn to the attention of people like Senator Lewis, because it is questions associated with research and development in the private sector, product development and so on, which will lead ultimately to a much healthier trading situation for this country in respect of manufactured products. Although Senator Lewis was not with us when I was giving the answer to Senator Crowley's question, I hope he will read the Hansard very carefully.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the story in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning which reports on the Queensland Government's determination to establish a food irradiation plant in Brisbane by September 1987? Will the Government give a guarantee that it will use all its constitutional powers to prevent the Queensland Government establishing a food irradiation plant in Queensland until the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation has completed its report into the numerous safety questions surrounding the issue of food irradiation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health informs me that his attention has been drawn to a report of the establishment of a food irradiation plant in Queensland, and denials by the Queensland Government of approval of any such project. The Minister also informs me that he has been informed that the Commonwealth has no powers over the States in the matter of the establishment of food irradiation plants. In June this year the National Health and Medical Research Council approved a recommendation for the establishment of food irradiation guidelines, and these guidelines were conveyed to the States.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of considerable concern by consumer representatives, the Minister for Health agreed to the Australian Consumers Association conducting an inquiry on the impact of food irradiation on consumer health and the environment. That inquiry is now under way. The House of Representatives Committee inquiry to which Senator Macklin referred was established in September to examine the use of ionising radiation for commercial sterilisation, disinfestation and food preservation, and will complement the ACA inquiry. While States have total autonomy to establish food irradiation plants, the Minister for Health has asked all State Health Ministers not to proceed with the establishment of food irradiation plants until the results of the inquiries are known. The Queensland Health Minister has responded and indicated that the responsible Minister is now the Minister for Primary Industries, and the Federal Minister for Health is awaiting his reply. I believe that this question will be solved in this country, as it has been in other countries, by sensible inquiries by appropriate authorities and not by rhetoric and scare tactics in this place.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LIBERAL PARTY OF AUSTRALIA: CAMPAIGN FUNDS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Special Minister of State aware of the article by David Monaghan in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning under the headline `Developer threatens to cut off Lib cash'? The resort developer of the Gold Coast, Mr Michael Gore, insists that he told Mr Howard, the Leader of the Opposition: `Either come up with a sensible policy or we will close the cheque books'. If, as is suggested, one businessperson has donated more than $1m to the campaign funds of the Liberal Party of Australia, is it possible that Commonwealth electoral laws have been breached? Does the Minister have any comment to make on this blatant attempt at cheque book corruption?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does appear that cheque book politics is becoming an increasingly recurring phenomenon within the Liberal wing of politics. I remind the Senate of Senator Cook's question in this respect on 23 September which I am still endeavouring to obtain an answer to. The situation is, as honourable senators should be aware, that under the Commonwealth Electoral Act, all political parties, candidates and Senate groups are required to disclose details of gifts received and electoral expenditure incurred. Moreover, the donor of a gift, or a number of gifts over the disclosure period, of $1,000 or more must be identified in the return.

ANSWER.PARA: The disclosures made by the Liberal Party of Australia and other parties in relation to the 1984 election are on the public record. Electoral expenditure reported by the Liberal Party for this election totalled $4.8m, so there was not much room for too many $1m donations among the contributions that have been disclosed. No doubt it will be interesting to check the record, as Senator Richardson no doubt will, to see what further information is there about the particular $1m donation to which the newspaper article refers.

The States, of course, do not have similar disclosure laws and no doubt the record of donors to the Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia in particular would be of great interest, although no doubt again so many of those are laundered through the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation that we might not have as much information as democracy would otherwise require. The vulnerability of parties to cheque book corruption of the kind outlined in this article and which one has reason to suppose is occurring elsewhere in the Liberal Party has been addressed through the public funding provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. One notes in this respect that the Liberal Party received $2.6m of public funding for the 1984 elections, which ought to have been enough to divert its attention away from attractions of the kind offered by Mr Gore and his colleagues.

I note finally, from the convenient memory lapse of the Leader of the Opposition, as reported in this Press item, when Mr Gore's comments apparently were drawn to his attention, that he rather wishes he had never met the gentleman in question. No doubt his embarrassment relates to the unwanted exposure by Mr Gore of the nature of the Liberal Party's funding and the sort of people who expect that party to respond to their beck and call. They are a pretty tacky collection and their tackiness has been well exposed by the article to which Senator Richardson referred us.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FREMANTLE GAS AND COKE COMPANY LTD

The matter to which he referred does not give rise to any conceivable question of political party donations, disclosed or otherwise. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

Good housing is vital for each of us-housing which is adequate, affordable and of good quality. Housing ranks high in the needs of Australians and their families. Today not only are Australia and Australians in deep trouble economically thanks to the Hawke Labor Government but also access to housing is disappearing for Australians, again thanks to the Hawke Labor Government. The hopes for housing are being dashed for Australians thanks to the Hawke Labor Government. The Australian housing industry is in trouble at present, again thanks to the Hawke Labor Government.

Several facts need to be stated. For four quarters running there were dramatic falls in new housing commencements in Australia. That is a fact. By June 1986 new housing starts were at an annualised rate of 117,000-down from something over 150,000 not so long ago. That is another fact. There are careful and sober predictions that housing commencements will fall as low as 105,000 in the 12-month period coming up. It is a fact that Professor Fred Gruen of the Australian National University advised earlier this year that the drop in commencements of owner occupied housing was likely to be as high as 17 per cent-one in six-by the middle of June 1986. It is a further fact that between February and April 1986 approvals for home units, flats and town houses fell by 20 per cent-by one-fifth-nationally and by as much as 43 per cent in my city, Sydney.

This is the stuff of crisis. Not only that; building costs are rising at a rate well ahead of inflation. Employment prospects in the building industry are diminishing. Even the Government's own indicative planning figures will mean the loss of a further 15,000 jobs in the housing industry. Again, this is a gift from the Hawke Labor Government to those who want to work in the housing industry. Stockbrokers such as Ord Minnett are advising their clients that if they are wise they will start selling the shares they hold in building supply companies. That is the judgment of the stock-market. Stockbrokers have judged correctly that housing is in crisis and housing investment companies are not good bets at present.

There is indeed a crisis in housing provision in Australia. Young Australians seeking homes today-either their first home or a larger home-face greater difficulties in so doing than they have for generations. It is not that there is no money around, because there is; it is just that home buyers cannot afford to use that money. The New South Wales Housing Minister, Mr Frank Walker, told a meeting recently that building society lending had dropped by 35 per cent in his State. Frank Walker is a Labor Minister. I believe him. If building society lending is down by 35 per cent, that is one indicator of the crisis. He correctly blamed the Hawke Government. Interest rates are very high and they are going up. The new loan rates are now 15 1/2 per cent. Young Australians know from bitter experience than an interest bill that was manageable when they took on a mortgage has very likely become unmanageable with the passage of time and rising interest rates. The rates for second mortgages, which many Australians need, are just prohibitive and becoming more so. So fewer Australians today are able to finance themselves into home ownership. That is indeed a crisis.

As financial pressures on home buyers rise, as interest burdens exceed people's capacity to pay, we find first that more families have debts which are so large that they cannot handle or service them. Secondly, we find there are increasing amounts of mortgage arrears. Indeed, the number of notices of arrears received by the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, a Government body, which receives notice of the arrears in mortgage payments, rose by 70 per cent between January and June this year. That is another indicator of a crisis in home ownership facing Australia today. Not only that; young Australians face an increasing number of repossessions of homes. An increasing number of families have insufficient cash to live on after they have made their mortgage payment. It is said that a family should aim to spend about 25 per cent of its weekly income on its shelter needs. The Government's housing poverty report identified 700,000 families as having severe difficulties in meeting home mortgage payments or rent payments. We know that there have been estimates that as many as 20 per cent of families are paying not just 25 per cent of their incomes but more than 35 per cent of their weekly incomes in an attempt to pay off their mortgages and stay in their homes.

The Reverend Canon Whitham of the Anglican Church's Home Mission Society, as reported in the Weekend Australian of 6-7 June 1986, said that in 85 per cent of marriage counselling cases in which his organisation was involved, overcommitment to mortgage repayments and other debts was a factor in marital breakdown. We are asserting today that Australians attempting to own their own homes are facing an enormous and increasing crisis, and the evidence is there. Not only that, but the access by young Australians to government support, if they wish to buy or own their own homes, is less now than it was. Support for home purchase has diminished markedly since the Hawke Government took office. Our first home owners scheme, the subsidy scheme which we implemented when in government, was changed substantially, and then the changed scheme was wound back. Certain housing interest payments were previously allowed to be set off against one's income, so that one got some tax relief. That scheme has now been wound back, too.

As fewer Australians can seek home ownership, more move into mobile homes or caravans. We have figures which show that the number of Australians living in caravans has increased by 100,000 to a figure of over 400,000, and that increase has occurred just in the past year. In addition, of course, more Australians are thrown onto the rental market. If they cannot own their homes, they have to seek to rent homes. If they try to rent homes, what do they find? There is less rental accommodation available; few vacancies for rental accommodation; high and rapidly increasing rents; and, not surprisingly, more and more Australian families are unable to own a home, unable to rent a home, unable to find or obtain decent homes for themselves and their children.

How do we support those assertions? We know that vacancy rates in the Sydney market as recently as August have been as low as 0.7 per cent. That is an all-time low in the availability of rental accommodation in Sydney. It is about one-quarter of what was thought to be an adequate amount of vacant rental accommodation to service the Sydney market. We know that vacancy rates for rental accommodation in Sydney, Perth, Hobart and Launceston hit an all-time low in February this year. We know that in the year between June 1985 and June this year there were 37 per cent fewer houses and 6 per cent fewer apartments advertised as being available for rental in Australia. We know that in Perth over the same period there were 41 per cent fewer apartments advertised. People looking for homes find that there are very many fewer being advertised. Not only can they not own their homes; when they come to rent, they find that rental accommodation is not available. They find, of course, that rents in Sydney have soared. I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 2 October 1986, a couple of weeks ago, which states:

Residential rents in Sydney have soared by about 20 per cent this year, and another 10 per cent hike is tipped before the end of this year. The average rental for a three-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment on the lower North Shore is around $250 a week.

Of course, not everyone has to have a house of that standard. But rents in Sydney are high and rising fast at present. As rents go up faster than prices-this is due, of course, to the shortage of accommodation-we find people's incomes being stretched even further. We know that in Hobart rents went up by 38 per cent in the year between May 1985 and May 1986. The rental crisis, brought about in part by the lack of accommodation and in part by the cost of accommodation, is very severe. It is surging ahead of the rise in prices. There are so few apartments available that in Sydney recently, when one apartment in an eastern suburb was advertised, 60 people applied to rent it. These problems are worsening rapidly, to the further disadvantage of Australians and of their families.

There is a crisis; it is a crisis which is worsening, and has worsened recently. We want the Government today to acknowledge that there is a crisis, because that is the necessary first step. Will the Government acknowledge that Australians are having trouble finding homes, finding places in which to live? If it does that, at least that is a start.

But this crisis can be associated clearly with certain policies put into place by the Hawke Government since its election 3 1/2 years ago. It is Hawke Government policies that have made home ownership in Australia more difficult. It is Hawke Government policies that have made investment in rental accommodation almost impossible. First, there was the capital gains tax. That was the tax which we were not going to get, the imposition of which represented just one of many broken promises by the Hawke Government. Secondly, there was the form of the capital gains tax, and that has driven people away from building or buying housing for rental. It has driven people to put their money into their own homes, which are free from capital gains tax. People have been upgrading their own homes, whereas previously they might have invested the same money in rental properties. It has helped to drive people towards putting money into bonds or into the money market, rather than into property for rental.

The situation was worsened further by the decision of the Hawke Labor Government to outlaw negative gearing to finance the construction or purchase of extra rental accommodation. So the crisis particularly affects the rental sector of the market. It affects the availability of rental accommodation; it affects the amount of rental accommodation; it affects the location of rental accommodation; and it affects the quality of rental accommodation.

The Government will tell us that it disapproves, on principle, of negative gearing. That is the Government's right. It said so, and it has said so often. But what it has not addressed, and what it will not address, are the consequences which flow from its decision to outlaw this form of financing for investment housing. I put it to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that this decision, like all decisions, has costs as well as benefits. Whatever ideological benefits the Government sees in outlawing negative gearing, there are costs as well. The costs have included less building for investment, less building for rental and less rental accommodation available for Australians who need it.

Frank Walker, the New South Wales Housing Minister, understands the situation that exists in New South Wales. He recognises the costs of what the Government has done. He has said so. I will quote part of an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of Friday, 10 October 1986. He talked about the unintended consequences of the Federal Government's economic policies having disastrous effects on housing. He stated:
. . . the Federal Government must urgently review its policies on interest rates and taxation that affected housing.
I am sure the Federal Government did not intend to exacerbate the housing crisis but that is what has happened.
He went on to talk about the ban on negative gearing being one of those consequences. The Housing Industry Association of Australia has said exactly the same thing.

Where does this leave Australian families? Where does it leave the dream of home ownership? Where does it leave the dreams of families wanting to live in their own homes, in their own dwellings? It is not a problem for a Minister in this Government on an income of about $100,000 a year; it is not a problem for a Labor senator who may be on a salary which is quite adequate and who has a home, anyhow; it is a problem for young Australians, unmarried people, migrants and for those who have been relocated between States; it is a problem for the poor, for Australian families and for thousands of people who cannot build, who cannot buy, who cannot rent, and who have been forgotten by the Labor Government, which has abandoned any pretence that it represents a traditional Labor constituency or traditional Labor voters. It does not represent them; it has forgotten them. This Government, by its actions-high tax, delayed benefits, broken promises, extra costs, high interests rates and national insolvency-continues to put the interests of those people at risk.

If we cannot own houses and if we cannot rent them, can we turn to public housing for relief and for decent housing? Apparently, we cannot do so with any great hope or any great effect, because another feature of Australian life during the 3 1/2 years of the Hawke Labor Government-and scarcely an achievement, might I say-is that today we have even longer and lengthening lists for public housing in Australia. Outstanding applications for public housing have increased by 50 per cent in the 3 1/2 years since Bob Hawke was elected Prime Minister. In January this year Victoria had over 33,000 outstanding applications for public housing relating to about 100,000 people.

Australia traditionally enjoyed, under Liberal and National Party governments, the world's highest rate of home ownership. We talked about little capitalists-Australia was made up of people who owned their own home-and there were about 70 per cent of them. We on this side of the House at least were proud of this fact. It is part of the Australian ethos, the aspirations of all Australians and the dreams of young Australians and their families that we own our own home, if not immediately, then some time down the track. Clearly, the achievement of this dream has been made more difficult since the advent of a Labor government in Canberra. The facts speak for themselves and I have set out some of them today. The facts represent a tragedy for individuals, families, parents and the entire Australian community and it is a tragedy compounded by the lack of rental or public accommodation on which they can fall back. Action is needed now to do something about that crisis, even from this disgraced and moribund Government, on the way out though it may be. Action is needed now to allow a start to rebuilding to make home ownership or rental possible.

This urgency motion proposes a course of action to help achieve that improvement. That action is to recognise that the Government has gone down a wrong track and to turn back from some of the taxation policies which have been so centrally responsible for the housing crisis which I have described and whose features I have set out in the last 20 minutes. Those policies have turned off access to home ownership and home rental. This should not be an issue of ideology. It is a matter of equity for Australians wanting a better life; it is a matter of a fair go for Australians wanting a house of their own, a house to rent or an apartment which they cannot get now. The way to help Australians own and occupy their homes is to restore conditions in which they will prefer to direct resources to real estate for themselves or for others rather than to place them on the money market for a quick return. We want to make it better for people to invest in the future of Australia and Australian families than for them to invest in quick cash returns. The Government must recognise the crisis and respond to it. The motion I have moved seeks the support of the Senate for action which recognises the problem and which tells us how to respond. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it amusing to say the least or ironical that the acolytes who would make the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, Prime Minister profess concern about the level of residential building activity because when John Howard was Treasurer he presided over the lowest level of residential building activity there had been since 1961. Since 1961 John Howard has held the record. The general prescription of the Opposition for overcoming Australia's economic problems, the most serious of which is our current account deficit, has three legs to it. The first is to bring back the free boozy lunch, the second is to pay pensions to millionaires and the third is to make Mercedes and even Rolls Royce cars tax deductible. In a nutshell that is the Opposition's trilogy for restoring the country to health. Precisely what linkages exist between that trilogy of policies and the current account deficit or investment in self-sustaining growth is, of course, impossible to identify.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing is very clear: The Opposition in public is against the Government's tax reform package. The Opposition has decided to opt for the strategy which Senator Messner counselled it against in September last year. Senator Messner, in a minute that was promptly leaked that night, displaying the customary teamwork, cohesion, mutual loyalty and respect which exist within the Liberal Party front bench, said that the Opposition cannot be seen to be taking all the goodies, that is, the tax cuts, and simultaneously opposing the nasties, that is, the cleaning up of the taxation base. Senator Messner said at the time that if the Opposition does that it will have resorted to opportunism, humbug and hypocrisy. That is exactly what it has done and we have heard a lot more of that humbug and hypocrisy today.

The plain fact is that the delivery of the tax cuts requires that the whole of the tax reform package be adhered to. The fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the ending of the boozy, free lunch and all of the other things have been legislated for and one cannot separate the massive cleanup of the income tax base from the tax cuts which will be delivered on 1 December this year and 1 July next year. If a government were to do what the Opposition claims should be done, that is, have no fringe benefits tax and no capital gains tax, what we would have is a massive erosion of the income tax base. In regard to the former-the fringe benefits tax-I think I can do no better than to quote John Howard in the days when he was somewhat more honest than he is now. On 11 July 1980 he said:

Fairness demands that employees who are paid solely in cash-and most Australians are-should not be asked to pay more tax, and thus effectively subsidise, those whose income is obtained partly in cash and partly in the form of valuable benefits of other kinds . . .

I do not think it can be put any better. He put it lucidly and in a moral sense. He has now completely abandoned any morality in his taxation policies. In regard to capital gains taxes and intended and unintended effects-these are phrases which seem to fascinate the Opposition-as a demonstration of one reason why it is essential to have a capital gains tax, I refer to an article written by Terry McCrann in the Melbourne Age published on 15 April this year. By no stretch of the imagination could he be regarded as an apologist for this Government. Terry McCrann set out step by step the details of a company takeover, specifically Elder Smith's takeover of Henry Jones, an arrangement or a deal over which the present Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr John Elliott, presided. I quote directly from McCrann, who stated:
Nevertheless, the fact that Elder Smith took over Henry Jones, rather than the reverse, did have some beneficial spin-offs for Mr Elliott and a number of other colleagues.
Shortly before Elder Smith unveiled its bid for Henry Jones, the leading executives in Henry Jones outlaid $19,000 in taking up 1c paid shares under an executive incentive scheme.
The Elder Smith offer delivered a clear-tax-free-profit of $4.16 million to those executives. Mr Elliott himself cleared $657,000 on a $3000 outlay.

Some people might ask some questions about company law which allows that sort of activity to take place but I do not intend to deal with that matter or pass any opinions on it. One thing of which we can be certain in the future is that if executives manage to arrange that sort of deal, which so massively advantages themselves, they will at least pay capital gains tax on it. If the Opposition had its way they would not. The Opposition wants to return to the roaring days, or the golden age, of tax evasion which John Howard presided over between 1977 and 1983. That is what the Opposition wants and that is the real reason why it does not want any fringe benefits tax or any capital gains tax. It wants to return to the roaring days, the golden age, of tax evasion over which John Howard presided between 1977 and 1983. What the country needs-even some members of the Opposition can see this-is productive business investment, that is, investment in self-sustaining economic growth. They have the right idea, but when one looks at the specifics of what they propose, instead of productive business investment which leads to self-sustaining economic growth, we have from the Opposition recommendations for the free boozy lunch being brought back, to pay pensions to millionaires and to make Mercedes and Rolls Royce cars tax deductible. This is a tax policy bereft of a capital gains tax which would encourage speculation rather than investment in self-sustaining economic growth, speculation which will bid up the price of existing assets but do little to promote investment in the economic sense.

Once we have that tax policy, of course, to cap it off the Opposition would police the system in a very slack way-that is, police the tax system in a way that allows the development of Slutzkin schemes, cherry picker schemes, art donation schemes, macadamia nut schemes and finally of course, John Howard's crowning glory, the bottom of the harbour schemes. That is the sort of tax system we had when John Howard was Treasurer and that is the sort of tax system we would have again if John Howard ever becomes Prime Minister. For at least two reasons I do not believe that John Howard ever will become Prime Minister. The first is that the Liberal Party will probably roll him from the leadership before the end of this year. The second, of course, is that the Liberal Party has a snowball's chance in hell of winning an election as long as John Howard is its leader. So I do not expect John Howard to be Prime Minister. But if by some mischance or misfortune he should be, that is the sort of tax system that we would have again-the sort of tax system over which he as Treasurer presided between 1977 and 1983.

As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed out yesterday, throughout most of the period to which I referred-that is 1977 to 1983-the Commissioner of Taxation sent a sequence of 28 increasingly frantic letters to the then Treasurer begging him to legislate before the income tax base was eroded away. A frantic letter was followed by an even more frantic letter. What did the then Treasurer do? He did nothing; he sat on his hands and did nothing. Ultimately, after about three years, he had introduced into the House what is now Part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act which, incidentally, is not foolproof. It has been got around in at least one instance already, but I will not go into that at this stage; it will be explained in debate on some subsequent legislation. Not until the scandals were exposed in the McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan reports did the then Treasurer take any action against the most blatant of the tax evaders who flourished in that period of the late 1970s and the early 1980s during which he was Treasurer and responsible for taxation policy and the administration of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

That was the former Treasurer's dealings with the last Commissioner of Taxation. Mr Howard does not seem to have had any more luck with the present Commissioner of Taxation because, although the former Treasurer refuses to say so explicitly, the only way in which an Opposition tax policy regarding fringe benefits could have any superficial credibility would be if the Opposition were committed to the effective enforcement of section 26(e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Mr Howard will not say that; of course, he will not say that for very good reasons. If he were to admit that that is what he thinks should be done, it raises the question of for how far back would Mr Howard enforce the existing Act. Mr Howard, having implicitly declared that section 26(e) is enforceable, would be obliged morally and legally to enforce it for at least some years into the past-I would suggest some five to seven years. That is the secret agenda of the Liberal Party. That is its secret tax policy which it is not going to unveil because it would frighten too many people who would not know for how many years they would receive backdated assessments for income evaded under section 26(e) of the existing Income Tax Assessment Act. The Government does not believe that section 26(e) can be enforced and that is why it decided to introduce new legislation for the taxing of fringe benefits. That Government's view is the view of many members of the Opposition. Mr Sinclair, Mr Hunt, Sir William Knox and even Senator Bjelke-Petersen have all expressed the view that section 26(e) should be enforced. Mr Howard has not publicly endorsed that view but they have said publicly that the enforcement of section 26(e) would take care of abuses of fringe benefits.
Today's Australian Financial Review contains an article which states:

. . . during a speech in Sydney yesterday, the present Tax Commissioner, Mr Trevor Boucher embarrassed the Opposition further with an attack on the methods the Coalition is promoting as an alternative to the Government's fringe benefits tax.
Mr Boucher said, of section 26(e) of the Tax Act which the Opposition believes it could rely on-
this is a quotation from Mr Boucher-

`. . . Anyone who would say that all that is needed is a return to application of the old law is either ignoring history or has a poor memory, not to speak of a lack of appreciation of the technical inadequacies in that law.'

So poor Mr Howard has not had much luck with Tax Commissioners, past or present. The last Tax Commissioner-fortunately for the Tax Commissioner and unfortunately for Mr Howard-left on the record the 28 increasingly desperate letters which he wrote to Mr Howard as Treasurer, increasingly frantic letters saying: `Legislate-you must legislate in order to stop the further erosion of the income tax base. Legislate against the sorts of schemes that were being organised by people like Brian Maher, who is now in the slammer, and a few other people who ought to be and, of course, exploited up to the hilt by a number of prominent Liberals, particularly in Western Australia.'

It is highly significant that of the 15 members of the Liberal Party finance committee in Western Australia, no fewer than five of them flogged off companies to Brian Maher's agents under what were clearly dodgy circumstances. In other words, they flogged off companies which owned nothing but money, that had no assets but money and contingent tax liabilities in the case of Tremog Ltd of $1.7m. They flogged them off for much more than they were worth once the tax liability had been taken into account, not as going businesses but as shell companies which owned nothing but money. Blind Freddy-even an accountant like Senator Watson-could have told us that those deals were shonky. Tremog was controlled by the chairman of the Liberal Party's finance committee in Western Australia at the time. He personally gained from that deal alone around $600,000 which was effectively stolen from the taxpayers of Australia. That is the sort of thing that Mr Howard presided over.

We can catch people and ensure that it does not happen again in one of two ways. The first way, of course, is the credible threat of retrospective legislation. While that unholy alliance of about half the Australian Democrats and the tax evader supporters in the Liberal and Country parties has half the numbers in the Senate-I forgot to add Senator Harradine in that unholy coalition-that route is not viable. The other route is to have a proper capital gains tax which will ensure that if people do not pay tax on that sort of income derived from fraudulent activity under the income tax Act or under tax applied on what is normally in law regarded as income, they will pay it on capital gains. That is why this legislation is essential. It is also essential, of course, for a number of other reasons that I mentioned earlier.

The absence of a capital gains tax in Australia has been a major cause not only of the present plight of the agricultural sector-a matter on which I have spoken a number of times-but also of the long term malaise of the Australian economy. The tax system has been designed in such a way that what was encouraged was not investment in an economic sense-that is, investment of the type which will generate employment and self-sustaining and expanding economic growth-but speculation. What was encouraged was not economic investment but speculation, directing money, because of the tax system, towards bidding up the price of existing assets instead of it being invested in self-sustaining economic growth. If the tax system, bereft of a capital gains tax, which Australia has not had until now, was so successful at promoting investment, the question must be asked: Why, then, on an almost continuous basis since the end of World War II, has the Australian economy performed worse than the economies of most comparable countries? Why has productivity growth in Australia over the last 10 years been particularly low? Why has investment in Australia over the last 10 years or longer been particularly low? All of that happened under the tax systems which the Opposition would have us resurrect. It failed then and it will fail again.

The sort of tax system the Opposition wants, as I said before, is the sort of tax system which produced Slutzkin schemes, cherry picker schemes, art donation schemes, macadamia nut schemes and, finally, bottom of the harbour schemes. They are the results of John Howard's taxation policy, the sorts of policies which the Opposition wants to bring back. If people cannot see what is intrinsically or logically wrong with that sort of taxation system, I ask them to look at the results. What did John Howard's taxation system finally produce? It produced the biggest economic crash that Australia has seen since 1930.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today an urgency motion which I must say I find rather extraordinarily worded, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to abandon its anti-investment taxation measures, particularly the capital gains tax, which have created the housing crisis presently facing Australian families.

It seems to me as though a Liberal Party committee got together, could not decide whether we ought to be debating the taxation measures introduced by this Government or the housing crisis, decided to put them together and then, rather extraordinarily, emphasised the impact or alleged impact of the capital gains tax on the housing crisis. I could have understood it if it had chosen to have a hack at the consequences or alleged consequences of negative gearing on the problems facing Australian families in acquiring housing, but to lay the emphasis on the mild form of capital gains tax that we currently have in this country is rather extraordinary. But then, the motion comes from a party which does not have a tax policy anyway, so perhaps it is not surprising.

Certainly there is a housing crisis. Senator Peter Baume is perfectly correct in his assertion that there is a very real problem facing Australian families as far as access to housing is concerned, whether that is housing ownership or access to rental, whether it is private or public housing that we are looking at. But the crisis is a continuing one; it is not one which has suddenly sprung up overnight or even in the last year to two. Repossessions, which Senator Baume mentioned, are not something new in 1986. They have been a continuing problem and one which I, and indeed many young couples, remember well from the last years of the Fraser Government in the early 1980s, when escalating interest rates then were the cause of a lot of people having to sell their homes because they simply could not afford the increase in mortgage repayments. That was occurring in days when there was no capital gains tax and when negative gearing was rife. So the logic of arguing that there is somehow a connection between the introduction of the particularly mild form of capital gains tax that we have and an end to tax rorts and the housing crisis, is a rather peculiar one even for this Opposition.

Certainly the argument that the capital gains tax has caused the housing crisis is rather novel. As I said a moment ago, I could have understood it if the question of negative gearing had been raised, because there was an argument put last year, in a number of submissions to us and in a number of letters to editors and so on, that the removal of negative gearing was going to have a dramatic impact on the availability of residential housing. We were not particularly persuaded by the arguments, for a number of reasons. First of all, while there was a claim that negative gearing was going to bring on an immediate and permanent crisis in rental accommodation, the industries involved, that is, the investment and real estate industries, did not come up with particularly persuasive figures. In fact, it is difficult to determine whether negative gearing was keeping rentals low by subsidising landlords and encouraging construction of rental accommodation, or whether the reverse was the fact, that indeed negative gearing, by increasing the attractiveness of investment in rental accommodation had so increased the competitiveness for limited rental housing stock that purchase prices and rents were as a consequence increasing.

However, even if the first argument is the correct one-that is, that negative gearing did increase the amount of rental accommodation available and did result in decreased rents-the question has to be asked whether that is an appropriate way of making sure that appropriate, adequate and affordable housing is available to those who want it. Certainly we, and a number of other organisations, including a number of welfare groups, did not believe that that was so. Negative gearing, of course, amounts to a subsidy paid by the ordinary pay as you earn taxpayer to an investor who has purchased negatively geared property. The investor may pass on some of that subsidy by way of lower rental, but all too frequently the lion's share of that taxpayer's subsidised assistance is retained by the investor in the form of tax exempt income. It is as simple as that.

It seems to me that a far more efficient means of providing rental accommodation in particular to those who are least able to compete on the open market would be to increase the amount of funding available for public rental accommodation; that is, we believe the assistance should go to the needy directly rather than via government subsidies to the people who own the properties-subsidise the user rather than the provider. The other alternative, of course, is to increase government expenditure on the provision of public housing or public rental accommodation. Furthermore, as has already been recognised in other countries, there is far more equity in the argument that tax deductions should be allowable for the owners of homes so that they can reduce the cost of their high interest mortgage repayments than in the argument for giving a tax deduction to absentee landlords through negative gearing.

As far as the capital gains tax is concerned, an argument can, I suppose, be made that capital gains taxes marginally decrease the attractiveness of investment in housing other than the family home. The effect of that particular tax on investment in housing has, however, we submit, been significantly overstated, for the obvious reason that it is not levied on that portion of the profits attributable to inflation, unlike, I might add, the American tax system which the Opposition appears to think so highly of and which, indeed, in this case makes no allowance for inflation and taxes nominal profit in a way in which the Australian capital gains tax does not. It is a much harsher tax applying in the United States than now applies in Australia, as Ross Gittins pointed out in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald a little less than a month ago. He pointed out that in the United States the tax on capital gains will be much tougher. He said:
At present, you only pay tax on 40 per cent of your capital gain, at a maximum rate of 20 per cent.

Under the scheme that was being discussed in the United States at the time Ross Gittins wrote this article, a person would pay tax on 100 per cent of the gain at a maximum rate of 33 per cent, or 34 per cent for companies. He said:
Our new capital gains tax will be levied at a maximum rate of 49 per cent, but we only pay tax on the real gain. The new US system makes no allowance for inflation, so it is much tougher than ours.

Certainly, there has been an unnecessary amount of outrage over the capital gains tax that the Australian Government is now applying. I for one cannot see that it will have a dramatic impact on the availability of housing in this country. We argued throughout the tax debate that a capital gains tax was both necessary and equitable, there being no argument in equity, for example, for someone being able to earn income by means of a capital gains having put no effort of his own into it while people who receive their income through salaries or wages have to pay tax at a variety of marginal rates. Those who are suffering due to the housing crisis over which the Opposition is weeping today fall into the category of people who do, in fact, pay the full tax on salaries and wages, that is, ordinary taxpayers on low or very moderate incomes. They are not into the business of negatively gearing and they are certainly not much into capital gains tax exempt situations. As far as economic efficiency is concerned, the absence of a capital gains tax distorts economic activity by encouraging investment in property rather than in income producing activities necessary to generate new industries and hence to increase employment. So there is, if you like, a double whammy by allowing that sort of tax exemption to exist.

As I said a moment ago, we certainly agree with Senator Peter Baume and with that part of the Opposition's motion which states that there is a housing crisis presently facing Australian families. But it is not a crisis which is totally attributable to this Government's tax policies because it did not commence with the Hawke Government taking office. In fact, it has existed for decades. If one looks at figures for 1981-82, the last full year during which the Opposition was in government, we find that a very similar housing crisis existed. Outstanding State housing authority applications for rental accommodation stood, for example, at nearly 110,000. The amount of money provided to the States for the provision of public housing in that same year was only $255m-$150m less than four years previously and $240m less than the amount provided by the Hawke Government last year. If one looks at Commonwealth funding for public housing over the full period of the Fraser Government the funding fell from $800m to $300m in constant 1984-85 prices. There was no expression of concern by the Liberal Party then as far as housing or a housing crisis was concerned. Perhaps the answer lies in the fact that it is not really interested in public housing or in providing housing accommodation for those people who are on low incomes. What it is really interested in is returning a number of tax rorts to those people who are better off than most in the community.

The picture as far as private housing is concerned is not much different from that relating to public housing. As the available statistics indicate, during the last two years of the Fraser Government dwelling approvals were in the vicinity of 139,000 and 116,000 respectively, whereas in 1985-86 they were in excess of 140,000-not much of an increase, but something of an increase. If one looks at lending for housing, the amounts for 1981-82 and 1982-83 were $6.5 billion and $7.1 billion respectively, while the figure for 1985-86 was $11.5 billion, which represents, I suggest, a significant increase even after allowance is made for inflation.

However, there is no solace in the fact that the housing crisis is not the product of this Government's policies or actions. It is there and something needs to be done about it, but giving tax incentives via negative gearing or tax free capital gains is not the answer. Instead, there needs to be a massive injection of capital into housing, both public and private, and a reduction in housing loan interest rates. It was ludicrous that with the support of this Opposition the Government was earlier in the year able to buy off the banking sector to the tune of several hundred million dollars at a time when the banks were making record profits in order to stop them from increasing existing housing interest rates from 13.5 per cent to 15.5 per cent which they were going to apply to new loans. Those sorts of interest rates are almost impossible for the average Australian family to contend with comfortably and still live reasonably well on the money they have left over from their salaries or wages.

We acknowledge that there is a housing crisis. We dispute that it has been caused by any of this Government's tax reform measures, in particular a capital gains tax. We argue that it is, in fact, the legacy of previous governments assisting speculators rather than users, and we say that it will not be eliminated until the Government ensures that sufficient public housing is available to those whose income is too low to make purchase feasible and that interest rates are affordable for those who want to fulfil the dream, which Senator Peter Baume mentioned several times during his speech, of home ownership in its own right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating this issue, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, despite his usual vitriol, deliberately avoided dealing with the question of housing and in effect pleaded no contest. One can understand why he left the chamber shortly thereafter. I address what is one of the most enduring economic and social tragedies currently besetting thousands of Australians, that is, the acute shortage of housing and accommodation stock. I think we are all aware of the plight of the homeless in Australia. Not to have a roof over one's head must be the height of social dislocation and the product of a great deal of alienation, and no doubt leads to very many of the problems that confront young people and others, especially first home buyers. In many ways a home of one's own is the ultimate security blanket but it is not to be disparaged; it has always been regarded as the great Australian dream. Unfortunately, it is now rapidly fading into a mirage. If we seek to analyse why this is, unfortunately it seems to be for all the right reasons. I refer to what Mr Frank Walker, the New South Wales Socialist Left Housing Minister, had to say. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The `unintended consequences' of the Federal Government's economic policies are having disastrous effects on housing in NSW.
He was speaking only a matter of days ago. He said:

I am sure the Federal Government did not intend to exacerbate the housing crisis, but that is what has happened . . . the Federal Government's decision six months ago to deregulate interest rates on new lending for housing had done little to ease the housing shortage.
He might be interested to know that the Brotherhood of St Laurence disagrees with him. It says that that has been one of the few benefits that have flowed from that decision. Mr Walker went on:
The abolition of negative gearing and introduction of a 4 per cent depreciation allowance on new private rental accommodation had failed to generate significant new development.

He wants an increase from 4 per cent to 8 per cent in the depreciation allowance, which is an initiative supported by the Housing Industry Association of Australia but is one which seems not to have found any favour with the Federal Government. He further called for an urgent review of the first home owners scheme. Finally, he said that building society lending had dropped by 35 per cent and that the waiting list for public housing in New South Wales stood at more than 57,000. So it it pretty clear even from the words of one of the Federal Government's ideological compatriots that housing is in a disastrous state. It is a classic case of unintended consequences and a case study in the perils of ideological politics.

Setting out to change the social landscape without regard to the economic implications can lead to very many blind alleys. In this instance, the problem seems to have flowed from a determination not to see the big picture, just the little issues-rich landlords, greedy investors, filthy profit-makers, `renteers' and avaricious banks. These are all part of the demonology, but they are not the real problem. The real problem is that the Government did not get its Budget strategy right.
