Housing is not a problem if one has a $17,000 travel allowance which will enable rent on one's property in Canberra to be paid whilst one's three-storey terrace in Elizabeth Bay is being renovated, but it certainly is a problem for many thousands of ordinary Australians.

The Government by its actions clearly no longer has a commitment, if it ever did, to meeting the very real emotional and social needs of so many Australians who have a belief in this country's future and want to own their own homes. Senator Walsh talked as though he sometimes reads Terry McCrann. Perhaps he does so for the wrong reasons, because he seems to delight in reading about dry and wet Slutzkin schemes and so on. But he really has not read much of what McCrann says about the social implications of some of the Budget decisions. For instance, it is quite clear that if the Government had paid attention to the real underlying financial difficulties it would have introduced a Budget which made some economic sense and did not simply have the grossly unintended consequences that we are now facing in the housing area.

We have seen the concentration on the accord, the determination to pass on wage increases irrespective of capacity to pay and the determination to achieve a beads and mirrors Budget deficit of $3.5 billion. That figure was achieved at a very great cost. It was achieved by gathering in the order of $1.4 billion in additional revenue, by currency speculation windfalls of about $600m, by deferring pension increases and by deferring the elimination of poverty traps. These are all measures which are the last things required at present. It does not need to be said that if the Government had had the courage and gumption to do what both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) now wistfully wish they had done-to have adopted option C-they would not be confronted with all these desperate measures which are clearly designed to increase revenue rather than cut expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —That shows ignorance. You don't know what is in option C.

—The aspect of option C relating to an increase in the indirect tax base could easily have been dealt with in isolation from all those other items that the Government finds it necessary to maintain because it insists on spending well beyond its means. Again, that choice seems to have been put in the too-hard basket.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal with some aspects of poverty which really are critical at present. If one applies the Henderson poverty line test which was enunciated more than a decade ago, one finds that it is necessary to have an income after tax of $246.60 for the average house with husband, wife and two children. That assumes accommodation expenses of about $55 a week. The reality, as we know, is nothing like that. It is almost impossible to find rental accommodation anywhere at that price. People who own their own homes are less likely to live in poverty than are rent-paying tenants on the same income. For the majority of Australian families, housing is the most important asset and the biggest single investment decision.

In the Government's commissioned study by the Department of Housing and Construction into homelessness and inadequate housing we find that in Australia there are as many as 100,000 people without secure housing-that is, homeless-and 700,000 families who have incomes below the poverty line after they have paid for their housing. I can do no better than quote the shadow Treasurer, Jim Carlton, who says:

The report highlights the contradiction inherent in the Government's objectives of providing income relief and rental assistance to low income earners while at the same time pursuing taxation measures and high interest rate policies which will force rents up and mortgage repayments up.

There is the crux of the problem. If there is to be any hope of people being able to buy their own homes, the level of interest rates obviously is critical. I applaud the Government's partial decision to free up home interest rates. Those seeking first mortgages are paying interest rates in the order of 15.5 per cent. One would have thought that that was a little beyond the reach of very many of those people who could be described as being in the lower income brackets. The problem of poverty is acute. It is compounded by the difficulties of owning one's own home. Perhaps that will not be achieved by most of those people in their lifetimes. In Australian Society of February 1986 a report of the Social Welfare Research Centre said:

The problem of poverty after housing cost cannot be reduced to a simple choice between raising rental assistance to recipients of social security payments and building more dwellings for rent by local authorities . . . This ignores the fact that more than a quarter of the families involved are purchasing their own dwellings.

Again, simply to penalise those who are in the process of buying their own homes, on the basis that they can well afford to maintain increased mortgage payments, ignores the reality of the difficulties they face.

I now turn to what, in effect, are the six major reasons why one can say that the effect of the Government's taxation and financial policies has been a critical housing shortage in this country. Despite the studied ignorance of the Australian Democrats, the capital gains tax is a very real problem. The fact is that prior to its introduction any person who bought an investment property for the purpose of gaining assess- able income-by that I mean making it available to tenants, receiving rent, declaring that as income and paying tax on it-did not then pay any tax on the profit that was derived from the sale of that property. That is no longer the case. We are now looking at paying 49c in the dollar on the real increase in profit. It is fatuous to compare that with the United States system. We are comparing that with the previous situation in Australia when investors had an incentive to purchase, were prepared to do so and were not frightened off. Now it simply is not worth their while.

Apart from the capital gains tax, which my colleague Senator Peter Baume rightly pointed out has led to people simply preferring to put their money into the matrimonial home as the last great tax haven, high interest rates are a crippling disincentive. The abolition of negative gearing and the ineffective 4 per cent depreciation allowance have resulted in the Master Builders Association survey showing that there has been a surge in housing rents since the tax reforms have been introduced. It is quite clear that investors have found it necessary to raise rents to maintain investment yield. If they do not do that, they sell out altogether. Landlords simply are not interested in being hemmed in by all sorts of government restrictions and regulations on their investments. If they sell to those who want to own their own homes, that leads to an even more acute shortage of rental stock.

The problems are compounded by State regulations. The New South Wales Government is hell-bent on introducing a whole range of rental controls which will make life intolerable. The Residential Tenancies Act in Victoria will have the same effect. These matters cannot be ignored and treated as State issues because they are impacted upon by Federal initiatives. A high rate of return is available to investors elsewhere in so many fascinating financial instruments. There is a veritable smorgasbord of financial trusts and alternative investments. Why should anyone get into housing stock as an investment? In light of the present uncertain economic outlook, it is quite clear why people are shying away from investing in housing.

The three growth areas to which one can point-it is really not a matter of great pride-include, firstly, the luxury market. In New South Wales, for instance, it is quite possible to rent a penthouse at Circular Quay for $2,500 a week. Large corporations are falling over themselves to pay up to $4,000 a week for city apartments. The top of the range properties in Sydney's eastern suburbs are commanding rentals of $3,000 to $3,500 a week. The Federal Opposition Shadow Minister has drawn attention to another growth area-caravans and mobile homes. It is clear from the investigations that have been carried out into that phenomenon that there has been a dramatic increase of something like 100,000 in the last 12 months to the current figure of 400,000. As a result of the relaxation of Foreign Investment Review Board controls on real estate, there has been an explosion in the commercial investment area.

None of this has anything to do with the provision of housing for those who really need it. None of it has anything to do with coping with the fundamental problem, that is, restructuring the Budget and bringing back the incentive for people to purchase housing. None of it tackles the Budget questions this Government has studiously ignored. The tunnel vision approach the Government now adopts shows that it is all too hard and too late. The Government simply is not prepared to move away from a system that requires it to maintain a whole range of taxes which have not served Australia well, which have punished unmercifully those who would like to have housing of their own and which will do nothing in the longer term to restore the balance which is so desperately needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume's motion typifies basic Liberal philosophy. It points to the difference between the two parties. Senator Baume's suggestion to abandon the capital gains tax is an affirmation of his belief in the trickle-down theory that is so common to pretty well all members of the Liberal Party. That theory is that if the wealthy get a tax break or an advantage not available to the great majority, all we have to do is hope, pray and have faith that they might just let a little of that advantage trickle down to the poor, to those at the bottom end. The theory ignores the logic that for that to happen, the poor, the ordinary Australians, have to pay a higher tax burden just to give a tax break in the first place to the wealthy few. That is the system the Liberal Party encouraged when in government and which it now says it wants to go back to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party, since its election to government, has made one of its first priorities a campaign to introduce fairness and equity to the tax system. Fairness and equity are foreign words on the other side of the House. They are not just words but principles to which those on this side of the House are committed. We do not have the interests of just a few at heart; we want to try to look after the vast majority of ordinary Australians. The reality is that those in our community who have a vested interest in getting rid of the capital gains tax try to do so by masquerading and camouflaging their real beliefs behind a veneer of social concern. That veneer is so shallow and thin that it takes in no one.

Let us consider the tax reform measures we introduced during the last years that can impact upon the housing sector. We abolished the quarantining of negative gearing-not, I hasten to add, any retrospective abolition. We introduced a four per cent depreciation allowance on new rental accommodation and the capital gains tax. The Government's capital gains tax and negative gearing decisions undoubtedly will introduce some of the fairness, equity and efficiency into the tax system I mentioned earlier. They will ensure a more equitable treatment of taxpayers, regardless of the form in which they obtain their income, and they will ensure that investment will take place in the areas of the highest social return, rather than just the most lucrative tax concession areas, as has been the case for years. The reduction of the tax advantages associated with negative gearing, therefore, have to make the tax system fairer.

The number of high income taxpayers who exploited this feature of the tax system over the years was growing. To minimise their tax liability negative gearing became the order of the day. The Government, in wanting to introduce fairness and equity, did not abolish those privileges. It set a date in 1985 and said that everything before that day would remain as it was because it did not seek to affect people who had planned their lives and incomes around the existing situation. The Government did not make the law retrospective. However, we said that from that day forward we would stop negative gearing. In the end, one has to remember two things about the rental market: First, a great part of it is not negatively geared and, therefore, this decision has no effect on it. Secondly, and more importantly, because the part of it that is negatively geared was overwhelming negatively geared prior to July of last year, it makes no difference anyway. So those decisions did not affect it.

The capital gains tax is hardly a new radical tax introduced by an ultra-socialist government in Australia. Most countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and most of the top nations in the world, even the top 20, have a capital gains tax. It is common everywhere else. It was held back in Australia because for years we had governments, run by the Liberal and National parties, who wanted to protect the wealthy. Even countries such as the United States, which I will get to later, the bastion of free enterprise and capitalism, have capital gains taxes. The capital gains tax was and is secretly supported by so many people on the other side. It is just that for political considerations they do not want to admit it at the moment. I will take them through some of their previous statements a little later if they are patient enough to wait.

As well as granting a complete exemption for the taxpayer's principal residence, the capital gains tax was also made fully prospective. It was never made retrospective, so it cannot therefore have an effect on places bought and sold prior to the specified date. Most importantly, the tax is only on the real gain, not on the nominal gain as it is in so many countries. It does not affect the family home, which is the major factor in the housing industry. It is the area where housing industry activity is best and most often judged. It affects properties acquired only after 19 September 1985. The four per cent depreciation allowance will encourage funds into the construction of new private rental housing. It will also fund capital improvement to existing rental properties. So it should provide over time a boon to the industry, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) outlined when he made the announcement in the first place. More importantly, the impact on rents and the supply of rental housing will be gradual. It will take place over time. It will not happen straight away.

Let us consider other factors that affect rent increases. One does not have to look to Labor Party sources. The Master Builders Association, hardly a Labor Party front, says that prospective changes in tenancy laws in Sydney and Melbourne are important factors in rent increases. They are State matters. They are not matters over which this Parliament has any power. Anti-landlord legislation, as it is termed by the Master Builders Association, is causing landlords the most concern. I can understand that. I have tried for years to agree with something that Senator Baume said. I have to confess that I have found something today. There is no doubt, and we certainly do not pretend, that interest rates do not impact upon the housing industry. Obviously, there have been increases in interest rates in recent times. Fortunately, the signs in recent weeks have been that the increases are starting to drop-off. The Executive Director of the Real Estate Institute, Mr Phil Roberts, has said that pressures compounded by interest rates being too high are forcing buyers to remain in the rental market, rather than back out.

In terms of what the Government says about interest rates, the Liberal Party, the Real Estate Institute and the Master Builders Association can all rest easy tonight because we have put in place policies which will ensure a gradual fall in interest rates over time. The signs are there already. The pressure is off interest rates now. We are starting to see a gradual reduction. If we monitor that position over time, when we redebate the matter, perhaps in a year's time, we on this side of the House will be more than proud of our performance.

In trying to ascertain the sort of response one should give to a resolution that calls for the abandonment of the capital gains tax, one has to look at the alternative-the Liberal Party's position. As always, on any tax matter, precious little information has been provided to us so that we can find that out. The Australian people have Buckley's chance of finding out. It is left to us to try to ferret out some information for the Australian people. We need do no more than look at the performance of John Howard, the current Leader. When he left office, taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product, was higher than when he came into government in 1975. All he did was to preside over seven Budgets and, at the end of that period, ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers were paying more. That is a matter of record and nobody can argue with that.

But we have to go further and look at what John Howard says and thinks about this whole matter of tax. As I mentioned last week and as I have said many times in this respect, it was Commissioner Costigan who really said it all about the Liberal Party's record on tax, when he said that the only growth industry-I think he compared its growth to the heady days of the Victorian goldrush-that actually existed within the period of Liberal government was the tax avoidance industry because there was no inclination or determination on the part of the Liberal Party Government to do anything at all about tax avoidance.

That is an assessment that I noted yesterday caused something of a furore in another place, but the facts are that the protection afforded to so many people involved in illegal tax activities over time meant that that industry grew and grew. It was left to Paul Keating and to Bob Hawke to do something about it, which they have. The capital gains tax is just another step along that road to eliminating all the loopholes and the rorts to make sure that everyone pays a fair share of taxation. It is interesting to note what John Howard has said about the capital gains tax because his position on that is a little bit cloudy. I would like to take honourable senators back to 29 September 1986 when he said that, as far as he was concerned:
I'm very attracted to what Reagan has done. What Reagan is doing is being examined very closely as part of developing our own tax policy.

It must be a close examination because it has taken so long. He wants to go along the road of President Reagan. He is looking at the model of the United States of America, so let us look at some features of the United States model that Mr Howard finds so attractive. The United States model, if we can call it that-I hesitate to use the words-includes a retrospective capital gains tax on the full nominal gain. We have to ask ourselves if that is what attracts John Howard, because when we look at some of his other statements it may well be that that is the attraction. That is what he said in September 1986. On 24 August 1984, when asked about the desirability of a capital gains tax-this is a classic answer-he said:
I think I was asked at the last National Press Club luncheon the same question and I said then that there are arguments within a total restructuring of the system for what you have said.

In short, in 1984 John Howard said that there were arguments to support a capital gains tax. When he became Leader of the Opposition he recanted and said: `No, we will not have a capital gains tax'. Fortunately, the Australian people will not be in the position of having him as Prime Minister to see what he would do then, but if ever that happened, God forbid, my rough guess is that straightaway he would change his mind again. The capital gains tax will stay for decades to come, no matter who governs this country. Why? Because it is fair and equitable, it is in place and it is one of those things about which John Valder said: `We hope that the Labor Party does all the difficult things so that if we ever get back, we will not have to'. John Howard's record on capital gains goes up and down, just like the polls.

The Opposition does not know where it stands on tax policy. It does not know what it is saying. The capital gains tax exists in practically every other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country-the wealthy are called upon to pay a reasonable share of the burden. In the United States of America-the bastion of capitalism and free enterprise-there is a capital gains tax at a full rate on the nominal gain, and it is retrospective. In the Labor Party we do not intend to do anything like that. We do not need to. But as part of an overall review, in the coming years we will make sure that the system gets fairer and fairer, that everyone pays a burden and that no one is able to opt out by rorts or by paying batteries of smart accountants and smart lawyers to get them off their taxation obligations. Under this Government everyone will pay a fair share. By the end of the next four to five years of this Government, we will see a tax system that works better, is more efficient and, most importantly, is fair to all Australians and is equitable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to rise to support this motion. It is a matter of grave concern to the whole nation, but from listening to the representatives from the Government bench this evening, one would not think that there was a crisis in the housing industry at all. First of all, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) I think failed to mention the housing industry at all.
—Not once.

—Not once. Thank you, Senator Peter Baume. Now we have just had a flourish around the taxation system from Senator Richardson, who tried to convince us of the purity of his Government's heart. Unfortunately, as in most cases when it comes to this Government's tax package, it may have been well-intentioned, but the Government has made an awful muck-up of things. We are now dealing constantly with unintended consequences. On this side we certainly do have a fascination for that phrase because it is one that the Government seems to have to use every time something is brought to its attention. I cannot quite make up my mind whether it is a malevolent government or whether it just consists of bumbling idiots, but one way or another it certainly is having a major impact on the whole nation. One would not expect our side of politics to be continually quoting the Labor Minister for Housing in New South Wales, but once again I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that Mr Walker has condemned his Federal colleagues for exacerbating the housing crisis. He has said that `the Federal Government must urgently review its policies on interest rates and taxation that affect housing' and that `unless they change course, they will lose government'. I would be very glad to see Labor lose government but that will not help the people who are in the housing crisis in Australia today.

SPEECH.PARA: This Australian Government is so obsessed with catching fat cats that there are unintended consequences in everything it does. It is placing an intolerable burden on people trying to set up a home for themselves and their families and it is putting people out of work in the domestic building industry. A submission was given to this Government in April this year by all the States and the Northern Territory called `Housing-the Other Australia'. That submission drew attention to the growing number of people facing a housing crisis. Those governments are aware of it, even if this Government is not. Those people are either homeless, inadequately housed, or paying a disproportionate amount of their income on high rents or mortgages. In this country, we have 40,000 people with no secure housing who sleep out of doors or in refuges. We have another 60,000 people on the verge of homelessness who are dependent on government resources. Over 700,000 households are below the poverty line after paying their rent or mortgage costs.

The waiting list for public housing was 146,000 in June 1985 and the submission estimated that, unless the Federal Government gave $1000m in this Budget, waiting times on that public waiting list would grow. The Government did not give that money. It provided $693m, about $300m short of the required level to keep those people on the public waiting list from slipping back. Why is that so important to this debate? The reason is that increasing numbers of people who in the past would have wanted to rent privately are being forced on to public lists. So these tax measures are affecting the public housing lists as well. They are affecting them in another way: State governments are compelled to enter the commercial markets with high rates of interest to help to subsidise a growing percentage of their tenants who need rent rebates. So in a number of different ways this Government's handling of the economy is making not just those in the private rental market and the private housing industry suffer; it is making the public housing industry feel the pinch as well. That sets the scene.

Australians wanting to own their own home in Australia today should beware that the capital gains tax does not give all the exemptions it sounds as if it might. Some one running a hairdressing business from home, selling goods from home or practising a trade or profession from home will not receive a capital gains tax exemption. The capital gains tax will apply to a new family home purchased by a young couple while they are still living with their parents, before marriage. It will also apply to a young couple who are renting and who purchase a block of land for their family home and then take some time to build their home. The exemption is available only if upon completion of the new home it is occupied for at least 12 months. We all know that this is a mobile society. If people are posted away they lose capital gains tax exemption for their new home. If people are building themselves, are not saving fast enough and the time lapse between the acquisition and the occupation of their new home exceeds four years, the tax will have to be paid on their home on a pro rata basis.

If either of the parties has any interest in a matrimonial home that is the subject of a dispute in the Family Court of Australia, or if both of them have, further problems will arise in relation to the capital gains tax. Many families these days like to buy a few acres of land on the edge of town on which to put their home. If a family home is built on a block of more than two hectares it is subject to capital gains tax. Old people who take a unit or flat in a retirement village may not be exempt from paying capital gains tax either unless they have a title, a lease or shares in the owning company. Many retirement villages do not grant such rights to ownership.

Terry McCrann is no friend of this Government but he recently spelled out what happens in the United States of America. A person on the average wage needs to earn something like an extra $4,500 each year to meet the annual interest payment on a $50,000 home loan. In Australia such a person would need to earn an extra $14,500 to meet the interest bill-on a modest home. I think that says a lot about where this country is going for young home owners. There are a couple of reasons for that. In the United States interest rates are around 9 per cent compared with 15.5 per cent for new home loans in Australia. But also, in the United States interest payments on homes are tax deductible.

I turn now to people wanting to rent homes. The Government's new measures have meant increased rents as investors try to recoup the tax. My colleagues Senator Peter Baume and Senator Alston have already referred to this. This is terribly important in Australia because 80 per cent of people who rent housing do so from the private sector. These measures are having and will increasingly have major impact on many Australians. So when Government members talk about taxing the fat cats and cutting down the tall poppies they must remember whom they are cutting down at the same time-the people who want to rent private houses. What is available now is coming to be in short supply, and the lists of those waiting for housing are increasing. My colleagues have covered that fairly thoroughly this afternoon. Rents have increased already in the capital cities of Australia and they are predicted to rise yet again. Once again, this affects the people who are least able to afford the rises. We hear the Australian Labor Party continually saying that it is the friend of the disadvantaged. It has a very funny way of showing it. I fear that the Labor Party must be economically illiterate, as I said before.

The Real Estate Institute of Australia, in its monthly survey of Australian residential property markets, reported that the vacancy rate was a very tight 0.7 per cent. The Institute's Executive Director, Mr Phil Roberts, said:
This is the lowest figure recorded for Sydney since the surveys began some 10 years ago.
He went on to say:
But Sydney's figure shows a strong demand for rental accommodation, the potential for considerable hardship for some tenants and a crying need for urgent remedial action.

He said that Sydney's tight rental market resulted from a number of factors, as Senator Richardson mentioned earlier, but that high amongst them was the buffeting property investors had taken over the past 18 months. That situation applies not just in Sydney, where there is a Labor government which is out to get the people who are prepared to invest their life savings in real estate for letting. In my home city of Launceston, which is not such a high market area for purchase and rental of property, the Launceston Women's Shelter, with which I am associated, used to be able to get people on to public accommodation lists which last year involved a wait of 15 months. The wait is now 18 to 24 months. On the private market, a family wanting to rent a three-bedroom cottage-not a grand one-six months ago was asked to pay $75 to $90 a week. Such people are now expecting to have to pay $100 to $130 a week. That is what has happened because of the reduction of investors thanks to this Government's taxation and high interest policies. The combination has been disastrous for the people dependent on the rental market.

That is not all that has been affected by these measures. We must not forget the employment consequences. There are over 800,000 businesses in Australia. Ninety-eight per cent of them are small businesses and 64.6 per cent of employees in small businesses in Australia are employed in the construction industry. So when this Government takes action that it thinks is affecting the tall poppies let it remember the building workers at the end of the line. The measures that this Government has taken have led to a virtual closing down of construction for the private rental market. Mr Bill Kirkby-Jones, the Managing Director of the Housing Industry Association of Australia, has said that small investors have deserted the market in droves. The introduction of the 4 per cent depreciation allowance was thought by the Government to go some way towards helping to offset the negative gearing provisions introduced last year. It has been insignificant. It is quite clear that it was not enough to keep people in the market. The latest housing figures show that total dwelling approvals for August fell by over 11 per cent on the figures for July on a seasonally adjusted basis. It is now clear that the recent Indicative Planning Council forecast of 122,500 starts for 1986-87 is in serious jeopardy. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, promised 135,000 starts as recently as April this year. That is a good indication that this Government does not know the impact of its measures. Sadly, what money is going into housing very largely is being taken up by the middle classes to extend existing homes. Because of the exemption from capital gains tax of family homes, this is where the available money is going; not into the area which has caused great concern.

Back in May the Institute of Chartered Accountants criticised the proposed capital gains tax and warned that it would seriously hamper development and limit growth. The Government would not listen. We told it then; the Institute of Chartered Accountants told it. Lots of people told it. But it knew best. Sadly, the expectations of the Institute are being met in full. Once again the Government is striking at families-families which are trying to set up homes for themselves. It is striking also at the small business contractors. It is striking at the poor, who are being forced out of the private rental market and who are being asked to wait longer and longer for public housing. I, like the New South Wales Housing Minister, am concerned about the battlers who are struggling to find a home. I agree with him that these policies are hurting a large section of the community. Honourable senators opposite do not address these problems. But as a nation we cannot afford the unintended consequences of this Government. For the sake of our fellow Australians, I urge the Government to reconsider its taxation measures. They are hurting Australian families. Give them a go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an attempt by the Liberal Party Opposition to bore the Senate and those hardy souls who listen to parliamentary broadcasts by trying to form a marriage of extraordinary inconvenience between an anti-capital gains tax push and an argument about housing. It is a convenience which I think was adequately exposed by Senator Janine Haines, of all people, in her contribution to the debate. So far we have heard from the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who exposed the Liberal Party's penchant under the Howard-Fraser Administration for tax avoidance schemes which enabled the tax system in Australia to fall into disrepute. We heard about the legendary Slutzkin wet and dry schemes, the macadamia nut schemes, the bottom of the harbour schemes and the cherry-picker schemes. Of course, we were taken as well on a tour of the Perth Attorney-General's bottom drawer in which there languished for many years papers which, if activated, would have stamped out some of these schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard, of course, as well from Senator Graham Richardson, who exposed the argument of Opposition senators who, from time to time in this debate, have relied upon the tax reform package in the United States. He pointed out that their opposition to capital gains tax is inconsistent if they support the United States model. He pointed out that the United States model has a retrospective capital gains tax, and a capital gains tax on the full gain. We heard as well a parade of crocodile tears from Liberal senators, who have the unique ability to pretend to argue in defence of the poor while arguing for the restoration of privileges to the rich. It is a unique form of argument. It is most insincere, unconvincing and, of course, in the end, electors judge that type of argument by deeds, not by the words it contains. It is only by resorting to the former Howard-Fraser Government's record that one can see what the deeds would be, and the deeds make horrendous reporting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then why don't you go to the electors now?

—Honourable senators who interject will not find any comfort when I expose what that record is. The thing that irks me most about this debate is that it is a continuance of the campaign of fear that the Opposition wants to generate about the Australian economy. Members of the Opposition in this country are out to knock the Australian economy, to destroy the rising confidence that there is in the way in which the economy is being handled. When they were in government they were economic vandals. In opposition, they are economic saboteurs.

SPEECH.PARA: The theory that seems to spring heartily to the lips of most Opposition senators when they are having a confab among themselves about strategy is that if they can only talk down the Australian economy, if they can only bad mouth the sterling work of the Government, if they can carp, criticise and condemn, they hope that, out of all of that cesspool of hate and bad will, the gloom and doom that that generates will open an opportunity for victory. Therefore, they set about, in opposition, being economic vandals, because they hope to do things to the Australian economy which will create a lack of confidence generally and which will lead to a recessed standard of living so that, in that circumstance, they will come to power. It is about time that the Opposition in the Senate faced what the Australian people want-that is, to see all parties in Australia pulling together, working around common goals, in order to lift the Australian economy so that there will be a better standard of living for all. Those who act as economic saboteurs will not be rewarded at the ballot box. In any case, all of the polls still show that the people respect the Hawke Government for having better policies for economic management than the failed and tired policies of the Howard Opposition, which have been tried and rejected.

One of the most distinguishing points of this Government is, of course, its willingness to tackle the hard, in-built rorts in the whole system. One of the most central ones that it has faced, fought and is bringing off, is a change to the tax regime in this country which, under the Liberals, enabled tax avoidance and evasion to flourish, which placed the load of tax payments on the backs of middle and low income earners and which enabled the rich to escape their tax obligations. The Opposition recognises that we have faced those problems and have worked out a tax package based on equity, efficiency and simplicity in order to sort out that system. What it is now complaining about is that that system is working.

As this debate is taking place, the Australian dollar is holding up on the international exchange. Interest rates are beginning to edge down to the point where it is now being forecast that the prime rates of lending will be cut in some cases soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the housing crisis.

—Senator Baume will hear about housing; do not worry. He will not like it when he hears about it. There are fewer industrial disputes; wages are moving in a modest way and below the levels of the consumer price index; there is increasing confidence generally; and there is an expectancy by the broader population that, because of the tax changes we have made, ordinary wage and salary earners will receive significant tax cuts in December and in July next year, as those people who have been escaping their tax obligations are caught in the net of our package and are required to pay tax. We know, too, that it was the previous Government, after all, which had the lowest level of housing activity in Australia of any government since 1961. So the Opposition's arguments on housing do not stand up when one looks at its previous performance.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the record of this Government, because a lot of ill-chosen words have been spoken about housing development in Australia. It is a record of which this Government is proud in regard to the industry activity that has been generated, the provision of jobs and the objective of meeting the social needs that we as a political party hold dear. When we came to office the housing industry in this country was in a parlous shape. In 1982-83, the dying years of the Howard-Fraser Government, only 105,000 commencements were made, compared with 152,700 commencements in 1984-85-an increase of 45 per cent on the 1982-83 Howard-Fraser figures, and the highest commencement rate since 1973-74. In 1985-86, 136,000 commencements were made-still an increase of 30 per cent on the 1982-83 figures. The Indicative Planning Council, a housing industry body set up under this Government, headed by Professor Fred Gruen, predicts that in 1986-87 there will be 125,000 commencements Australia wide. The major reason for the decline in the prediction for commencements in 1986-87 is the truth that anyone who studies the economic situation in Australia knows-that is, the Queensland economic performance is holding down the rest of Australia. The predicted decline of 7,000 commencements in Queensland is one of the reasons why those figures have come in below the previous levels. We know of-it is legend in this place-the mismanagement of the Queensland economy, the lame duck of the Australian economy; the one that causes all of our figures to be in a down cycle.

In the housing construction industry the employment figures have risen significantly since this Government came to power. In August this year 491,000 people-almost half a million-were employed in the housing construction industry, which was 70,000 more than the May 1983 level. Of course, the Government took major action in April this year to assist the housing industry and protect housing borrowers when it announced the housing assistance package. As part of this package it paid a subsidy of about $150m to the banks to safeguard the one million borrowers paying an interest rate of 13.5 per cent to the banks. It allowed the banks to lift their interest rates to 15.5 per cent for new borrowers and it got banks to agree to lend at least $6 billion in 1986-87 to promote low start loans. This is a quite significant injection of funds, particularly for people at the lower end of the scale. Lending for housing has increased significantly since that decision was made. In the three months to July housing lending was running at around $7.5 billion as an annual rate. In August and September bank lending for housing was at least double the figure for the months prior to April 1986. The 13.5 per cent ceiling will remain, lending is strong, deposit growth on banks is still okay and the Government has fiscal and wages policies in place to take off the pressure on interest rates. Current interest rates are declining, as I have said.

In October 1983 we started the first home owners scheme which reflects our vital concern for first home owners. Under that scheme they get up to $6,000 which they can use as a deposit or lump sum payment to reduce the interest. Compare that figure with the maximum assistance of $3,500 given under the Liberals. Since the first home owners scheme was introduced in October 1983 nearly $1 billion-in fact $970m-was committed Australia wide for the 214,000 successful applicants. It has provided a massive boost to that industry. In the public housing area one has to consult only the Liberal Party's housing policy to see that its interest in the public housing sector virtually does not exist. In our case, the total funding for public housing from the Federal Government in 1986-87 will be $1,275m; that is, $694m in grants and $582m available in low interest loans. That figure is up 130 per cent on what the Liberals provided in 1982-83 and I have a table which demonstrates the State distribution. This will lead to an increase of 17,500 in the public rental housing stock, compared with only 8,700 in the first half of 1982-83, the last year of the Liberal Government. In total, public housing funding with State contributions will be over $1.9 billion in 1986-87, the highest ever, and it will lead to over 22,000 new housing commencements. That is part of our record.

This urgency motion is launched on tax reform, an area in which this Government is prepared and proud to debate the issues. I think there are three significant areas of tax reform that ought to be mentioned: The quarantining of negative gearing, the introduction of the 4 per cent depreciation allowance on new rental accommodation and the capital gains tax. The new quarantining of negative gearing arrangements affect the rental properties negatively geared prior to 17 July 1985. It should minimise any possible outflow of current investment from the private rental market, that is, it does not affect the great bulk of rental stock. The reform package includes a new 4 per cent depreciation allowance for investment in rental property. This will encourage funds to be put into the construction of new private rental housing and capital improvements to existing rental properties.

A lot has been said in this debate about the capital gains tax. The key is that it is not a punitive capital gains tax; it is a necessary reform in the armory of all taxing measures to have a proper capital gains tax in place. We now have that. It is a prospective tax and a number of the furphies that have been circulated about it are consistent with the scaremongering activities of the Opposition. The impact on rents and the supply of rental housing is likely to be gradual and the changes will occur over time.

As I have said in this urgency debate, this Government has a proud record on tax reform. However, one area of tax reform that needs to be mentioned in addition to those I have mentioned is that the imputation system will eliminate the old double tax on company income and that will be an incentive for investors. It will correct an efficiency distortion in the taxing scales and it will encourage funds into productive investment, unlike what was going on under the previous Government when, in the absence of a capital gains tax and a proper tax package, the investment that occurred in Australia often went into speculative areas, not productive wealth creating areas.

The bottom line is that the Liberal Party comes into this Senate and criticises our performance which I have just enunciated. It comes here without any clothes because it has no tax policy of its own. It is about time that the Opposition put up or shut up. It can go around criticising performance, it can go around criticising achievement, it can go around criticising a government which has the guts and courage to face one of the hardest political obstacles of all-that is, rearranging the tax scales to a more equitable level-but it cannot go around with any credibility if it fails to produce its own blue print so that what it would do can be seen by the people at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-This has been an extraordinary debate. There have been three speakers for the Australian Labor Party, not one of whom has acknowledged or admitted that there is a housing crisis in Australia today. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, did not talk about the state of Australia's housing. Whatever else Senator Walsh is, he is an honest person and he could not talk about it and pretend that it was all right. Senator Cook has given eloquent reason to understand why he languishes on the back bench and why he will stay there because he wants to tell us how good the housing situation is in Australia today. Senator Cook has made the classic mistake that Labor people make; he tried to tell us all that the Labor Party is doing by way of input into public policy and therefore assumes that the public policy area is all right.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we have demonstrated, with figures of what is going on today in the community and what is happening right now to Australians, that Senator Cook is wrong; that it is not all right. It is far from all right. Australians are not able to move into home ownership today. That is the fact. Fewer Australians than anyone imagines-with all these whizz-bang schemes which Labor is putting into effect-think that things are wonderful. They are not wonderful. Senator Cook did not address the fact that the rental market in Australia is a disaster. It is not a disaster for Senator Cook, with his salary and an established house, but it is a disaster for Australians looking for rental accommodation because they cannot find it and what is available costs too much. Senator Cook did not address that matter because either he could not or would not. It was a pathetic performance. We did not hear one word of acknowledgment from the Labor Party that there is a crisis or that it had some answer to it.

Although Senator Haines was less than complimentary about our motion, she readily acknowledged that there is a housing crisis in Australia today. She, representing the Australian Democrats, had it right and the Labor Party had it wrong again. Labor speakers want to talk to us about what our prospects would be in a contest before the people today. We invite them to take us on and try us. There is nothing we would like better today than to let the Australian people judge because we know that this Government-it is moribund and bankrupt-would be swept from office. Today's performance is the kind of performance that, whatever the Labor Party thinks of its tax regime, it did not even have the wit or the willingness to acknowledge that a crisis exists in Australia today in owning, renting, locating and acquiring housing. That makes it unfit to govern this country. We not only demonstrated but also produced adequate, contemporary figures of what is going on today. The crisis is there and we know that it has been brought about by the policies of this Government-I presume it is the unintended consequences of those policies. Nevertheless the crisis has been brought about by the policies we have set out in the Senate today. It is not good enough for those who traditionally look to Labor governments for their support and help to have this inadequate and poor performance from the Government that they elected. It was absolutely pathetic. We believe that the motion is a good one.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the eightieth report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which was tabled last night by Senator Cooney. I would like, as Senator Lewis did, to commend Senator Cooney for the way in which he chairs that Committee. Chapter 4 of the eightieth report commences with a number of quotations. I would quickly like to refer to a few of them because they say something very important about the history of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. Sir Robert Garran was a very significant figure in Australia's legal and constitutional history. In 1930, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: A committee could scrutinise regulations. But a good deal of its work would be thankless, as it would not discover very much to find fault with. It would certainly be the least interesting of the committees.
In 1958, some 28 years later, Sir Robert said:
The Senate has taken a good forward step. It has established a Regulations and Ordinances Committee. . . . I should like to see the Committee further developed and better advertised.
Further down the track, Senator Wood, a former Chairman of the Committee, recounted a conversation that he had had with Sir Robert and said:

As a man who helped with the framing of the Constitution, Sir Robert replied that this was the most important Committee in Parliament because its duty was to see that Parliament ran this country with legislation and that the Executive did not do so by regulations and ordinances.
That is an interesting progression of thought.

The eightieth report represents a very important statement by the Committee of its attitude and approach to delegated legislation. The report should be required reading for policy advisers and legislative drafters if they are to avoid infringing the Committee's bipartisan principles of scrutiny. In one sense the Committee is a difficult one to serve on because of the heavy workload of instruments that it processes. In the past year nearly 900 instruments have passed through the Committee and it was sufficiently concerned to write to Ministers concerning 60 of those instruments.

One frustrating aspect of our work arises when the Committee writes to a Minister to repeat a point which had already been made to that or another Minister on an earlier occasion. Honourable senators will see in the report a number of themes repeated over and over again. Although the Committee has adopted the practice of being as open as it can be about its work, making statements in the Senate and incorporating or tabling its correspondence, it still seems to take a very long time before particular flaws in delegated legislation are dealt with and weeded out.

The Committee has asked the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to give general instructions to his Department about these kinds of matters, and he has been very responsive on this issue. The Committee is anxious to see that flaws which it identifies are not repeated, because the exercise of drawing these flaws to the attention of Ministers in order to get them fixed is not so much a waste of the Committee's time as it is a waste of the Minister's time, because the problem could have been avoided by reference to the Committee's reports and tabled correspondence before drafting of the offensive instrument. Apart from discussing how the Committee interprets and applies its principles, the report is important because it identifies and discusses major flaws as seen by the Committee in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, which are the Acts conferring disallowance powers on this Senate. These flaws allow delegated legislation to be retrospectively prejudicial to individuals without any express mandate for that retrospectivity in the parent Act of Parliament, and they make it possible for delegated legislation to be virtually permanently in force without the need to table it in both Houses of the Parliament which granted the power to make the legislation in the first place.

The Senate has no power to disallow regulations partially, although this power has been sought repeatedly and indeed, under the previous administration, it was promised. We can partially disallow ordinances, but nothing else. Clever drafting can mean that the only way to knock out a really offensive provision in regulations would be to disallow pages and pages of inoffensive and innocuous provisions, because the offending part could not be partially disallowed without the disallowance of a whole regulation. The rules governing the revival of repealed laws need to be overhauled to prevent the possible repetition of the difficulties which faced the Senate when it disallowed the New South Wales Acts Application Ordinance 1985 last year. These are serious flaws which must be addressed as matters of priority if the Senate is to continue to claim to have effective disallowance power which cannot be evaded by artificial devices.

This Committee, on behalf of the Senate, claims to be the world leader in the scrutiny of delegated legislation, but these flaws, to a certain extent, undermine the reality of that claim, and because of that they must be dealt with. In a sense we would be called a `fix it' committee. If the delegated legislation, regulation or ordinance infringes the Committee's principles, we write to Ministers telling them of the infringement, we point out the importance of the issue and we try to persuade the relevant Minister to remove or remedy the offending clauses. When we get undertakings to amend, we are happy to commend Ministers for their genuine commitment to rights. The Committee has had success with these procedures under this Government and under the previous Government. One of the previous chairmen of the Committee, Senator Devitt, in 1974, reported that the trend at that time was for the Committee to investigate approximately 20 per cent of instruments being made. It is a measure of the continued impact of the Committee on the conscientious efforts of legislative drafters that the Committee now investigates about 10 per cent, which is quite a significant reduction. That is a measure of the success of the Committee's persuasive approach. But in the end, if the persuasive approach does not work, there are disallowance powers, and when the Committee makes a reasonable assessment of a matter which infringes rights and where a Minister or his or her officials refuse to be persuaded, this Committee is confident that the Senate will back the Committee's judgment. It has done so for the past 55 years, and particularly for the past 15 years, during which the Committee has not had occasion to move for disallowance. Sometimes ministerial undertakings are withheld until the last minute before a disallowance motion is due, as if to test the resolution of the Committee. We have had the experience of sitting as a committee in an in camera hearing with official witnesses at 10.30 the night before a disallowance debate, repeating verbally what we had already said three or four times in correspondence over numerous weeks prior to that time. That is another of the frustrations of working on the Committee.

The people who draft delegated legislation and advise on it do not all seem to realise what the Committee is about. We are open to persuasion but not bluff, and in Professor Douglas Whalan we have the best legal brains available to advise us. The Committee protects its position by giving protective notices of motion to allow time for discussion. But sometimes the Committee does not get ministerial responses as soon as it would like, simply because sometimes our concerns are not taken as seriously as they should be. However, one of the features of the Senate Standing Orders is that once a notice is given, it can be taken over by any senator for disallowance on policy grounds, and that is the gauntlet that the Minister is made to run by his Department if it delays for so long in replying to the Committee that we have to give a notice of motion.

At the end of the day, infringements on the rights of Parliament or on personal rights will be removed from delegated legislation, or the instrument will be disallowed. But it would greatly facilitate our work, with great respect to Ministers, were they to instruct their advisers to address the Committee's concerns with more speed and less protectiveness. For some reason, although the Committee in its correspondence goes to some lengths to set out its concerns and even in the initial letter to answer obvious rebuttals of those concerns so that we can quickly get to the kernel of any issue--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to commend the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to the Senate. This Committee is a very hard working one, as is shown by the long list of regulations, ordinances and by-laws which have been considered during this year. I wish to raise a few points that come out of the report and which I believe need to be picked up in legislation. I also wish to give notice that if the Government does not pick them up, I would hope to be able to introduce these measures as legislation. I note that in paragraph 2.26 of the report, under the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) (No. 1) Act 1982 the Government at that stage moved that an ordinance or a regulation which had not been tabled in the Parliament within 15 days of its being set up was not automatically void. In fact, if that instrument-whatever it was, whether it be a regulation or a by-law-were not tabled as required under the Acts Interpretation Act, it would be taken to apply for the whole of the 15 sitting days before it went out of existence. I believe that this is a problem because it leaves us with regulations that can operate for a small amount of time. Instead of the regulation never having existed, it would have existed until the automatic disallowance for tabling it took effect. It is extremely important not to have such loopholes within the law because we could have a similar, or almost the same, instrument brought back into being immediately as the Parliament had not disallowed it. It would be possible continually to try to by pass the processes of parliament, not that that would get people very far. It is a real problem to have that type of loophole in the law.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been some changes to the ability of the Senate to change Australian Capital Territory ordinances. I believe that these changes have been very beneficial. We have used them this year to improve delegated legislation in the Australian Capital Territory. We can change those ordinances right down to the last word by deleting a word or a figure from a particular line in an ordinance to produce a different effect. This is not possible in regulations under the Acts Interpretation Act. This should be changed to allow the Senate to change or delete any single word sentence or clause in a regulation made under a given Act and whose liability to disallowance comes under the Acts Interpretation Act if the Senate so wishes unless the government acts, I will be introducing some legislation, or maybe an amendment to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, this year to try to reverse this situation. I think we should even go further because basically it seems pretty ridiculous that we can amend Bills in this place but we cannot at this stage amend delegated legislation in any way other than by deletion. If we are to use the Parliament in the most effective way possible, we should allow the Senate, and the Parliament generally, to amend-if that is required by the majority of the Senate-delegated legislation. I hope to move such amendments in the reasonably near future to try to support that type of proposal.

The instance today when I moved to disallow a regulation under the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (Inquiries) Regulations-No. 100 of the Statutory Rules 1986-is an example of how we could have saved an enormous amount of time if it had been possible to change one or two words or sentences in the regulation instead of carrying on a full-scale debate about disallowing either the whole of each of the regulations in turn or the whole group of regulations, which were the only two options available to the Senate. I definitely recommend to the Government that it consider this proposal at length.

I also commend the Committee on the excellent work it has done in forcing the Government to look more closely at the delegated legislation which has been put before this place. On a regular basis we have had a number of ordinances or regulations which have been under threat of disallowance while the Committee discussed with the Government some provisions which may have an effect either on civil liberties or on the appropriateness of the delegated legislation. In most cases these motions of disallowance are not proceeded with because the government backs down on the particular proposal and changes the ordinance or undertakes to do so. This Committee fulfils an extremely useful task.

I refer to one example which I was involved in where that role did not work totally as expected, that is, the New South Wales Acts Application Ordinance 1985. Basically this ordinance made certain that all the outdated New South Wales Acts which applied in the Australian Capital Territory, except those which were directly listed in the ordinance, ceased to exist. The problem was that there was no list of the Acts that would cease to exist. One of those was the Trade Union Act 1881 which was of some use apparently to an organisation that wanted to register under its provisions. The failure to list the Acts in the ordinance meant that those people were disadvantaged. It was picked up by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the whole ordinance expired through the effluxion of time.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 256th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts entitled `Forward Obligation of Government Expenditures'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The inquiry into forward obligation of government expenditures was initiated by the Public Accounts Committee following the finding by the Auditor-General, in his September 1985 report, that significant weaknesses existed in the forward obligations control systems of several departments. This finding arose from audits at the departments of Finance, Aboriginal Affairs, Local Government and Administrative Services, and Territories. Audit found that: The departments have not kept accurate records; monitoring by Finance was inadequate; approved limits to forward obligations have been exceeded by substantial amounts on a number of occasions; there was no mechanism through which the government could be regularly informed of such breaches; and there was a reluctance by departments to accept responsibility for the inadequacies discovered by Audit.

SPEECH.PARA: Because the Auditor-General's comments had service-wide implications, the Committee sought submissions from all departments. Additional information was sought from Treasury and the Department of Finance. Some 29 departments responded to the initial request. Procedures to secure government approval to enter into expenditure commitment against Budgets of future years-that is, forward obligations-have existed for some time. Such procedures are essential in cases where financial commitments cover several years. Purchase of defence equipment or property by the Commonwealth, or contractual arrangements, such as the cleaning of airports or the maintenance of computer equipment, are typical examples where the forward obligations system would be used extensively.

The forward obligations system was introduced in its current form in 1976, at a time when the Government attached particular importance to the objective of reining in the rate of growth in government spending. The stated aim of the procedures was the application of a forward programming system to enable the Government to regulate the extent to which commitments involving future Budget allocations could be made. This forward programming system was to apply across a broad range of Budget expenditures to minimise the extent of Budget `lock-in'.

The Committee examined the Auditor-General's findings within the framework of the broad objectives set for the forward obligations system in 1976. Information obtained through submissions, discussions with officers of the Department of Finance and further research indicated that:
Forward obligations covered less than 20 per cent of budget outlays;

The breaches against approved limits reported by Audit had a relatively minor impact on overall expenditures. This was because, in most cases, departments have been able to find offsetting savings to the funds they needed, over and above the approved forward obligations limits;
Non-compliance tended to bear mainly on internal program management, rather than on overall budgetary control;

The Forward Estimates system, which covers all Budget outlays, has become the best available indicator of the extent of Budget `lock-ins'. The 1985-86 Budget Statements noted that, in that year, Forward Estimates formed the basis of individual portfolio targets for the first time, and that these targets served as guidelines in the determination of Budget estimates; and
The existing legislative and policy framework placed primary responsibility for forward obligations with departmental secretaries.

The Committee concluded that the forward obligations system, while important to departments, had limited value to overall Budget strategy and control. In addition, the budgetary impact of the breaches reported by Audit were found to be relatively minor, once offsetting savings had been taken into account. These findings suggested that tighter monitoring by Finance and regular reporting to government on possible future breaches were unlikely to have a significant impact on overall Budget outlays. In addition, greater involvement by Finance would not be within the spirit of the current policy of devolution of financial responsibilities to departmental secretaries.

The Committee also concluded that it was time to review the purpose and the operations of the system. This was because the environment in which the forward obligations system was introduced a decade ago has changed considerably. The Committee noted that, in response to the Auditor-General's findings, the Department of Finance initiated an internal review of the forward obligations system. The review proposes that Finance's monitoring activities be, in future, limited to only the major forward obligations categories, and that monitoring of expenditures against all other obligation limits be the responsibility of departmental secretaries.

The Committee recommends that the current review of the forward obligation system by Finance be expedited; and that the new regulatory framework arising from this review specify that the system's main objective is to authorise departments to enter into forward commitments in certain expenditure categories, and limit the extent of monitoring by Finance to cases where commitments could have a significant impact on overall Budget outlays.

The Committee further recommends that in developing the details of the new regulatory arrangements, the policy of greater devolution of responsibility to departmental secretaries be given as much weight as possible. In this context, the Committee considers that monitoring arrangements by Finance which rely on global obligation limits for departments would be preferable to arrangements which monitor obligations at the program level. I would like to express the Committee's appreciation of the effort put in by departments in preparing their submissions, and thank the Department of Finance for the supplementary information it prepared for this inquiry. I commend this report to honourable senators.
