I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 15, dated 15 October 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was indicating the opposition of the Australian Democrats to the whole range of measures that the Government has introduced in the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill. The Freedom of Information Act is basically being dismembered and its effectiveness destroyed by the Government's desire to make sure that the information which citizens should have will not be available to them, at least without a great deal of expense. Not to put too fine a point on it, the amendments in this Bill, if passed, will cripple the Freedom of Information Act by putting the cost of access beyond the reach of ordinary citizens. People making requests now will have to pay a new application fee of $30 before public servants will begin to respond to the request. Even if one is refused access one will not get back the $30. It will cost another $40 to make an internal review request. In exercising this $40 right of appeal to another bureaucrat-senior to the first-it should be remembered that the second bureaucrat probably has been consulted in the first place anyhow. Even worse, the hourly charge for search and retrieval has been increased to $15. This is a useful basis on which to penalise the person making the request for the department's incompetence in not being able to find the material in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: Worst of all is the introduction of a $20 per hour charge for agency decision making and consultation time. The mind boggles as to what exactly might end up appearing under that type of heading. Unfortunately, it would be too costly to find out under the Freedom of Information Act. The iniquitous provision for a $20 fee per hour for agency decision making and consultation time will no doubt be used by the bureaucracy to charge for its inefficiency and delaying tactics under the guise of decision making.

A mere description of these provisions indicates how seriously the operation of the Act will be impeded. But just how valid is the argument the Government is putting with regard to costs? Senator Puplick raised this matter at some length. I do not want to go over the same ground he traversed but it is worth noting that the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, in his second reading speech said that in 1984-85 the operation and administration of the Freedom of Information Act cost the Commonwealth between $16m and $19m, depending on the precise allowances made for overheads. The preliminary figures for 1985-86 indicate a cost of between $14m and $16m. The Attorney-General describes this as a situation which Australia simply cannot afford. One wonders why something so important cannot be afforded when each year the Federal Government spends an estimated $108m on propaganda of various sorts. It is perfectly alright to use money for propaganda purposes in astronomical amounts, but it is not all right for citizens to be able to find out the information they want. That suddenly becomes too costly in our democracy. One can consider other factors. One might consider the $14m to $16m. One factor that comes to mind immediately is the cost of artworks, furnishings and communications equipment for the new Parliament House of $17.5m.

Not only does expenditure on the Freedom of Information Act compare unfavourably with other areas of expenditure, but the costs have been queried recently by the former Commonwealth Ombudsman, Professor Jack Richardson. Earlier this month Professor Richardson criticised the changes embodied in this Bill and expressed the view that the Government was exaggerating the long term costs of protecting this fundamental right. That case was made very clearly by Senator Puplick. One can conclude only that the Government has reasons of its own other than costs for this destructive attack on the Freedom of Information Act.

Increased costs and the consequences of introducing them are not the only problem with this Bill. The Government has devised another way to make the system unworkable. In this area, I am pleased to say, the Opposition has got it right and we will be supporting its amendment accordingly. I refer to the multi-document request clause. This extraordinary provision allows a Minister to refuse a request for more than one document on the grounds that it would present a substantial diversion of resources and deletes the present requirement that that diversion be unreasonable. Obviously, departments would be able to exploit the situation and effectively deny access when they did not want their processes opened to public scrutiny and examination. It does not take very much imagination to see how this exploitation could occur. Every department whose filing system was in disarray could refuse almost every freedom of information request simply because it was in disarray. It could say that any request made to it was unreasonable. Every request necessarily increases the delay in answering every other request. So this, too, could be used as an excuse. As most documents are circulated to other departments, departments can now say that they must consult other departments-a further delay.

The list of ramifications and excuses under this clause is endless. It is no exaggeration to say that it will sow the seeds of destruction of any effective freedom of information system for ordinary citizens in our community. I am not talking about the friends of the Government such as the multinationals and large companies which simply have direct access to Ministers. I am talking about ordinary citizens who try to get information. Apart from these implications, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has expressed concern about the multi-document request clause. This merely strengthens the Democrats' opposition to this preposterous amendment.

Another issue of concern to us is that charges would no longer be waived simply because the release of information is in the public interest. The Government has argued that the public interest provision has been the most difficult to administer. Surely this is Yes Prime Minister material. Next we will hear that not all questions have been answered and that there are constitutional implications. Those two items will probably end up in the Minister's response, but this one must take the cake. One suspects that the activities of consumer groups and lawyers working on behalf of disadvantaged clients have had far more to do with the Government's decision to abolish the obligation on bureaucrats to consider waiving fees than the difficulty of administering the public interest consideration.

We all know that it is easier to defeat ill-informed critics than well briefed ones because knowledge is certainly power. The best way to ensure that end is to keep as much information as possible from those critics. In the United States people in the categories I have mentioned are protected from exorbitant fees under the United States Freedom of Information Act, but we are confronted with a Government that wants to move from that type of protection. Added to this, the Government wishes to retain the 45-day limit on handling requests and has abandoned the plan to reduce that time to 30 days. In both of these areas the Australian Democrats will be supporting Opposition amendments to rectify the Government's proposals.

Finally, it strikes the Australian Democrats as the height of absurdity that the Government has introduced these amendments while the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is investigating the first three years of the Freedom of Information Act in operation. The Committee is required to review experience and to make recommendations. It has had over 100 submissions and 60 witnesses. Its report is expected in November. Having pre-empted the Committee's report in such an extraordinarily flagrant way, we believe that it is quite unreasonable and unconscionable for this chamber to pass this Bill. Therefore, at a later stage we will be seeking to have this legislation deferred until the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee of this chamber has had a chance to report. At best, we believe that the Government is acting without that report, a report of this chamber, prepared by an all-party committee, which we believe would bring added, useful and vital information which would enable us to make a reasonable decision with regard to this Bill. Why do we ask our Committee to carry out a long and detailed inquiry if the very chamber which has set up that Committee does not even bother to wait for its report?

In short, this Bill is an utter disaster. If the amendments are passed, the Act will be fatally flawed, and let nobody be in any doubt about that. It will be this Labor Government which started the rot. Quite frankly, I do not expect the Opposition parties, when they come to power, to do any better despite the honeyed words we have heard from Senator Puplick in this debate. It will be on the head of this Labor Government that it started the destruction of this vital piece of legislation which is so vital to democratic institutions in this country.

I am reminded of similar attacks on the Freedom of Information Act in the United States of America in the first few years after it started in 1966. In the United States, however, the Watergate scandal shocked the American public and the media so much that that particular Act was saved. Indeed, not only was it saved but also it was strengthened against further attack and, in fact, it has survived far better than this Bill will unfortunately survive by the time these amendments are passed with the collusion of the Opposition and the Government. I hope that Australia does not have to suffer the trauma of a Watergate experience before we recognise how vital the Freedom of Information Act is to our citizens and to our media in protecting the Government, and ultimately us, from this vandalism that is about to be perpetrated on freedom of information in Australia by this Government and by the Minister at the table who, to his credit, did so much to make sure that we had this legislation but who is now to be the person to respond in its initial destruction. It seems to me to be an extraordinary situation-a situation that I believe no-one can take any heart from-that we should see this Government turn around so much in respect of this matter in the short period it has been in office.

I want to express the Democrat's complete dismay and utter disgust at what is going on in the chamber tonight. I have already quoted the view of the Attorney-General that freedom of information is a basic right at the very heart of our democracy. I remind the Minister at the table of the words he used when he described good freedom of information legislation as `that which would set a minimum of procedural obstacles by way of delay or complexity of costs, and afford the maximum of practical assistance to those who are pressing requests for access to information'. I hope that honourable senators on both sides will look at what we are about to do and will consider that at least one course that might be acceptable to the majority of honourable senators, if they cannot, for whatever reason, vote against the Bill, will be to consider seriously that we wait until the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has reported to this chamber. I believe that its report will add weight to the comments that I have made tonight and to the comments that Senator Puplick made on behalf of the Opposition. I ask the Opposition to consider seriously the Democrats' request that we at least delay this legislation so that, in the light of the recommendations of our own chamber Committee, we can see whether or not we will be able to modify it, or perhaps the Government, in that space of time, might have second thoughts about the action it has embarked upon.

In any event, it seems to me that that delay is not against this so-called doctrine of Budget Bills that the Opposition has trotted out. It does not violate that so-called doctrine. It is merely in keeping with the need to wait until we hear the Senate Committee's own review. It took Australia an enormous long time to put this piece of legislation into effect. It has had a very short working life. It is shocking and distressful that we should now be chopping it about in such a way that it will lead to its ultimate demise as an effective adjunct to the operation of democracy in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the foreword of the 1983-84 annual report on the Freedom of Information Act, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: While some problems in administration have been identified, the Act is working well and achieving its stated purpose of extending as far as possible the right of the Australian community for access to information in the possession of the Australian Government.

Indeed, that was the signal for the type of attack we are seeing tonight to start. It started last year. It was due only to the conscience and uprightness of Senator Missen, who managed to get the Opposition to vote against the regulations which were put forward in this place last year, that we were spared last year the demise of freedom of information in Australia. I believe this will come to be dubbed the freedom from information Bill because basically what is happening is that the Government and the Opposition are conspiring together to put information out of the price range of ordinary individuals and ordinary Australians. They are doing this for various reasons which are not related to their personal convictions.

In the past we have heard Senator Gareth Evans make strong pleas for freedom of information. I believe that he is honest in this. Yet he is the Minister who is bringing forward this legislation today. Today we have heard Senator Puplick wax lyrical, as he always does, on the issues surrounding this particular legislation. He said why it is unreasonable for the prices to go up, yet he said the the Opposition is going to support the Government in raising the fees. That just does not make sense.

I would like to dwell on this issue of the two types of legislation which the Opposition seems to recognise as going through this Parliament. One type of legislation results from statements by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on one particular night in August when he says `this is the Budget'. From that moment on, if the Government claims that the legislation going through the House comes directly from the statement mentioned on that night, it can rely on this group of people-the Opposition-who are being paid by Australians to actually monitor what the Government is doing, not to vote against it because it is a Budget Bill. That is one type of legislation that goes through this House.

Another type of legislation is announced in the Governor-General's speech and that is obviously not as important as the legislation in the Treasurer's speech in the eyes of the Opposition. Other types of legislation are declared from time to time in this Parliament that the Opposition is able to vote against. I find it very difficult to understand why the Opposition should abrogate its responsibility to vote against bad legislation, whether it is legislation declared on one particular night of the year by the Treasurer, and treat it differently because of that, or whether it is declared or put into this Parliament in some other way. I believe that a real indictment of the current political system is that people who have ability, knowledge and conviction are being forced by the party system to vote in such an unthinking and unreasonable way. I feel very sorry for them in this particular case. In fact, this problem will be faced with the identity card, if that comes up, if the Government claims that it is a Budget issue. I believe that, for the sake of all Australians, the Opposition must realise that the Government can just simply put some money bits into a Bill but that there can also be some non-Budget bits in that Bill. The Opposition, in fact, is moving to amend the non-budgetary bits currently, and we are supporting it in this area. But it has given up the ultimate sanction against the Government of throwing the legislation out. We are willing to support any move, if the Opposition still has this hangup in the next period of sitting, to divide off the monetary sections from the other sections of the Bill and to consider them separately, to free them so that we can act in the interests of the people who elected us to this place. I believe that is very important.

I turn now to the Government. It seems par for the course that when something improves, the Government seeks to close it down or make it ineffective. It is doing just that with the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations, and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal due to the dislocation which will be caused by the new inquiry regulations that Senator Puplick was also part of allowing to continue today. This is exactly what is happening with the freedom of information legislation. The Government wants to turn it into freedom from information. The Government is acting as an agent for the mandarinate within the Public Service, which does not want to be oversighted by this Parliament. Parts of the Public Service do not want to be questioned on what they do by anybody-by the Parliament or by the people of Australia. The mandarins at Treasury and the forces in the Department of Finance would love to be able to manipulate the strings of this country totally as Sir Humphrey would and to have the Ministers represent them rather than the people of Australia. They are exactly the types of actions that we are seeing, unfortunately, from Senator Gareth Evans. I would have thought better of him-that he would have taken up the interests of the people and stood up for open government, which he has been a champion of for so many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be fair. It would not have happened if he were Attorney.

—Roll on the day when Senator Evans will again be able to bring us free information and open up the Public Service to full scrutiny. That is what we should all stand here for, not the type of secrecy, hiding and excuse making which goes on. The annual report covering the operation of the Freedom of Information Act for 1984-85 shows that things got even better; the average cost per request dropped from $917 to $584 over that year. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) says in his foreword that this is due to `improved and more efficient administration in processing requests'. I would like the Senate to ponder on that for a moment. Freedom of information has actually resulted in public servants improving their performance in terms of information storage and retrieval. I believe there will be a net saving over all the operations of public servants because if they found it very difficult to find information for ordinary citizens they probably also found it very difficult to get information for their own use in the normal day to day running of their departments. It is not surprising that freedom of information is again under attack so shortly afterwards. It is very unfortunate that this Senate is contemplating taking such an unprincipled stand in trying to pass this legislation quickly when the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is part way through an inquiry into this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Government departments really ought to have much better document retrieval as a result of FOI. In fact, that is being found to be the case by the Committee. The Committee has blown the gaff on the inflated costs that have been given for the operation of freedom of information legislation. On 7 November last year, before this matter blew up, I drew attention to the 88 per cent on-cost figure being used to inflate the stated costs of freedom of information. This basically added $2 1/2m to $3m to the cost of freedom of information being obtained from the Public Service. Almost a year later, in evidence before the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, the Department of Finance has admitted that 60 per cent is a far more reasonable figure. An officer of the Department made these comments on 28 August this year:

The Attorney-General's Department consulted with me and a colleague in the last few weeks about this question about what a proper overhead was. We came to an agreement that the long-standing basis on which overheads had been calculated was probably an exaggeration. If my memory serves me correctly, this was particularly because using the Public Service Board's formula had involved the Attorney-General's Department in what it believed was some double counting. The double counting I think arises because the Public Service Board's formula includes some indirect staffing costs in its 85 per cent, whereas the Attorney-General's Department has always been assessing all salaries costs and then looking for non-salary additional elements. We concluded that, short of a proper assessment agency by agency, circumstance by circumstance, a good operating figure is more likely to be in the range of 50-plus to 60-plus per cent than the 85-plus per cent.

The difference between a 50 per cent overhead and an 85 per cent overhead is enormous. Yet the Government is using this type of shonky figure in determining to raise the overall costs. I repeat that this sort of activity results in plus or minus $3m being given in the Bill for the costing of freedom of information. What we spend in this area is a pittance compared with the enormous amounts that the Government spends on advertising and public relations activities in the departments-probably five to ten per cent of total expenditure. Would it not be better to give people the information they want rather than pumping propaganda out at them as is happening through many of the general advertising programs?

A really interesting breakdown that we cannot get is the amount that is spent on internal review processes and how much goes on preparation for Administrative Appeals Tribunal hearings and for various court cases that result from information being refused. In 1984-85, 38 per cent of requests for internal review resulted in extra documents being released. The Government wants to impose a $40 application fee, without refund, for cases in which decisions in the first instance are wrong. They basically must have been wrong if the appeal reverses them. So penalties are being imposed because the Public Service is wrong. No penalties are being applied to departments which try to bluff and to keep their information private rather than disclose it but which disclose material just before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal hearings are about to start. That sort of thing should not occur without some type of disciplinary action of the officers who squander both public and private money through their obstinacy in refusing access to information to people who have a right to it. It is an attitudinal problem within sections of the Public Service. That attitudinal problem starts here, because unless we actually tell public servants that their responsibility is to serve the public, we will not get anywhere in terms of instilling an understanding of and a new attitude towards open government within Australia. It is a policy of the Labor Government to have open government. Mr Hawke campaigned on that policy during the election campaign before last.

One other frightening thing about the legislation is that it attempts to charge for decision-making time. We have heard about the $20 per hour charge for procrastination. I hope that some sort of consolidation of time spent will be made, that we will get some type of report on how this money is charged and some type of statistic on what type of thinking time public servants need. As far as I can see, these public servants are being paid for making up excuses, and people who are good at making up excuses are seldom good at anything else. I will follow through that view during Estimates committee hearings in those areas in which the Australian Democrats perceive that departments are taking an unreasonable approach towards, or are hostile to, freedom of information legislation.

I believe we should note that the Treasury is one of those departments which were singled out in evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Treasury took five hours to search for and retrieve about 30 documents relating to increases in national productivity. It released only two of those documents, one of which was a telex which originated from the Australian Council of Trade Unions. On the other hand, in regard to the same request, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations took two hours to find and retrieve 24 relevant documents and give access to eight of them, which seems to show a much better attitude towards people. I think it should be commended. I wonder what will happen if there is a perceived benefit, in terms of increased charges, from procrastinating over decision-making operations. Departments will see it as serving the Government, as earning money to think up better and bigger excuses because of this $20 charge for each hour. I would like the Minister to justify this particularly heinous charge for which there does not seem to be any justification.

Another area that I want to deal with concerns reporting to parliament. I would like to ask the Minister a question about service-wide collation of figures on the number of requests falling into the personal documents category and the costs of processing those requests. It seems that there will be an exemption for the personal documents category. Currently it is very difficult to extract from any of the statistics that are provided any information about the difference between public interest and personal documents. I would like to know whether, under the new scheme, with the added cost, there will actually be a report to parliament on the information that we are looking for. Will we be able to look separately at the performance of agencies in this area and at the number of documents they actually provide associated with each request?

There is a need, which is not catered for in this Bill, for information about internal review. I would like to know from the Minister whether there will be a service-wide collection of data on the time spent and the costs attributed to internal review processes. What steps will the Government take to counsel agencies with unreasonable costs for internal review or with records of quite bad primary decision-making? It is extremely important that we make certain that we have a reasonably efficient Public Service. FOI has allowed us to do this. Departments fooled the Senate and lied to the Senate, until FOI brought forward certain documents; for example, the Department of Defence in relation to the Army land grab at Cobar. This type of process means that we can keep a reasonable Public Service that will serve the public. If the Government closes all avenues by which people can get truthful information about how government operates, it will turn us more and more into a dictatorship and make it less and less of a responsible system of government.

I feel that it will be extremely important to have decent statistics from all departments on applications to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. What further steps will the Government take to discourage agencies from just toughing it out and only releasing documents at the moment that they reach the doorstep of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal? People are being held up, and large legal costs are being incurred both in the private sector of the community where these documents are required and in the public sector, because of the attitude of senior public servants. I commend to the Government a rethink of these very high charges that it will impose and a rethink of the unreasonable constraints it is putting on people who want information from the Government. It should make certain that, whatever happens as a result of this legislation or as a result of the existing legislation, where it has not been amended, we get statistics on which we can make sensible decisions about the future of freedom of information and decisions about the effectiveness, co-operativeness and efficiency of various parts of the Public Service. I ask the Minister to comment on what type of statistics will be gathered and what type of reporting will be made to parliament on the effects of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986. I will speak first about its origins. It is worth remembering that the present Freedom of Information Act had its origins during the 1977 election campaign, when the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, pressed by a number of Liberals, put in the policy speech that we would introduce freedom of information legislation if we were re-elected. The argument was, of course, the overwhelming importance in a democracy of the public having reasonable access to information held by the Government. After the election the then Prime Minister took steps to implement his policy promise. It is quite obvious that the Public Service thought he was insane to have made such a promise. In the best Yes Minister style, it produced a Freedom of Information Bill which was properly described as a freedom from information Bill, which would ensure that practically no information would get out. What was not made exempt was released only at the discretion of Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: When this Bill reached the Senate I and a number of others voted to have it referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for thorough examination. Four of the six members of that Committee are still serving in the Senate-Senator Puplick and I from the Opposition, and Senator Evans and Senator Tate from the Government. The report of that Committee was decisive in producing an excellent Freedom of Information Act. We recognised the importance of access to information and that the access should be affordable and within the means of people who might want it. I can remember Senator Evans, in particular, waxing extremely eloquent-or perhaps extremely loquacious-on the subject of the importance of these matters. I agreed with him, rather more briefly, about the importance of these matters. What has happened is that there has been a total reversal by this Government of the reasonable access to information held by the Government to the public. Look at what the Government is doing. It is introducing a $30 fee for a request.

TALK.START.PARA: —What don't you oppose it?

—I will come to that in a moment. It is increasing the charge for agency search and retrieval time to $15 an hour, introducing a charge of $20 an hour for agency decision making consultation time, introducing an application fee of $40 for internal review requests-this is not repayable-and reducing the grounds for the remission of charges. The Government claims that these charges will increase revenue by $4m a year. The Opposition is committed to the integrity of the Budget process. The Government is responsible for the economic management of this country and the Budget must be looked at as a whole. Therefore, we are not prepared to oppose a Budget measure that raises revenue when it is part of the budget. That is a matter of principle and one by which we stand.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have no pretensions of being an alternative, or even a possible, government and they do not have such inhibitions. Nevertheless, we believe that the Budget must be looked at as a whole and this measure is properly part of the Budget. However, that does not deal with the fact that this particular Bill deals with a large number of other matters which have nothing to do with the Budget at all. It is also curious that this Bill amends regulations. I think the Government is aware that if it introduces regulations, as it did last year, to raise charges they will probably be rejected by the Senate. So what the Government has done is to introduce amendments to regulations as a Budget Bill. That is an effective tactic but it does not justify the Government in introducing a large number of other extraneous matters which have nothing to do with the Budget.

When our constitution was being framed a great deal of attention was paid to preventing Bills on financial matters having other provisions tacked on to them. Yet that is just what this Bill does. Knowing that we are committed not to resisting, not to opposing a Bill that is integral to the Budget, what the Government has done is put a large number of other provisions, which have nothing to do with the Budget, in this Bill.

I do not for a moment accept the Government's claims of cost savings in the Bill. It could be argued that freedom of information increases efficiency and saves costs in other ways, but the cost savings associated with these measures are not, in any sense, part of the Budget but revenue is. The Government has introduced administrative matters into the Bill. I will give a couple of examples. The Government is maintaining the present 45 day limit on answering requests rather than reducing it to 30 days as it should have. It is strengthening the provisions relating to the refusal of requests on work load grounds-of course, people could work a little harder if they wanted to-and it is reducing obligations relating to published statements and providing statistics. These are all administrative matters which should not in any way be regarded as part of the Budget. It is highly improper of the Government, using the known attitude of the Opposition not to reject Budget Bills, to try to get legislation through by tacking on measures that have nothing to do with the Budget. I will press, and I hope others will support me, that in future Budget Bills are solely concerned with Budget matters and that other issues, which should be debated and probably referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for thorough examination, are presented to the Senate separately. I will be very interested to see how eloquent Senator Evans happens to be on this subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986 does not involve the destruction of freedom of information legislation or the freedom of information concept. It merely involves a modification of some aspects of it for reasons which are defensible by reference to the financial and administrative burdens that the present legislation involves and are defensible by reference to the nature and extent of those burdens at a time of the kind of economic stringency this nation and this Government are currently facing.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand some of the disappointment that has been expressed about this Bill. I share some of that disappointment myself. However, I do not think it was entirely fair of Senator Puplick to construct his entire speech from my previous contributions which are on the public record. What I think needs to be appreciated in understanding why the Government felt it necessary to bring this legislation forward is the way in which costs were exploding, the way in which cost recovery was receding and the way in which this was all happening at a time when there was really a need for very great financial and economic discipline as far as this Government, or any other government, is concerned.

The reality is that the current economic climate warrants a more stringent attitude to cost containment than seemed possible at the time when this legislation was first enacted and first substantially amended. There has been bipartisan support for charges being imposed. The only issue is how much is charged, who actually pays for it and in what circumstances. The basic point-I think it will be appreciated-is that freedom of information is about access to information; it is not about free information. To date, taxpayers have been subsidising FOI applications when many users can afford to pay more than they have been paying. I refer, in particular, to corporate applicants and newspapers which are a particular category of corporate applicant that are very well able to pay more than they have been for access to material.

It needs to be appreciated that less than one per cent of FOI administration costs were recovered in 1984-85. That amounted to $22,000 out of $16.3m and in 1985-86 the figure was around $75,000 out of a total notional figure-the final figures have not yet been precisely calculated-of $15m. Those figures need to be looked at against a background where significant cost recovery, through charges, is accepted in other jurisdictions. For example, in Victoria there is a $20 per hour search and retrieval fee with a maximum of $100 per request. In the United States of America agencies set their own fees with the State Department, for example, setting a $12 per hour search and retrieval fee. In Canada there is a $5 application fee plus charges if processing exceeds five hours.

It needs to be appreciated that the cost recovery experience of other jurisdictions has been substantially greater than hitherto has been the case in Australia. Let me give some comparative figures to make that point clearer. I said that in Australia in 1985-86 the proportion was less than one per cent of cost recovery. In fact, it was just half a per cent on the figures now before me which are as follows: Total requests were 36,580, total costs were $15m in round figures, total charges collected were $75,000, average cost per request was $400 and average revenue per request was $2.08. Compare those figures with the situation in Canada where there were 2,654 requests, total costs were $3.4m, total charges collected were $33,000, average costs per request were $1,242 and average revenue per request was six times that in Australia-$12.46. One per cent of the total cost of running the system was thus recovered. It is not a high proportion but it is a higher amount than that collected in Australia per request. In the United States a considerably higher amount per request is collected in terms of the total proportion. Let me give the Senate the figures: 309,768 requests; total costs of $99.3m; total charges collected, $5.1m; average cost per request $321; and average revenue per request $16.42. The average return per request in the United States, the home of freedom of information of a kind that appeals so much to the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, is $16.42 compared with a figure in Australia of just over $2. It is important to appreciate that there is scope in our system for there to be greater cost recovery. It is legitimate for that to be pursued when one considers the experience of other jurisdictions, quite apart from the particular circumstances of financial stringency in which this Government finds itself at this time, for reasons with which we are all familiar.

The further point I want to make and stress very strongly is one that Senator Vigor mentioned along the way, and that is that a very substantial proportion of applicants for FOI access will not be paying any charges at all because of the very nature of their request being a request for personal documents. Applications for personal documents by whoever they are made will remain totally exempt from charges of any kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the cost of them be calculated and recorded?

—Yes. I think one can make notional estimates of what is involved here. I am happy now to put on the record some figures which demonstrate the order of magnitude of the sacrifice, if you like, that is involved by the Government in continuing to exempt applications of this kind from charges. Material has been prepared for and today submitted to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs by an inter-departmental committee which was set up to report on costs of freedom of information legislation. It has been put to the Committee today-whether it is publicly released is a matter for the Committee--
—Why did you bother? You wasted more money. You are not interested in its report.

—One of the reasons that we are proceeding with the legislation is that so many of the findings in this report confirm the strategies that the Government has here embarked upon, and one such instance is the particular matters which I am now referring to which I am happy to have incorporated in Hansard with the leave of the Senate.
—What is it?

—It is a table from the inter-departmental committee report which has been submitted to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee today which estimates FOI costs for 1985-86 by document type, which breaks it up. I seek leave to have the table incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
