TALK.START.PARA: —The table makes absolutely clear that the requests for 1985-86 that were of a personal document character constituted 73.8 per cent of the total requests that were made and that the total cost associated with the processing of such requests was $4.7m. I have other figures which indicate by contrast the percentage of the requests for other classes of document and the costs and the percentage of the total cost represented by those other classes. For example, business private sector documents made up 6.9 per cent of total requests and $1.4m worth of the total cost figure. Personnel requests made up 12.1 per cent of the total and $1.4m was involved.
—How are they different from personal?

—Personnel requests are from staff. Maybe that has properly added to the number of personal documents. Personnel requests, to the extent that they involve personal documents, would also be exempt from the charge. So that is another $1.4m to add to the $4.7m, making $6.1m out of a total of just under $14m on this calculation and a total of 84 per cent.
—You aren't winning too many friends with your argument. I think you are actually defeating your case.

—On the contrary; what I am demonstrating is that these are all categories of documents and costs which the Commonwealth is acknowledging ought not to be the subject of fee charges at all. By far and away the largest category of users of FOI are people, first, seeking personal documents and, secondly, also for the most part personal documents that are in the category of personnel documents-that is to say, staff members seeking information from agencies about employment matters which will usually involve personal files but which may not involve personal files in every case. But when we compare the figures with law enforcement documents, other business documents, policy documents and internal administration documents-the other classes-we will see by contrast that the percentages are obviously quite small of the total number of requests and in each category the total costs involved are not especially great although in total, of course, they add up to a very substantial saving of the kind that the Government has already indicated that it expects to make from this legislation. What precisely the amount of the saving will be, whether it is $3m, $4m, $5m or whatever, remains to be seen. But it is savings of that order of magnitude. They are significant savings, and they cannot be denied.

SPEECH.PARA: So the basic point remains that the Government is making deliberate cost savings because there has not been sufficient contribution to the revenue from the operation of the system to date. But it is making those cost savings and getting additional cost recovery in areas, which, by and large, involve seekers of information who can afford to pay for it because very often here one is talking about corporate clients. We are not seeking to deny access, to deter access or in any way to discourage access by imposing fees that do not otherwise exist to that large category of people seeking access to personal documents who, on the face of it, are likely to be the group of people who are most likely to suffer if some costs were imposed.

So I think all of those points are important to appreciate in weighing, evaluating and understanding what it is the Government is doing in this legislation. There are many more points that no doubt honourable senators will want to take up at the Committee stage. I will do my best to answer them one by one when we get to them in that context. The only point on which I would conclude, in the light of the explanation and the further information that I have offered, is that with all its modifications, with all the ways in which the Bill has be reshaped in some significant respect by this amendment legislation now before us, it does remain a vital and effective freedom of information legislation of a kind thoroughly deserving that name and description and thoroughly deserving the legitimate pride of this Parliament which gave it birth.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have spent some not very fruitful time today listening to a series of second reading speeches on the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986 from Opposition senators defending the indefensible, justifying their support of the increase in fees that is being introduced in this legislation on the somewhat specious ground that this is somehow a Budget Bill, notwithstanding the fact that Part III of the Freedom of Information Act, which is the most contentious part, at least as far as we are concerned, is substantially merely a rerun of the 1985 regulation which was defeated. How the Opposition can argue that this is, therefore, a Budget Bill simply because it contains some amounts of money, is anybody's guess. I can only assume that it is supporting this legislation in the hope that it will be in government after the next election and will therefore benefit from the quite significant increases in charges that are being introduced in this Bill, as well as a number of other changes.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not insignificant to introduce a $30 application fee for a freedom of information request. It is certainly not insignificant to increase the charge for agency search and retrieval time to $15 an hour. It is not insignificant to many ordinary people to introduce a charge of $20 per hour for agency decision making and consultation time when one considers exactly how that could be abused by agencies and departments wanting to delay providing information. It is by no means insignificant to ordinary people in the community, who want access to information to which they feel entitled to have access, for the Government to introduce an application fee of $40 for internal review requests.

This is not a Budget Bill, whatever the Opposition, led by Senator Puplick from his newly found vantage point of the seat of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, may think. He is indulging in some sort of delusion of grandeur. We have nothing more in this legislation than a rerun of the attempt by the Government to increase charges and impose fees in a regulation that the Opposition parties, to a person, to the best of my knowledge, enthusiastically opposed some 12 months ago.

To make matters more ludicrous, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is currently winding up its inquiry into the operation and administration of the freedom of information legislation that this Federal Government has. The Committee has had about 100 submissions so far and it has heard about 60 witnesses. I understand that it has completed its public hearings and that it is in the process of writing its report. It would seem to me that those are extremely good reasons for this chamber not to proceed with an amending Bill to an Act which is under investigation by one of what I would consider to be the most prestigious committees in this place, and a committee on which Senator Puplick sits. One wonders why, when he is certainly not prepared to take it seriously enough, he cannot put aside this piece of legislation until the report from that Committee has come down.

What we are seeing happen here is something that my colleagues canvassed earlier during the second reading debate, a process of impending access to information to some people who are most in need of it. We have a piece of legislation which purports to provide freedom of information without actually providing the information. The freedom of access is there if one can afford it; the information is not unless one can afford it. I am appalled at the specious and hypocritical reasoning that has been put forward by the Opposition as justification for not opposing those fee increases while it is quite prepared on the other hand to play around with other clauses that do not contain a dollar sign anywhere in them. Consequently it is my intention to move in a moment that the Chair reports progress, which is something not unusual during a Committee stage when further information is required, and that the Committee have leave to sit again only after the presentation of the report by the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I do not think that that is an unreasonable request to be making of this chamber, given that the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee has reached the stage of preparing its report that it is quite likely to bring that report down during this Budget session and that it is ludicrous for us to be looking at ways of changing the administration and operation of the freedom of information legislation when we have not heard what that Committee feels about it. The position of the Democrats on this issue has been made fairly clear during today's debate. That is why I shall move that the Chairman report progress and ask for leave to sit again following the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the operation and administration of the freedom of information legislation. I move:
That the Chairman of Committees report progress and ask leave to sit again.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 1 to 9-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a point in response to a couple of comments made by Senator Haines. While undoubtedly Senator Haines knows a great deal more about the workings of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs than I do-I am a member of that Committee and Senator Haines is not-I think it is appropriate simply to comment that the likelihood of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee being able to report in this Budget session, as has been alleged, is very small. We have not yet concluded all of the hearings that we wished to undertake. As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who is in charge of the legislation, has mentioned, only today have we received the report of the inter-departmental committee, which we have been seeking to assist us in our deliberations. The report will certainly be lengthy. Given the work which is always inherent in the preparing and checking of drafts and the making of final corrections, I do not think that the record should be left unchallenged on the basis that the Committee is near reporting. As a result, the assertions by Senator Haines about the Committee's work can be taken at face value.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement Senator Puplick has made on the inter-departmental committee report as well as his assertion that it will take longer than this Budget session for the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee report to reach this chamber are further proof that the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill ought to be delayed. Senator Puplick makes the admission that those reports are intended to provide this chamber, that is, senators from all parties, with the information needed to help them in their deliberations. Apparently, the honourable senator is quite cheerfully prepared to ignore the fact that we have not had time to pay any sort of attention to the information in the inter-departmental committee report. Nor is he prepared to give us the opportunity even to see the report from the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee which may well come down this session. Even if it does not, it is germane to what is in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: We are making amendments to the operation and administration of freedom of information legislation in Australia. That is the brief that was put before the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. How we can make any properly informed decisions without the sort of information that can be gleaned either from the inter-departmental committee or from the information supplied to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee in the submissions it has received and by the witnesses it has heard I do not know. Senator Puplick may be able to read minds; I have not that capacity. Nor should we in this chamber assume that information is known when it is not. Senator Puplick's concern about my beliefs as to when the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee is likely to report simply justifies our argument that the piece of legislation before us tonight should not be proceeded with while that report is still in abeyance.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 10 (Processing of requests, &c.).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, clause 10, leave out paragraphs (b) and (c).

This is the first of four amendments which have been circulated on behalf of the Opposition. Clause 10 in sub-clauses (b) and (c) seeks to amend section 19 of the principal Act to reduce the automatic reduction of the time limit to 30 days-that to occur after 1 December 1986. Section 19 sub-section (3) provides the mechanism whereby the time within which a request has to be responded to is progressively reduced. Sub-section (3) in its existing form provides:
(a) a case where the request is received before 1 December 1984-60 days;
(b) in a case where a request is received on or after 1 December 1984 but before 1 December 1986-45 days; and
(c) in any other case-30 days.

This is in accordance with the original recommendations of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee that as the bureaucracy became more familiar with the operation of the Freedom of Information Act it should be able to respond in a reduced number of days. Our own experience in the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, as Senator Vigor pointed out in his contribution, is that departments claim that their greater familiarity with the Act is allowing them to shorten the time taken to make a decision and that the effect of the Act on the operations of many departments has been to improve their record-keeping and retrieval systems.

I have already drawn attention to the fact that, when the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee conducted its investigation and reported in 1979, Mr Lionel Bowen, at that stage the Opposition spokesman on Attorney-General matters, made a submission to the Committee saying that the time limit should be 10 days. The Government is now seeking to maintain the 45-day limit and to prevent the automatic reduction of the time to be taken to 30 days. We are opposed to that attempt to require the departments, after 1 December 1986, to respond within a 30-day period. For that reason I have moved the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support this Opposition amendment which means that in this place the numbers are sufficient for the amendment to be carried. This then raises a rather interesting philosophical, not to say practical, point for the Opposition. If this amendment and the other amendments which the Opposition intends to move and which we intend to support are rejected by the Government, the Bill will be returned to the Senate. As everybody in this place knows, for a Bill to become law it has to be passed in exactly the same form by both Houses of the Parliament. If the Government chooses to return the Bill to the Senate, what will the Opposition do then? Will it cave in-which would certainly be consistent with its behaviour to date-or will it press the amendment and insist on the changes that it wants to make to clause 10-the amendment that Senator Puplick has just moved-and the amendments that it wants to move to clauses 11, 13 and 14 a little later? If it does press them, it will delay the Bill-one of the sacrosanct Budget Bills that this Opposition enthusiastically supports while deploring the contents. If it delays the Budget Bill it has produced the grounds for a double dissolution and all its high sounding rhetoric about not interfering with the Government's Budget has gone down the proverbial gurgler.

SPEECH.PARA: So I hope for the Opposition's sake that the Minister here tonight, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), will prevail on the Government graciously to accept this Bill in its amended form. Otherwise it will be doing Opposition members a terrible injury in forcing people outside, as well as itself, to realise that they are-I suppose that `hypocrites' is an unparliamentary term. I am sure that there is a suitable alternative; I just cannot think of it at the moment. The Democrats will be supporting the Opposition's amendment to clause 10, as I foreshadow we will be doing in regard to the amendments it has circulated in relation to clauses 11, 13 and 14. I will await with bated breath the Government's reaction to all of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the few pleasures I have in piloting the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill through the Parliament is watching the Australian Democrats and the Opposition working themselves into a lather attacking each other for their attitudes to this legislation and the procedures associated with it.

—No, you have it all wrong. They attacked you for the content of the Bill but they are supporting it. I am attacking them quite cheerfully for not opposing the Bill when they are opposing its contents.

—Everyone is attacking everyone else but the only ones who are doing it with any passion are the Democrats and the Opposition. That is giving me my sole pleasure in the conduct of this legislation. I do not know what the Government's attitude will be if the Bill is amended. That is a matter for the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Government to decide. I will convey the circumstances of this exchange and whatever happens during the evening to these amendments and the Government will no doubt make the decision that is appropriate in all the circumstances as a result. As to the substance of the amendment now before us, it is designed to ensure that the present statutory response time of 45 days to 30 days-I am sorry; let me start again. I am getting very tired.
—No wonder you do not have any passion.

—I told the honourable senator I was not very passionate about this; I cannot afford to be. The Act presently provides that on 1 December the present 45-day time limit will be reduced to 30 days. The Bill now before us is designed to maintain the 45-day period intact.
—We have worked that out.

—That is true. It is now sought to retain the status quo, which is not really the status quo but which will be the status quo on 1 December. The Government wants to keep the time limit at 45 days. It does not want to reduce it to 30 days. The reason is that the way the system is being administered at the moment, only 54 per cent of requests are met within a 30-day deadline and 46 per cent of them would overrun. Substantial additional administrative costs would be involved in meeting that earlier deadline in an economic and financial environment where it would be very difficult to meet the burden of such additional costs. It ought to be appreciated in particular that a 30-day deadline would sharply increase Administrative Appeals Tribunal reviews which are invariably costly because a deadline overrun gives an automatic right of appeal. It needs to be appreciated further that overruns have been due to increased demand and the complexity of requests rather than any inefficiency in the system.

SPEECH.PARA: Productivity has increased since the legislation has been in force. I am told that eight staff days per request was the situation in 1982-83. We are down to 1.9 staff days per request now. But while the great bulk of requests can clearly be accommodated within quite narrow time frames, many requests, particularly those with any complexity at all, cannot be met within that timeframe. It is for those reasons that what was originally the aspiration, certainly, of the Government that we would be able to move to a 30-day period, has been unable to be realised and why we want to maintain the Bill in the form in which it has been moved by the Government. I regret that the Opposition is not supporting the Government's position.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 11 (Requests may be refused in certain cases).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of clause 11 is to establish a new regime to be known as multi-document requests. At present under the Act people administering it may treat a series of related requests for documents as if they were one request. The authority for that is to be found in the decision of Sir William Prentice in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision on Shewcroft's case. Nevertheless, the Government now proposes to bring together this regime so that multi-document requests may be determined by the authority to whom the request is initially made. The Minister or agency may determine that to meet the request would be a substantial burden upon the department, would substantially divert the resources of the agency from its other operations, would interfere substantially with the performance by the Minister of the Minister's functions, or would result in substantial delays in dealing with other requests.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to traverse the ground I went over in my speech during the second reading debate on the question of the meaning of the words `unreasonably divert' because other matters are to be brought forward. The first, and perhaps the most important of these matters, arises by way of example. The example I give is the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence entitled `Land Acquisition in New South Wales by the Australian Army-First Report'. During the Committee's investigation the Department of Defence sought to conceal documents from the Senate Committee and from requesters in general. It did so by claiming that the requests which had been made to it by the No Base Central Tablelands Association, I think taken together rather than as individual requests, imposed upon the Department an unreasonable burden in asking for all documents relating to the event. It claimed that this was an unreasonable burden and that the requests should not be acceded to. Eventually, after a great deal of legal and political pressure, the Department of Defence was forced to cave-in. The Chairman of the Committee, Senator McIntosh, who is in the chamber this evening, will recall the words on page xviii under the heading `Conduct of the Department of Defence'. It states:

The Committee is not satisfied that the Department of Defence has co-operated fully or openly with this inquiry. Throughout the inquiry, material obtained from the Department under the Freedom of Information (FOI) Act by interest groups opposing the proposals repeatedly contradicted or undermined evidence presented to the Committee by Departmental witnesses.

In other words, the Department of Defence was shown, by the documents obtained under freedom of information legislation, to have failed to co-operate fully and properly with the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. The Department was rightly called to account by the Committee on that occasion. But had this particular piece of legislation been in operation at the time, the Department of Defence would have been able to claim that the multi-document request being made by the No Base Central Tablelands Association had the effect of substantially diverting the resources of the agency from its other operations and it would have been able to use that as a blanket refusal mechanism for the documentation which, when it eventually got out and got into the hands of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, demonstrated the extent to which the Department of Defence was involved in a deliberate cover-up and a deliberate attempt to mislead the Parliament.

I give that as one example, and one example only, of the effect that had this piece of legislation been in place at the time the Senate Committee was at work on this reference, its activities would have been frustrated. The other point to which I draw attention is the report of the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills which was tabled only an hour or so ago in this chamber. Fortuitously, the report came in tonight and under the heading `Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986', the Committee comes to the conclusion that clause 11 would amend section 24 of the Principal Act in a way which would have a retrospective effect. The Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills has taken evidence from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). The Attorney-General had this matter drawn to his attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure that it was actually tabled?

—It was tabled by Senator Robertson on behalf of Senator Tate earlier this evening. I am in enough trouble without getting hanged for contempt if the document in fact has not been properly tabled. Nevertheless, the Attorney-General responded to the Committee and the Committee analysed what the Attorney-General had to say and concluded that, even after it had examined the Attorney-General's response, and I quote from page 73:

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly the Committee continues to draw new paragraph 24 (1a) (b) to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (i) in that, by reason of its retrospective application, it may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.
I will not go into the Orwellian text of the Attorney-General's letter, which at one stage supports the proposed amendment and rejects the criticisms of clause 24. It reads:
The diversion of resources caused by these requests impacts chiefly on other FOI applicants whose requests are considerate of resource requirements.

What that piece of newspeak actually means is fairly mind-boggling, but undoubtedly Senator Gareth Evans, with his usual erudition, will be able to sort that out. I therefore indicate that the consequences of this amendment will be that every department whose filing system is in disarray will be able to use this is as a mechanism to refuse almost every FOI request. Therefore, every multi-document request can basically be treated in this contemptuous fashion because it can be argued that any request will cause the department, agency or Minister concerned to bring about delays in dealing with other requests. By the very nature of the application, of course, it will cause delays in something else occurring. As a result, clause 11 provides this extraordinary new blanket amendment.

Two points upon which I principally rely, therefore, are the Scrutiny of Bills Committee comment about the retrospective nature of this-in other words, that there will be a capacity to aggregate documents already in the system, which have not yet been determined, with documents arriving in the system after the legislation comes into effect in order to claim that they are part of the multi-document request, therefore prejudicing the status of requests already in process-and secondly, that we have a clear example in the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in relation to the land acquisition matter that had this exemption been in place, very valuable information would have been withheld, both from the affected persons and from the Senate Committee, and that the Committee would not have been in a position to expose the maladministration and the cover-up that the Department of Defence was engaged in on that particular occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated a moment ago, the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Opposition in relation to clause 11, substantially for the same sorts of reasons that Senator Puplick has just outlined. Essentially, passage of this clause would mean that departments would be able to exploit the situation that would then obtain and effectively deny access where they did not want their processes open to public examination. Quite frankly, that flies significantly in the face of what this legislation is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, the concerns that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills raised with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) were answered in part. The Attorney-General was able to satisfy the Committee reasonably about the concern that it raised with regard to a non-reviewable decision. The Attorney-General's response, while somewhat prolix, placated the Committee sufficiently for it to say in its digest of today that the Attorney had in his response answered the Committee's concerns in relation to that aspect of the new section 24 that is to be established under clause 11 of this Bill. The concern, as I said, related to the fact that the Committee was concerned that although a decision to refuse to grant access to a document was subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, such review might not extend to a decision under paragraph 24 (1a) (b), that a request was one of a series of related requests and therefore was a multi-document request for the purposes of sub-section 24 (1).

The question of possible retrospectivity was not so satisfactorily answered and the Committee has continued in this report to draw to the attention of the Senate, as Senator Puplick indicated, its belief that under principle 1 (a) (i) of its terms of reference, the new paragraph 24 (1a) (b) could, by reason of its retrospective application, be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. The Democrats, therefore, are happy to support the Opposition in moving for the deletion of clause 11. Given the enthusiastic support that the Government has given for including this clause in the legislation, I will be fascinated to see just exactly what it does when confronted with the fact that a fairly significant clause it obviously placed in there after due consideration has been deleted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again regret that the Australian Democrats and the Opposition have chosen to combine forces to assault this particular worthy amendment that is proposed by the Government. The amendment is proposed at a time of Budget constraints, I repeat again, to meet resource problems--
—That is a tautology even for this time of the night.

—No, I have repeated it before and now I am repeating it again. It is not a tautology at all. Eat your heart out Rex Mossop, or Alex Buzo, or both. It is to handle a few exceptionally large and costly requests. They are the only ones with which there are significant resource problems. But these sorts of cases do arise.
—How many is a few?

—That remains to be seen. Many are called but few are chosen. Senator Haines is familiar with the distinction. Laurence Maher, a Melbourne solicitor, a friend of mine, sought documents relating to the Westinghouse anti-trust settlement. The cost to the Government was $80,000. The cost to Conzinc Riotinto of Australia, the private company involved in resisting that application, was another $120,000.
—If it had not resisted, it would not have cost so much.

—That is a perfectly understandable response but not one that necessarily appeals to the Government at a time of financial stringency, particularly when it must be appreciated that the merits of the particular application were subsequently held to be not especially great so far as legislation was concerned, and Mr Maher failed in his various attempts before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to override the claims of exemption that were made by the Commonwealth. Contemplate this: Mr Kevin Newman, a former Liberal member of parliament, sought documents on every overseas travel item involving Ministers of the Crown. Over 10,000 items were involved, adding up to 170 days work in processing. The cost to the community was $43,000. In the Swiss aluminium case an Australian alumina exporter sought documents justifying a substantial tax assessment that was made. The cost of that application to 30 June this year has been over $60,000 for the Commissioner of Taxation alone. There is a separate matter involving the Department of Trade which is now before the High Court of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that a number of applications are being made that on the face of it involve very substantial burdens and impositions upon Government departments. This clause, of course, would not operate to strike out applications in any way automatically simply because they are burdensome in terms of the time involved. This is an entirely discretionary provision for the agencies and obviously one that would be relied upon only in circumstances in which costs and the burden involved were so substantial as to be unconscionable. Agencies will have to publicly justify their resources judgments and decisions to the Ombudsman and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Obstinate officials can and will continue to be exposed by the ground rules that will continue to exist under this legislation if this amendment is passed, as we hope it is.

The other point that was made in relation to this clause went to the concerns of the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills, alleged claims of retrospectivity and goodness knows what else in the way in which this document was framed. It needs to be appreciated that it is in only a very limited context that this alleged issue of retrospectivity arises and that is where the claim in question is part of a series of related requests, processing of which series of requests is not completed before the commencement of the legislation. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in his communication to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee did not accept that there was any breach of the basic principles that are applicable in these circumstances. His argument is set out in a thoroughly detailed, logical and cogent document. Whether it is thought to justify the description that Senator Puplick offered of it of Orwellian newspeak is something that I leave to this Committee to judge for itself. The best way of ensuring that the record is complete and that the Government's position on this is understood is for me to simply seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the text of the Attorney's letter and I so apply.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER
ATTORNEY-GENERAL
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Michael,

The Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 12 of 1986 raises two concerns about clause 11 of the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986. Both relate to new paragraph 24 (1a) (b) of the Freedom of Information Act proposed by clause 11 of the Bill.

The first concern is that a request made before the new s.24 comes into force might be able to be rejected by reason of its aggregation with other post-amendment requests for the purpose of applying the ``multi-document request'' ground for refusal of access. The effect of s.8 of the Acts Interpretation Act in relation to the proposal to replace s.24 with a new provision is that existing rights under the present s.24 will not be affected except to the extent that express provision is made to the contrary. Such express provision is, in my view, made in proposed new s.24 to the limited extent that undecided requests extant at the date of commencement of that section will be able to be dealt with under that provision where they are part of a series of related requests which is not completed before commencement. Other requests extant at that date will continue to fall to be considered under existing s.24 to the extent that that section was applicable before commencement to that request.

I am able to confirm that it is the Government's intention that new s.24 should so apply. However, I do not consider that the new s.24, in giving effect to that intention, will unduly trespass on existing rights because:
experience indicates that only a small number of requests will be affected;

those requests are, in the main, in the nature of ambit claims, ``fishing expeditions'' and the like which make disproportionate demands on the limited resources available to meet requests made under the Act;
the diversion of resources caused by these requests impacts chiefly on other FOI applicants whose requests are considerate of resources requirements;
for these reasons the amendment is being proposed at a time of Budget constraints in order to meet a resources problem in handling a few exceptionally large and costly requests;
the s.24 (3) obligation on agencies to consult with an applicant and provide an opportunity to remove grounds for refusal will continue unaffected;

the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has already recognised that agencies are entitled to aggregate related requests for the purpose of applying existing s.24 (1): see Re Shewcroft and Australian Broadcasting Corporation (1985) 7 ALN N307; and

where a series of related requests is not completed until after commencement the total workload will not be clear until then and, moreover, there would be difficulty in dealing with different requests in the series on different criteria;

the s.24 provision is discretionary and agencies will be instructed to apply it to existing requests in only the clearest cases (e.g. not where an applicant has already been advised that a request will be processed).

The Committee's second concern is that some aspects of the decision to refuse access under new s.24 may involve unreviewable administrative decisions. There is no basis for this concern. Sub-section 58 (1) of the Act supplements s.43 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act to confer on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal very broad powers to review any decision that has been made in respect of a request and to decide any matter in relation to the request that could have been or could be decided under the Act by the agency or Minister concerned. The terms of these provisions are sufficiently broad to embrace all relevant aspects of a decision to refuse access under new s.24.
I trust the foregoing will allay the concerns of the Committee.
Yours sincerely,
(Lionel Bowen)
Senator Michael Tate,
Chairman,
Senate Standing Committee for the
Scrutiny of Bills,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA. A.C.T. 2600

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. Against that background, I believe the amendment is perfectly defensible in concept and in drafting and I commend it accordingly to the Committee, even though in a spirit of philosophical appreciation that that commendation is unlikely to prove effective.

—I have a question to ask Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister representing the Attorney-General. He indicated that the provision is to stop if not frivolous requests at least ones that require a great deal of time and effort on the part of the departments concerned and hence a great deal of cost. Firstly, I would like to know how the departments know before they have started the search how long it will take and hence what the cost will be. Is there some little flag on the sort of requests that are likely to be made that indicates beforehand that a request will be lengthy and hence costly? Secondly, since I am quite sure that Senator Gareth Evans knows far more about the American freedom of information legislation than I do, can he indicate whether there are any circumstances in Australia in which a situation which I understand exists in the United States of America could also apply here-that is, the applicant being let loose among the files to find the information that he or she is seeking? I understand that that provision exists in some circumstances in America. I am not particularly clear what are the circumstances in which that can be done or what restrictions are placed on access to what files. I would be interested in the Minister's response firstly on the mind-reading exercise that apparently goes on to work out whether a request will be lengthy and expensive and, secondly, the possibility of introducing something similar to the process that I understand applies in some circumstances in the United States of allowing the applicant access to relevant files in order for him or her to find the information that is required. I am happy if the Minister wants to leave his reply until a little later.

—I might need to take the second question, about the United States of America experience, on notice. As to the first one, if there is one thing public servants are usually pretty good at it is identifying whether a particular task is likely to prove lengthy and burdensome.
—On whose definition though?
—I think the concept is familiar to them. One hopes that it is.
—I mean, what is burdensome to one public servant may not be to another or even to the applicant.

—What mostly matters is how the request relates to the circumstances not so much of the energy and hormonal zest of a particular public servant but, rather, the circumstances of a particular agency or the office that is concerned. What might constitute a minor diversion of a single employee for a very large agency which could well afford to have a single employee occupied for three or four days on a particular task might for a very small agency be a thoroughly unconscionable disruption for the same job length to occur in that context. If it is a small agency with a handful of personnel and the job involves four of five full staff days, for example, to process a particular request and the judgment is made that the job is likely to be of that order of magnitude-judgments of that kind can be made in prospect after very quick scrutiny of the state of files and the nature of the request-the substantial burden of that test would appear to be potentially satisfied, bearing in mind always that it is not an automatic test but one that is within the discretion of the agency concerned and the subject to review and appeal if the agency abuses its position. The test, as we see it, will be simply whether the likely total work in dealing with the request would substantially divert the resources of the agency from its other operations, whether it would substantially interfere with the performance by the Minister of the Minister's functions or whether it would result in substantial delays in dealing with other requests. I think it is probably the first of those that is likely, in practice, to prove to be the most significant.
—It is a pretty subjective judgment.

—It is a subjective test. All of these things are subjective. But if one tries to build in objectivity in terms of numbers of days and so on and use a test of that kind it may be one that will operate in a far more restrictive way in practice than an open ended, more subjective looking test like this. Senator Haines asked whether an applicant in Australia can be let loose among files to find out what he wants. The answer is not under FOI. Under the Archives Act one could get special access rules if the records are with Archives, but usually only for documents of a significant age. I think Senator Haines asked me something else as well with reference to the United States.

—I did not ask the Minister that. I thank him for reading the note from his advisers, but either they mis- heard me or I was not terribly clear. Since I said it twice, I suspect that the former was the case. I want to know whether there is any potential for introducing something similar to that which applies in the United States. I do not want to know whether it exists in Australia. I was aware that it did not exist under FOI. I want to know whether the Government has given any consideration to whether there is any potential for something similar to happen, so that an applicant can be let loose, among files, as apparently happens under certain circumstances in the United States.
—If it does not exist now, the potential obviously is there for it to exist in the future.
—That is going to get over your clause 11 problem, isn't it?

—To the extent that there are precedents for this sort of thing under the Archives Act, it may be a procedure which would have some potential application. Clearly, by definition almost, if one is talking about sensitive classes of documents, in respect of which there may be claims of exemption, to let someone loose among the files in question with an opportunity to see them before the claim for exemption can be put in train, would be completely to undermine the practical utility of the avenue of exemption.
—Sir Humphrey would love you.

—He would not even mind my language actually, not to mention the concepts that I am advancing. I am improving; this is what happens when one has been a Minister for 3 1/2 years. I am afraid that that is the best I can do and Senator Haines will have to like it or lump it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to this discussion-I will not call it a debate-over the hours that it has been continuing. I feel that it is time to explain what happens in the United States, because I was very familiar with the system and I had great occasion to use it. I ran an environmental law group. In the United States freedom of information is the one thing that allows people like Ralph Nader to operate. Ralph Nader could not make a living in Australia because there is no freedom of information here, as we would understand it in the United States. As to the matter of letting people loose among files, this does happen. I was a lecturer at the University of California at Santa Barbara. I taught environmental defence courses. I often had my students combing through files. We were very interested in the Santa Barbara oil spill. Under the freedom of information Act my students were allowed to go through the filing cabinets of the United States Geological Survey and, in so doing, discovered that there was a variance in the drilling program which was granted by the USGS, which eventually ended up in a court case.
—I bet that they were not allowed back after that.

—Yes, they were allowed back, and the bureaucrats welcomed them back, for the reason that if one has freedom of information the bureaucrats have no worries. They do not have to worry about leaks; they do not have to worry about their necks being on the line. If there is true freedom of information, the bureaucrats are quite happy to give the people what they have paid for. It is the people's information; it is not the Minister's. I notice he is laughing. It is not the bureaucrats' information; it is the people's. They paid for it. They deserve to have access to it. The Minister and his Government are denying access to the people's own information. Frankly, I am ashamed of them.
—Or making us pay for it.

—Making us pay doubly for it. We pay for its collection in our taxes and we pay again when we want to see what it is. I think it is actually unworthy of this Government to go back once again on its policies and promises and make what little freedom of information we have available more unavailable by pricing it out of the market-place. Sooner or later the only people who will be able to afford freedom of information will be CRA Ltd and the multinationals. The transnationals will know what is going on in this country, but the people will not. That will be to the detriment of our society.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause negatived.
Clause 12 agreed to.
Clauses 13 and 14-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 5, clause 13, leave out paragraph (b), insert the following paragraph:
`(b) by inserting in paragraph (3) (b) ``or a person on whose behalf the application was made'' after ``applicant'' (second occurring).'.
(4) Page 6, clause 14, proposed new paragraph 30a (1) (b)-
(a) sub-paragraph (i), leave out `and' at the end of the sub-paragraph; and
(b) after sub-paragraph (ii), insert the following word and sub-paragraph:
`or (iii) the giving of access is in the general public interest or in the interest of a substantial section of the public,'.

These two amendments essentially strengthen provisions whereby fees may be waived in the public interest. I am not anxious to detain the Committee overly long this evening. I think there is a prospect of dealing with the legislation this evening. Amendment No. 3 seeks to leave out paragraph (b), as proposed by the Government, and to insert in paragraph 3 (b) of the original legislation the words `or a person on whose be- half the application was made'. That paragraph would require the Minister to take into account-and I quote the words that would be used in the amended form-`whether the document to which the applicant seeks access relates to the personal affairs of the applicant or a person on whose behalf the application was made'. It then continues. That is the status which would allow the Minister or agency to remit charges for people making applications on behalf of another.

The second amendment, to page 6, clause 14, adds a new paragraph 30a (1) (b) which, by strengthening the public interest amendments, will provide, in the words of the last part of that amendment, `where the giving of access is in the general public interest or in the interest of a substantial section of the public, then a capacity exists for a Minister or agency to waive the charges'. The original Senate Committee and Senator Evans in his comments were strongest when they stated that there ought to be a considerable strengthening of the public interest test throughout the whole legislation. Senator Evans has done a most extraordinary volte face on this matter. He has changed clothes so much on this that he reminds me of a political transvestite. But the whole approach that is being launched into as far as this is concerned is quite undesirable. The two amendments, taken together, that have been moved by the Opposition will streng- then the capacity of Ministers or agencies to reduce or waive fees where the interests of a person who is being assisted by somebody else in the seek of information or where the interests of the public in general, or a substantial section of the public, are involved. I think that that is very much in accordance with the spirit of the freedom of information legislation and very much in accordance with the principles which the Senate Committee and Senator Evans in an earlier incarnation advocated with such strength and force, and about which the Opposition remains entirely persuaded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate on behalf of the Australian Democrats that we will be supporting the Opposition amendment. The points I made on the public interest clause in my speech at the second reading stage do not need to be repeated but I strongly support the matter raised by Senator Puplick. The extremely strong recommendation in the original report to which he referred of strengthening that public interest clause is an essential part of this operation. I can but reiterate the point that this measure is an extraordinary departure from that very important first principle that was enunciated in that report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleague Senator Macklin and follow on by asking for some undertaking from the Minister that we will be able to get figures broken down into categories on how much will be spent annually on the internal review processes associated with each of these amendments. Obviously, this amendment will produce a new category under which it will be useful to get statistics. I believe that it is extremely important that those running the country know exactly what is happening. To be able to handle this type of legislation we should know about the usage of these FOI facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Will additional data be collected now that an application fee is about to be imposed? In what circumstances will agencies, which have bad primary decision making records-that is, which have to take decisions to various appeal processes-be taken to task within the administrative operations of the Government? Will any figures be produced on the cost of preparing cases for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and higher court proceedings? At some point during the Committee stage of the debate we would like an undertaking from the Minister that such statistics will be available well beyond those that have been incorporated to date. I would like to know what action is being taken against departments that have released documents virtually on the door step of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and that have basically cost both the public and private sectors a lot of money. If the Minister could give us some indications on these matters, it would be useful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to Senator Vigor's set of questions about the sorts of statistics and data the Government intends keeping on the costs of doing various things, running appeals and so on, it is the Government's intention, as I understand it, to gather data and to continue gathering data on most, if not all, of the particular matters to which Senator Vigor referred. I do not think we want to accept that as a mandatory obligation nor would I wish to give any firm undertaking in that respect until the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has had an opportunity to fully appreciate what might be involved in Senator Vigor's question.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a desire, as there has been in the past, to keep the maximum amount of information about the way the system is working and the costs that are being incurred in relation to it and I give him that assurance that that objective will continue. Implicit within the collection of such data is, obviously, continued close supervision by the Attorney-General's Department of the way in which the system is being administered by the other agencies and that implies a degree of discipline over the way in which the system is being operated. There are, of course, extensive guidelines prepared by the Attorney-General's Department governing the way in which various classes of decisions are made. One would hope that the Freedom of Information Act continues to be applied in a flexible spirit and one that genuinely reflects the open access spirit of the whole legislation.

The only points I want to make in defence of the existing amendment and in rejection of the Opposition proposal to qualify it is that while it is the case that the public interest criterion is being removed as a mandatory criterion for the remission of charges, it is still to be a relevant consideration for the purposes of most parts of the operation of the legislation. An agency failing to properly consider public interest considerations, where that is relevant, would be open to investigation by the Ombudsman and correction by the Federal Court of Australia under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. I believe that under those circumstances removal of the mandatory public interest criteria, which is here involved, is not something that is challengeable or colourable in the way that has been alleged by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. Accordingly, I urge them, with no greater prospect of likely success than has been the case in the past, not to proceed with their demolition of this part of the legislation but to accept it in the spirit in which it is offered and to vote for the Government amendment.
Amendments agreed to.
Clauses, as amended, agreed to.
Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, noting Australia's rising inflation, increasing unemployment, worsening balance of payments crisis, record interest rates and declining investment--
(a) deplores the confusion created by the misleading and contradictory statements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the state of the Australian economy and calls on the Federal Government to:
(i) reduce the record spending budgeted for this year,
(ii) restructure the industrial relations system as recommended by the Federal Opposition,
(iii) reduce the heavy burden of Government regulation, and
(iv) abandon its damaging anti-business taxes; and
(b) condemns the Treasurer for trying to paper over these defects by reverting to his old habit of falsely talking-up the economy.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 March 1985 the Senate agreed to become part of a joint committee to inquire into certain matters relating to video material. This followed considerable debate in this chamber on the setting up of a Senate committee to inquire into similar matters. The Joint Select Committee on Video Material was set up to inquire into such matters as the effectiveness of certain legislation which had been introduced in relation to the classification of video material and, in particular, X-rated videos and their importation. It was to inquire into whether the present classification system was adequate, whether video retailers were observing the conditions of sale or hire for X-classified material, whether this material was being made available contrary to the law to people under the age of 18 years, whether the regulations were adequate to identify the categories of prohibited material and a number of other things.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to suggest that these things were urgent at the time the Committee was set up. Some 17 months have passed and we have heard nothing from that Joint Committee. I am wondering whether there is any way, Mr President, whereby you could inquire of the Chairman of that Committee just when we are going to get a report, because these are important matters. X-rated videos are banned in all states of Australia and as a result the Australian Capital Territory now is the mail order capital for X-rated videos.

We asked for a moritorium on the sale of X-rated videos so that they could be banned until the Committee reported, but the Minister conscientiously and consistently refused to have anything to do with that. So the fact is that X-rated videos have been available from the Australian Capital Territory. I am not suggesting that they are being made available to people who should not be getting them or that the police are not policing their distribution. However, the matter came up again the other day when I received a telephone call from the proprietor of a video shop. This man told me that he had been contacted by the Australian Taxation Office. He was asked a number of questions in respect of the operation of the fringe benefits tax. He was asked whether or not he ever looked at any of the videos himself or took them home. He was told that if he did he would be required to pay a fringe benefits tax based on the value of any such video.

Any self-respecting video proprietor who has material in his shop which is classified by someone else but in relation to which he bears the legal responsibility for the contents must look at the material particularly if it is hired to customers under 18 years of age. He has an obligation to see what is in the video. We all know that videos classified as other than X-rated have contained material at the beginning or the end of the tape that advertises X-rated videos. For the Taxation Office to go around suggesting to video shop proprietors that they cannot look at the material without paying a fringe benefits tax must surely border on the absurd.

Questions have been asked here and in the other place about the review that is to be undertaken of the unexpected consequences of this legislation. We do not yet know how anybody can make a submission to this inquiry, how it will be carried out, when the inquiry will be finalised and when the changes will be made. On 9 October the Prime Minister said:

I have indicated that there will be a review of the sort that I have talked about. If anyone wishes to bring forward anything through the consultative process in which we will engage, he will be able to do so.
Presumably when he said that, he also meant, of course, that she will be able to do so as well, but we have not had any details of how the consultative process is to take place.

Tonight I particularly want to refer to the situation that I mentioned of the proprietor of a video shop being told that if he takes a video home to look at a fringe benefits tax must be paid. I say that he has a responsibility to look at his videos. He has the legal responsibility to see that what he lets out of his shop in fact complies with the law and that he is not in breach of the law in any way. I suggest to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who is in the chamber at present, that he assist in trying to ensure that the video committee that was set up on 19 March 1985 presents a report. We are entitled to know the stage its inquiries have reached. I think we are entitled to have a report in view of the seriousness of the matters that we are looking into.

I certainly hope that someone will talk to the Taxation Office about whether or not it is really on the right track when it starts asking these sorts of absurd questions which go to the heart of something as serious as a man's responsibility for running his business, when he is hiring videos and is legally responsible for the consequences of what he is in fact hiring. This obviously is a matter which needs to be reviewed. However, I would really suggest that it does not need to be reviewed because it is just too absurd to contemplate. However, hopefully, amongst all the absurdities of the fringe benefits tax, this one will be ironed out. Mr President, I would like you to find out when the Committee will present its report because I think it is time we knew a bit more about this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to give a very short resume of a letter that recently fell into my hands. Anyone who is in any doubt about the sorry state of business and especially agriculture should read that letter. The letter was forwarded just before the Budget session by a farmer who was finding it difficult to pay an account. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sirs,
With the end of the financial year and the coming Budget in our minds we submit the following heart rending story:-
In reply to your request to send a cheque in payment of my account, I wish to inform you that the wolf is at my door and the present frame of mind of my bank manager makes it almost impossible.
My shattered financial position is a result of federal laws, State laws, outlaws and mother-in-laws.

Through these laws I am compelled to pay workers' compensation, payroll tax, group tax, road tax, sales tax, excise tax and, in the unlikely event of my making any profit, I have provisional tax and, last but not least, income tax and fringe benefits tax.

For my family and business protection, I have to carry life insurance, public liability, burglary insurance, accident insurance, old age insurance and Medicare private insurance. I am required to get a firearms licence, driver's licence, dog licence, not to mention a marriage licence.

My business is so governed that it's no easy matter for me to find out who owns it. I am inspected, expected, suspected, disrespected, rejected, dejected, examined, re-examined, informed, required, summonsed, fined, commanded and compelled so that I provide an inexhaustible supply of money for all Government bureaucracy.
I can tell you honestly that except for the miracle that happened, you would not be finding my cheque enclosed.
The wolf that was at my door had pups in the kitchen. I was able to sell them and, so I survive another week in this rat race called business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I think the only appropriate response to Senator Brownhill's contribution is a long drawn out groan. That sort of document was doing the rounds when my grandmother was a girl. I think that the attempted addition of a topical reference to fringe benefits tax is about the only relevance that that has to anything that is conceivably happening in the real world. I was fascinated with Senator Brownhill's obvious concern about the requirement for people to have marriage licences. I am sure that that particular aspect of his contribution tonight will go down well in a family oriented and marriage enthusiastic party like his own.

SPEECH.PARA: But apart from all that, we had Senator Reid's contribution about pornographic videos, a familiar and recurring theme in Senator Reid's contributions to this place. I do not think it is appropriate that a Minister should be asked to comment on the progress of a committee. In fact, I am not even sure whether the honourable senator was asking me or the President to pursue this matter. But it is a parliamentary committee that has been established to look at the question of the way in which X-rated video systems are operating in the Australian Capital Territory. It is a committee on which the Liberal Party of Australia-Senator Reid's own party-is represented. I suggest that she devote her attention not so much to raising this endlessly on the adjournment but stirring her colleagues into life and producing the report that she is so keen to have. As to the question of the possible application of the fringe benefits tax to a circumstance where someone is, in the course of business but out of hours, scrutinising the content of a particular film for its legality or suitability for hire, obviously there is no question under those circumstances of anything remotely resembling a fringe benefits tax being applicable. If it is a matter of the stock of a video retailer or cinema distributor being available for home consumption as part of the perks of the job, I suppose that might give rise to questions of that kind in particular circumstances. But it all depends on the circumstances. I think that here, as elsewhere, common sense will prevail within the Australian Taxation Office in the administration of this measure. But beyond that, Mr President, I suggest we all go home.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.40 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 16 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When does the Minister for Aviation expect a decision will be made on the upgrading of the pavements at the Tennant Creek airport.
(2) Can the Minister say how his conclusion was reached, given the Minister's statement of 6 June 1986 that aircraft movements at the aerodrome were not sufficient to justify the upgrade.
(3) What studies have been or will be undertaken prior to any decision on the availability of the present operations of F28's into the airport.

(4) Is the Minister aware that Ansett which operates the F28 service into Tennant Creek regards it as a commercially viable operation; if so, how does the Minister justify his statement that it is difficult to justify expenditure on the aerodrome, when to fail to do so will lead to the curtailment of a profitable remote area airline service, in the face of airline, passenger, local and Territory Government opposition.
(5) What work has been done on the pavements of the airport since the Minister's press release was issued on 6 June 1986, promising immediate action to improve the condition of the pavements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A decision that the Commonwealth would take immediate action to improve aircraft pavements at Tennant Creek to ensure continuation of reliable air services was announced on 6 June 1986 by the Minister for Aviation.

(2) In his statement of 6 June 1986, the Minister commented that the Tennant Creek Council had sought works costing $4.5m as a condition of transfer of the aerodrome under the Commonwealth's Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan. That estimate was based on F28 standard of operation and it was in this regard that the level of expenditure was difficult to justify.
(3) The future of F28 operations is the subject of a review currently being conducted jointly by the Department of Aviation, the Northern Territory Government and the Tennant Creek Council.

(4) Because of Tennant Creek's small population, the low numbers of aircraft movements and passenger loadings, expenditure of public money to provide for F28 services does not appear justified. The Minister, however, is satisfied that the allocation of $1m of public money to provide upgrading of the aerodrome to commuter aircraft standard is warranted.

(5) Following the Minister's announcement of 6 June 1986, the Department of Aviation immediately commenced the preparation of a planned scope of works to reinstate pavements at the Tennant Creek Aerodrome. That has now been completed and the resultant proposal has been forwarded to the Department of Housing and Construction. It is anticipated that a contract will be let by mid-October 1986 for upgrading of the drainage for the main runway. Tenders for runway, apron, taxiway and access road repairs are expected to be called early in January 1987.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) It is correct that the Department of Aviation's planned change from a domestic to an international system of Distance Measuring Equipment (DME), is set to take place within the next 2 years; if not, when is it proposed that this change will take place.
(2) Where is international DME installed, in Australia, at present, and where is it proposed to be in operation in the near future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Aviation currently operates an Australian designed domestic distance measuring equipment (DME (D)) facilities from 108 locations throughout Australia. The System is incompatible with the ICAO international DME (DME (I)) system.

The Department also operates DME (I) facilities and when the currently approved programme is complete there will be 32 DME (I) facilities installed of which 25 will be colocated with DME (D) facilities. The DME (I) facilities meet the requirements for international and domestic wide bodied aircraft operations. Most modern aircraft are already equipped with DME (I) when purchased.

There is neither an approved programme nor any date set for a changeover from DME (D) to DME (I). The Department of Communications is seeking the early decommissioning of the DME (D) facilities to permit the allocation of two additional VHF TV channels in Australia. The domestic aviation industry have supported a timely changeover from DME (D) to DME (I). An acceptable programme and changeover date has yet to be finalised with the aviation industry, after which Government approval will have to be sought in the budget context. There are no funds in 1986-87.
The changeover would be expected to be completed within seven years of Government approval.
(2) The Department currently operates DME (I) facilities at 21 locations as follows:

Adelaide, Alice Springs, Brisbane, Caiguna, Cairns, Canberra, Coolangatta, Derby, Esperance, Hobart, Kununurra, Mallacoota, Melbourne, Mildura, Moomba, Mount Hope, Mount Isa, Norfolk Island, Perth, Port Hedland, Sydney.

Under the currently approved programme another 11 facilities are planned for installation over the next three years. Currently these 11 DME (I) facilities are proposed for installation at the following locations:
Barmount, Collinsville, Cunnamulla, Geraldton, Learmonth, Lord Howe Island, Mudgee, Parkes, Taroom, Thangool, Walgett.
The actual locations may be subject to change as a result of regular review of priorities, which includes consultation with the aviation industry.
